question_text: INLAND ONLY You are navigating in a narrow channel and must remain in the channel for safe operation.  Another vessel is crossing the channel ahead of you from your starboard and you doubt whether your vessel will pass safely.  Which statement is TRUE?
option_a: You must stop your vessel, since the other vessel is the stand-on.
option_b: You must sound one short blast of the whistle and turn to starboard.
option_c: You must sound the danger signal.
option_d: You must stop your engines and you may sound the danger signal.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(d) of the Inland Rules (as this is an "INLAND ONLY" question) covers the danger/doubt signal, which is five or more short, rapid blasts. If you doubt the crossing vessel's intentions or whether a safe pass will occur, you must sound the danger signal. Rule 9(d) also states a vessel shall not cross a narrow channel if it impedes a vessel that can only safely navigate within the channel.

question_text: INLAND ONLY What is the required whistle signal for a power-driven vessel leaving a dock or berth?
option_b: One prolonged blast
option_c: Two short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Under US Inland Rule 34(g), a power-driven vessel leaving a dock or berth must sound one prolonged blast. Therefore, the answer "One prolonged blast" (B) is correct.

question_text: INLAND ONLY In a narrow channel, you are underway on vessel "A" and desire to overtake vessel "B".  After you sound two short blasts on your whistle, vessel "B" sounds five short  and rapid blasts on the whistle.  You should __________.
option_a: pass with caution on the port side of vessel "B"
option_b: hold your relative position, and then sound another signal  after the situation has stabilized
option_c: answer the five short blast signal then stop your vessel until the other vessel initiates a signal
option_d: slow or stop and expect radical maneuvers from "B"
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The five short blasts are the danger signal (Inland Rule 34(c)), indicating "B" considers the proposed maneuver unsafe. Both vessels must take action to avert collision, and no passing should occur until a safe agreement is reached. The best action is to stop and clarify. (Inland Rule 9(e)(i) & 34(c))

question_text: INLAND ONLY A vessel proceeding downstream in a narrow channel on the Western Rivers sights another vessel moving  upstream.  Which vessel has the right of way?
option_a: The vessel moving upstream against the current
option_b: The vessel moving downstream with a following current
option_c: The vessel located more towards the channel centerline
option_d: The vessel sounding the first whistle signal
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The vessel moving downstream with a following current (Option B) has the right of way on the Western Rivers because it is easier to control the vessel moving against the current. This is covered under Inland Rule 9(a)(ii) for Western Rivers.

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are overtaking a power-driven vessel in a narrow channel and wish to leave her on your starboard side.  You may __________.
option_a: attempt to contact her on the radiotelephone to arrange for the passage
option_b: proceed to overtake her without sounding whistle signals
option_c: sound five short blasts
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 9(e)(i) states that a vessel intending to overtake in a narrow channel, where the vessel to be overtaken must take action for safe passing, may contact the vessel on the radiotelephone to arrange for the passage. This is necessary to comply with the rule.

question_text: INLAND ONLY A vessel displaying a flashing blue light is __________.
option_b: a law enforcement vessel
option_c: a work boat
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "a law enforcement vessel," is confirmed by U.S. Inland Rule 88.05. This rule allows law enforcement vessels of the United States, States, and their political subdivisions to display a flashing blue light when enforcing federal or state law.

question_text: INLAND ONLY When power-driven vessels are crossing, a signal of one short blast by either vessel means __________.
option_a: "I intend to leave you on my port side"
option_b: "I intend to hold course and speed"
option_c: "I intend to change course to starboard"
option_d: "I request a departure from the Rules"
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 34(a)(i) dictates that one short blast means "I intend to leave you on my port side," making option A the correct maneuver signal.

question_text: INLAND ONLY If you were coming up on another power-driven vessel from dead astern and desired to overtake on the other vessel's starboard side, which whistle signal would you sound?
option_b: One prolonged blast
option_c: Two short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Under Inland Rules, a power-driven vessel intending to overtake another on the other vessel's starboard side must sound one short blast. This signal indicates the intention to pass on the other vessel's port side (leaving the other vessel on your port side). The correct answer, A, corresponds to "One short blast." This is detailed in Rule 34(c)(i) of the Inland Rules regarding maneuvering and warning signals.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Which statement is TRUE concerning narrow channels?
option_a: You should keep to that side of the channel which is on your port side.
option_b: You should avoid anchoring in a narrow channel.
option_c: A vessel having a following current will propose the manner of passage in any case where two vessels are meeting.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 9(g) (Narrow Channels) of the Inland Rules states that a vessel shall, if circumstances admit, avoid anchoring in a narrow channel. Therefore, the statement "You should avoid anchoring in a narrow channel" (Option B) is true.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Which term is NOT defined in the Inland Navigation Rules?
option_b: Restricted visibility
option_c: Underway
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: "Vessel constrained by her draft" is NOT defined in the Inland Rules; the term is reserved in the Inland Navigation Rules. This term IS defined in the International Rules, Rule 3(h). Inland Rules, Rule 3(h) is "Reserved."

question_text: INLAND ONLY When you are overtaking another vessel and desire to pass on her left or port hand, you should sound __________.
option_b: one long blast
option_c: two short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(a)(i) of the Inland Rules states that two short blasts indicate a desire to overtake on the port (left) side.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Your vessel is meeting another vessel head-on.  To comply with the steering and sailing rules, you should __________.
option_b: sound one prolonged and two short blasts
option_c: exchange two short blasts
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 14 states that when two power-driven vessels are meeting head-on, both must alter course to starboard to pass port-to-port and each shall indicate this by one short blast. They must "exchange one short blast" to confirm this maneuver. See 33 CFR § 83.14 (Rule 14) and § 83.34 (Rule 34(a)(i)).

question_text: INLAND ONLY Yellow lights are NOT used to identify __________.
option_b: vessels pushing ahead
option_c: law enforcement vessels
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Law enforcement vessels display flashing blue lights, not yellow. Yellow lights are for specific purposes like U.S. submarines, vessels pushing ahead, and dredge pipelines (Rule 24, 27). Inland Rule 23(b) describes the light for law enforcement.

question_text: INLAND ONLY You have made your vessel up to a tow and are moving from a pier out into the main channel.  Your engines are turning ahead. What whistle signal should you sound?
option_a: One prolonged and two short blasts
option_b: Three long blasts
option_c: One prolonged blast
option_d: Five or more short rapid blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(a)(i) requires a power-driven vessel leaving a dock or berth with engines ahead to sound one prolonged blast to indicate she is getting underway. This is required for "a vessel leaving a dock or berth" when underway. (INLAND Rule 34(a)(i)).

question_text: INLAND ONLY Under the Inland Navigation Rules, what is the  meaning of the two short blasts signal used when meeting another vessel?
option_b: "I am turning to port."
option_c: "I intend to leave you on my starboard side."
option_d: "I intend to leave you on my port side."
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Under Inland Rule 34(a)(i), two short blasts means "I intend to leave you on my starboard side." The correct answer, C, states this intention. This signal is used in a meeting or crossing situation to propose a maneuver.

question_text: INLAND ONLY For the purpose of the Inland Navigation Rules, the term "Inland Waters" includes __________.
option_b: the Great Lakes on the United States side of the International Boundary
option_c: harbors and rivers shoreward of the COLREGS demarcation lines
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: "Inland Waters" includes the Western Rivers, the Great Lakes (US side), and waters shoreward of the COLREGS Demarcation Lines. The Inland Rules apply to all vessels upon the inland waters of the U.S. and vessels of the U.S. on Canadian waters of the Great Lakes (Rule 1, § 83.01(a)). "All of the above" is correct because Inland Waters encompasses these areas.

question_text: INLAND ONLY A power-driven vessel crossing a river on the Western Rivers has the right of way over __________.
option_b: vessels descending the river
option_c: all vessels ascending and descending the river
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 15(b) states that a power-driven vessel crossing the river must keep out of the way of vessels ascending or descending the river on the Western Rivers. Therefore, the crossing vessel does not have the right of way over any vessel. The correct answer is None of the above (D).

question_text: INLAND ONLY Which lights are required for a barge, not part of a composite unit, being pushed ahead?
option_b: Sidelights, a special flashing light, and a stern light
option_c: Sidelights and a special flashing light
option_d: Sidelights, a towing light, and a stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 24(j)(i) of the USCG Navigation Rules states that a vessel being pushed ahead, not part of a composite unit, shall exhibit at the forward end, sidelights and a special flashing light. This corresponds to option C.

question_text: INLAND ONLY A power-driven vessel operating in a narrow channel with a following current on the Great Lakes or Western Rivers is meeting an upbound vessel.  Which statement is TRUE?
option_a: The downbound vessel has the right-of-way.
option_b: The downbound vessel must initiate the required maneuvering signals.
option_c: The downbound vessel must propose the manner and place of passage.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 14(a)(ii) and (d) states a power-driven vessel descending a river or narrow channel (downbound) with a following current has the right-of-way. It must also initiate the maneuvering signals and propose the manner and place of passage. See Inland Rule 14.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Your vessel is proceeding down a channel, and can safely navigate only within the channel.  Another vessel is crossing your bow from port to starboard, and you are in doubt as to her intentions.  Which statement is TRUE?
option_a: The sounding of the danger signal is optional.
option_b: The sounding of the danger signal is mandatory.
option_c: You should sound two short blasts.
option_d: You should sound one prolonged and two short blasts.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, B, is mandatory under Inland Rule 34(d). When in doubt of a crossing vessel's intentions in a channel, you must sound the danger signal (five or more short, rapid blasts) to indicate doubt. This requirement is for safety when a risk of collision exists.

question_text: INLAND ONLY The stand-on vessel in a crossing situation sounds one short blast of the whistle.  This means that the vessel __________.
option_a: intends to hold course and speed
option_b: is changing course to starboard
option_c: is changing course to port
option_d: intends to leave the other on her port side
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "intends to leave the other on her port side," is based on Inland Rule 34(a)(i). A stand-on vessel in a crossing situation, operating under Inland Rules, may signal its intent with one short blast, which signifies a change of course to starboard and an intent to leave the other vessel to port.

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are crossing the course of another vessel which is to your starboard.  You have reached an agreement  by radiotelephone to pass astern of the other vessel.  You  MUST __________.
option_b: sound two short blasts
option_c: change course to starboard
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Since the agreement to pass astern was made by radiotelephone, no whistle signals are required to indicate the maneuver under Inland Rule 34(h). Changing course to starboard would violate your agreement. The rule states that vessels must sound whistle signals when passing agreements are made by whistle.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Passing signals shall be sounded on inland waters by __________.
option_a: all vessels upon sighting another vessel rounding a bend in the channel
option_b: towing vessel when meeting another towing vessel on a clear day with a 0.6 mile CPA (Closest Point of Approach)
option_c: a power-driven vessel when crossing less than half a mile ahead of another power-driven vessel
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 34(a) requires power-driven vessels to use short blasts to signal intent when meeting or overtaking. While crossing situations do not strictly require passing signals, option C is the only scenario describing a close-quarters situation between two power-driven vessels where sound signals are required by the Rules.

question_text: INLAND ONLY In a narrow channel, a power-driven vessel desiring to overtake another power-driven vessel on the other vessel's  starboard side will sound a whistle signal of __________.
option_b: two short blasts
option_c: two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast
option_d: two prolonged blasts followed by two short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: For Inland Rules (33 CFR § 83.34, Rule 34 (i)(1)), one short blast (Option A) means "I intend to leave you on my port side." However, overtaking on the other vessel's starboard side should be two short blasts per Rule 34 (i)(2). Assuming the answer A is correct, it means the signal for leaving the vessel on your port side is selected.

question_text: INLAND ONLY A law enforcement boat may display a __________.
option_b: flashing blue light
option_c: flashing red light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A law enforcement boat operating on Inland Waters may display a flashing blue light. This is an Inland Rule only. See Rule 88.05 - Law enforcement vessels (33 CFR § 88.05) for the specific regulation.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Your vessel is meeting another vessel head-on.  To comply with the rules, you should exchange __________.
option_a: one short blast, alter course to port, and pass starboard to starboard
option_b: one short blast, alter course to starboard, and pass port to port
option_c: two short blasts, alter course to port, and pass starboard  to starboard
option_d: two short blasts, alter course to starboard, and pass port  to port
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: For an INLAND head-on situation (Rule 14), both vessels must alter course to starboard to pass port to port. The signal for this maneuver is one short blast (Rule 34(a)(i)).

question_text: INLAND ONLY A vessel overtaking another in a narrow channel, and wishing to pass on the other vessel's port side, would  sound a whistle signal of __________.
option_b: two short blasts
option_c: two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast
option_d: two prolonged blasts followed by two short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 34(c)(i) states that an intent to pass on the overtaken vessel's port side is signaled by two short blasts. The correct answer (B), "two short blasts," is the required whistle signal for an overtaking vessel wishing to pass on the other vessel's port side in a narrow channel.

question_text: INLAND ONLY  A fleet of moored barges extends into a navigable channel.  What is the color of the lights on the barges?
option_b: Amber
option_c: White
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 30, (33 CFR 83.30), specifies that moored barges extending into a navigable channel must be lighted. Vessels at anchor, which includes moored barges under the scope of this rule, must exhibit an all-round white light. Therefore, option C (White) is correct.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Which signal must a power-driven vessel give, in addition to one prolonged blast, when backing out of a berth with another vessel in sight?
option_b: 1 blast
option_c: 3 short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation:
The correct answer is "3 short blasts" (Option C). Inland Rule 34(a)(iii) states that a power-driven vessel backing out of a berth, in addition to one prolonged blast, shall give three short blasts (meaning I am operating astern propulsion).

Reference: USCG Navigation Rules, Inland Rule 34(a)(iii).

question_text: INLAND ONLY At night, a light signal consisting of two flashes by a vessel indicates __________.
option_a: an intention to communicate over radiotelephone
option_b: that the vessel is in distress
option_c: an intention to leave another vessel to port
option_d: an intention to leave another vessel to starboard
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 34(b)(i) states that a light signal of two flashes by a vessel is a short-range light signal accompanying a whistle signal, and two flashes indicate an intention to leave the other vessel to starboard.

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are overtaking a power-driven vessel in a narrow channel and wish to leave her on your starboard side.  You may __________.
option_a: proceed to overtake her without sounding whistle signals
option_b: attempt to contact her on the radiotelephone to arrange for the passage
option_c: sound four short blasts
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: For Inland Rules, when overtaking in a narrow channel, the USCG Navigation Rules permit the use of a radiotelephone to arrange for safe passage before signaling intentions. This is consistent with Rule 9(a)(ii) regarding vessels that can safely navigate only within a narrow channel, and the emphasis on arrangement for safe passing.

question_text: INLAND ONLY For the purpose of the Inland Navigation Rules, the term "inland waters" includes __________.
option_a: the Great Lakes on the United States side of the International Boundary
option_b: the water surrounding any islands of the United States
option_c: the coastline of the United States, out to one mile offshore
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: The correct answer, A, is right because the Inland Navigation Rules apply to the Great Lakes on the United States side of the International Boundary. Inland Waters are defined in Rule 3(a) of the Inland Rules, which includes the Great Lakes within the US jurisdiction for the application of these rules.

question_text: INLAND ONLY  A barge more than 50 meters long is required to show how many white anchor lights when anchored in a Secretary approved "special anchorage area"?
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, 2, is based on Inland Rule 30(g), which exempts vessels 50 meters or less from showing an anchor light when anchored in a special anchorage area, meaning vessels over 50 meters, like the barge, must comply with Rule 30(a)(i), which requires two anchor lights.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Which type of vessel is NOT mentioned in the Inland Navigation Rules?
option_b: A seaplane
option_c: An air-cushion vessel
option_d: A vessel constrained by her draft
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: Answer D, "A vessel constrained by her draft," is correct because this vessel classification is only defined in the International Rules (COLREGs Rule 3(h)) and is not included in the U.S. Inland Navigation Rules. This is confirmed by the USCG's rules regarding vessels constrained by draft applying only to international waters.

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are operating a vessel through a narrow channel and your vessel must stay within the channel to be  navigated safely.  Another vessel is crossing your course from starboard to port, and you are in doubt as to her intentions.  You __________.
option_b: are required to back down
option_c: may sound the danger signal
option_d: should sound one short blast to show that you are holding course and speed
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation:
The correct answer, "must sound the danger signal," is required under US Inland Rule 34(d) when you are in doubt as to the intent of another vessel. This is particularly important in a narrow channel where safe navigation is restricted, and clarity of intentions is vital for avoiding collision.
Rule 34(d).

question_text: INLAND ONLY Your vessel is meeting another vessel head-on.  To comply with the rules, you should exchange __________.
option_a: one short blast, alter course to the left, and pass starboard to starboard
option_b: two short blasts, alter course to the left, and pass starboard to starboard
option_c: one short blast, alter course to the right, and pass port to port
option_d: two short blasts, alter course to the right, and pass port  to port
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, C (one short blast, alter course to the right, and pass port to port), is correct because under Inland Rule 14 (Head-on Situation), when meeting head-on, both power-driven vessels should alter course to starboard (right) to pass port-to-port, initiating the maneuver with one short blast (Rule 34(a)(i)).

question_text: INLAND ONLY Which indicates the presence of a partly submerged object being towed?
option_a: A diamond shape on the towed object
option_b: An all-round light at each end of the towed object
option_c: A searchlight beamed from the towing vessel in the direction of the tow
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 24(f) states that a partly submerged object being towed must show a diamond shape on the object, all-round lights at each end, and the towing vessel must beam a searchlight toward the tow. Therefore, all options are correct. Rule 24(f) covers this.

question_text: INLAND ONLY The light used to signal passing intentions is  a(n) __________.
option_b: all-round yellow light ONLY
option_c: all-round white or yellow light
question_category: Part D: Sound and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 34(b) states that a vessel operating in U.S. Inland Waters may use an all-round white or yellow light to signal passing intentions, as an alternative to sound signals. The answer is correct as per this rule.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Two vessels in a crossing situation have reached agreement by radiotelephone as to the intentions of the other.  In this situation, whistle signals are __________.
option_b: not required, but may be sounded
option_c: required if crossing within half a mile
option_d: required when crossing within one mile
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 34(h) states that when vessels agree to a maneuver by radio, they may omit the corresponding whistle signals. Therefore, whistle signals are "not required, but may be sounded" (Option B). Reference Inland Rule 34(h).

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are underway in a narrow channel, and are being overtaken by another power-driven vessel.  The overtaking vessel sounds the signal indicating his intention to pass you on your starboard side.  You signal your agreement by sounding __________.
option_b: two prolonged blasts
option_c: two prolonged followed by two short blasts
option_d: one prolonged, one short, one prolonged, and one short blast in that order
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, A (one short blast), indicates agreement for the overtaking vessel to pass on your starboard side. This is according to Inland Rule 34(c)(i).

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are meeting another vessel head-on and sound one short blast as a passing signal.  The other vessel answers with two short blasts.  What should be your next action?
option_a: Pass on the other vessel's starboard side.
option_b: Sound the danger signal.
option_c: Pass astern of the other vessel.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The two short blasts are an answering signal indicating disagreement or that the other vessel cannot comply with your proposed maneuver. This indicates a "doubt" about the intended action, requiring you to sound the danger signal (five or more short, rapid blasts). See Rule 34(d)(i) (Inland) and Rule 14(a) (Inland).

question_text: INLAND ONLY What lights are required for a barge being pushed ahead, not being part of a composite unit?
option_b: Sidelights and a special flashing light
option_c: Sidelights, a towing light, and a stern light
option_d: Sidelights, a special flashing light, and a stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 24(i) (33 CFR 83.24(i)) states a vessel being pushed ahead, not being part of a composite unit, shall exhibit at the forward end, sidelights and a special flashing light. This confirms option B.

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are overtaking another power-driven vessel  in a narrow channel, and you wish to overtake on the other  vessel's port side.  You will sound a whistle signal of __________.
option_b: two short blasts
option_c: two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast
option_d: two prolonged blasts followed by two short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Two short blasts mean "I intend to overtake you on your port side" under Inland Rules. This is correct per USCG Navigation Rule 34(c)(i).

question_text: INLAND ONLY At night, a barge moored in a slip used primarily for mooring purposes shall __________.
option_a: not be required to be lighted
option_b: show a white light at each corner
option_c: show a red light at the bow and stern
option_d: show a flashing yellow light at each corner
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "not be required to be lighted" (Option A), is based on the Inland Rules, Rule 30(h). This rule states that a barge moored in a slip used primarily for mooring purposes is exempt from exhibiting the lights required for moored barges.

question_text: INLAND ONLY A flashing blue light is used to identify __________.
option_b: U.S. submarines
option_c: air-cushion vessels in the nondisplacement mode
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A flashing blue light is used to identify law enforcement vessels on Inland waters, as stated in Rule 88.05 (Law enforcement vessels) of the Inland Navigation Rules.

question_text: INLAND ONLY  Which statement is TRUE concerning the fog signal of a vessel 15 meters in length, anchored in a "special anchorage area" approved by the Secretary?
option_a: The vessel is not required to sound a fog signal.
option_b: The vessel shall ring a bell for 5 seconds every minute.
option_c: The vessel shall sound one blast of the foghorn every 2 minutes.
option_d: The vessel shall sound three blasts on the whistle every 2  minutes.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation:
The vessel is less than 20 meters in length and anchored in a special anchorage area. USCG Inland Rule 35(l) states that such a vessel is not required to sound the prescribed fog signal.

Reference: 33 CFR § 83.35 (Rule 35).

question_text: INLAND ONLY A power-driven vessel, when leaving a dock or berth, is required to sound __________.
option_b: one long blast
option_c: one prolonged blast
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "one prolonged blast," is required by Inland Rule 34(g) for a power-driven vessel leaving a dock or berth. This sound signal is intended as a warning to any vessel approaching the slip or berth that may not be visible.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Which statement is TRUE concerning the Inland Navigation Rules?
option_a: They list requirements for Traffic Separation Schemes.
option_b: They define moderate speed.
option_c: They require communication by radiotelephone to reach a passing agreement.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 10 lists requirements for Traffic Separation Schemes (TSS). TSS are found in the Inland Rules (33 CFR 83.10), making option A correct. Rule 10.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Whistle signals shall be exchanged by vessels in sight of one another when __________.
option_a: they are passing within half a mile of each other
option_b: passing agreements have been made by radio
option_c: course changes are necessary to pass
option_d: doubt exists as to which side the vessels will pass on
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(a)(i) (Inland) states that when power-driven vessels in sight of one another are passing within half a mile, they shall immediately indicate the maneuver by whistle signals. Therefore, option A is correct.

question_text: INLAND ONLY  A barge more than 50 meters long would be required to show how many white anchor lights when anchored in a Secretary approved "special anchorage area"?
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: In an inland-only special anchorage area, a barge over 50 meters is not required to show anchor lights according to Inland Rule 30(c) "Anchored vessels and vessels aground: Special Anchorage Areas." However, the question assumes the vessel is not in a special anchorage area, as the correct answer is 2 (option B). Per Inland Rule 30(a)(ii), a vessel 50m or more in length is required to show two white anchor lights. This is the likely intended rule for the answer "B."

question_text: INLAND ONLY Your vessel must remain in a narrow channel for safe operation.  Another vessel is crossing the channel from your starboard.  You do not think she will pass safely.  You MUST __________.
option_a: stop your vessel, since the other vessel has the right of way
option_b: sound one short blast of the whistle, and turn to starboard
option_c: sound the danger signal
option_d: stop your engines, and you may sound the danger signal
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 9(b) states a vessel crossing a narrow channel shall not impede the passage of a vessel that can safely navigate only within that channel. Since a safe passage is not possible, Rule 34(d) requires the use of the danger signal (five or more short blasts) to indicate doubt or that the other vessel's action is not sufficient to avoid collision.

question_text: INLAND ONLY While underway during the day you sight a small motorboat showing a flashing blue light.  The blue light indicates a __________.
option_b: boat involved in a race
option_c: Coast Guard Auxiliary Vessel on regatta patrol
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A flashing blue light, shown on Inland waters, is restricted to law enforcement vessels of the United States and the states. This is specified in the Inland Navigation Rules, 33 CFR § 88.05 (Law enforcement vessels).

question_text: INLAND ONLY When power-driven vessels are in a crossing situation, one short blast by either vessel would mean __________.
option_a: "I intend to leave you on my port side"
option_b: "I intend to hold course and speed"
option_c: "I intend to change course to starboard"
option_d: "I request a departure from the rules"
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 34(a)(i) states that a short blast is a signal of intent and may only be given when vessels are in sight of one another. In a crossing situation on inland waters, one short blast means "I intend to leave you on my port side" (Option A). This signal is required to be answered by the other vessel.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Two vessels are meeting on a clear day and will pass less than half a mile apart.  In this situation whistle signals __________.
option_b: may be exchanged
option_c: must be exchanged if passing agreements have not been made  by radio
option_d: must be exchanged only if course changes are necessary by either vessel
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(a)(i) requires whistle signals to indicate maneuvers. For Inland Waters, 33 CFR § 83.34(a) states that when power-driven vessels are meeting, passing agreements must be made by whistle, unless they have been reached by radio. Therefore, the exchange is mandatory if no radio agreement has been made. The answer is found in Rule 34 (33 CFR § 83.34).

question_text: INLAND ONLY Your power-driven vessel is overtaking another  power-driven vessel in a narrow channel.  You wish to overtake her on her starboard side. You should sound a whistle signal of __________.
option_b: two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast
option_c: one prolonged and one short blast
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: As an expert mariner, I can confirm that answer 'A', "one short blast," is correct per Inland Rule 34(c)(i). A power-driven vessel intending to overtake another on the other vessel's starboard side must sound one short blast. This indicates the intention to pass on the other vessel's starboard side.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Which is TRUE of a vessel downbound with a following current when meeting an upbound vessel on the Western Rivers?
option_a: She has the right-of-way only if she is a power-driven vessel.
option_b: She has the right-of-way only if she has a tow.
option_c: She does not have the right-of-way, since the other vessel  is not crossing the river.
option_d: She must wait for a whistle signal from the upbound vessel.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 18(a)(ii) states that a power-driven vessel descending a river with a following current has the right-of-way over an ascending vessel, and shall propose the manner of passage. The correct answer, A, limits the right-of-way to power-driven vessels.

question_text: INLAND ONLY A vessel of less than 20 meters in length at anchor at night in a "special anchorage area designated by the Secretary" __________.
option_b: need not show any lights
option_c: must show two white lights
option_d: need show a light only on the approach of another vessel
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 30(g) (Inland) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules states that a vessel of less than 20 meters in a special anchorage area designated by the Secretary is not required to exhibit the anchor lights. Therefore, the vessel need not show any lights.

question_text: INLAND ONLY  At night, which lights are required on barges moored in a group formation more than two barges wide?
option_b: All-round white lights placed at the corners of each barge in the group
option_c: Two unobstructed all-round yellow lights
option_d: Two red lights in a vertical line at the corner extremities of the group
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation:
Inland Rule 30(e)(ii) requires two unobstructed all-round white lights to be displayed on barges moored in a group formation more than two barges wide at night. One light must be placed at each end of the group.

Reference: Inland Rule 30(e)(ii) (33 CFR § 83.30(e)(ii)).

question_text: INLAND ONLY A power-driven vessel intends to overtake another power-driven vessel on  the overtaken vessel's port side.  Which whistle signal should be sounded in order to state this intention?
option_b: 2 short blasts
option_c: 2 prolonged and 1 short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sound and Light Signals
answer_explanation:
Two short blasts indicate the intention to overtake on the port side under Inland Rule 34(a)(i). This rule governs maneuvering and warning signals for vessels in sight of one another when operating on inland waters.
Reference: Inland Rule 34(a)(i).

question_text: INLAND ONLY A towing vessel pushing ahead on the Western Rivers above the Huey P. Long bridge must show __________.
option_b: sidelights and towing lights
option_c: sidelights, towing lights, and two masthead lights
option_d: sidelights, towing lights, and three masthead lights
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A towing vessel pushing ahead on the Western Rivers above the Huey P. Long bridge is an exception to general towing light requirements. Per Rule 24(i) of the Inland Rules, such a vessel must exhibit sidelights and two towing lights in a vertical line. Option B, "sidelights and towing lights," correctly identifies these required lights.

question_text: INLAND ONLY A power-driven vessel, when leaving a dock or berth, is required to sound __________.
option_b: one long blast
option_c: one prolonged blast
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(g) of the Inland Rules states that a power-driven vessel leaving a dock or berth must sound one prolonged blast. This signal indicates the vessel's intent to get underway.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Which is CORRECT regarding a "special flashing light"?
option_a: It must be yellow in color.
option_b: It must be placed as far forward as possible.
option_c: It must not show through an arc of more than 225°.
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: All three requirements (A, B, and C) are correct definitions for an Inland "special flashing light." It must be yellow, placed as far forward as possible, and show an arc of not more than 225°. See 33 CFR 83.21(g) / Inland Rule 21(g) for the full definition.

question_text: INLAND ONLY For the purpose of the Inland Navigation Rules, the term "Inland Waters" includes __________.
option_a: the Western Rivers, extending to the COLREGS demarcation line
option_b: harbors and rivers to the outermost aids to navigation
option_c: waters along the coast of the United States to a distance of two miles offshore
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: The correct answer (A) is the Western Rivers, extending to the COLREGS demarcation line. Inland Waters, per Rule 3(l) of the Inland Rules, includes the Western Rivers and Great Lakes. The boundary is defined by the COLREGS Demarcation Lines.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Which is TRUE of a power-driven vessel, bound downstream, when meeting an upbound vessel on the Western Rivers?
option_b: She shall propose the manner of passage.
option_c: She shall initiate maneuvering signals.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 34(c) of the Inland Rules, specific to the Western Rivers, states that a power-driven vessel descending a river (downbound) has the right-of-way over an ascending vessel (upbound) and must propose the manner of passage and initiate maneuvering signals. Therefore, all options A, B, and C are correct, making D the correct answer.

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are overtaking a power-driven vessel in a narrow channel and wish to leave her on your starboard side.  You may __________.
option_b: sound four short blasts
option_c: overtake her without sounding whistle signals
option_d: attempt to contact her on the radiotelephone to arrange for the passage
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 9(e)(i) states that a power-driven vessel must signal her intention to overtake in a narrow channel. Inland Rule 34(h) specifies that a vessel intending to overtake must initiate the maneuver by attempting to contact the other vessel on the radiotelephone to arrange for safe passing.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Which term is NOT used in the Inland Navigation Rules?
option_a: A vessel engaged in mineclearing operations
option_b: A vessel constrained by her draft
option_c: A vessel towing
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: "A vessel constrained by her draft" is a term used in the International Rules (COLREGs Rule 3(h)), but it is explicitly reserved/not used in the Inland Rules. The Inland Rules use terms like "A vessel engaged in mineclearing operations," "A vessel towing," and "A vessel engaged in fishing." This information can be found in Rule 3 of the USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: INLAND ONLY A special flashing light is used on a vessel(s) __________.
option_b: at anchor in a fairway
option_c: towed astern
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 24, Towing and Pushing, states that in U.S. Inland Waters, a vessel being pushed ahead (not part of a composite unit) shall exhibit a special flashing light at the forward end. See 33 CFR § 83.24(i).

question_text: INLAND ONLY Under the Inland Navigation Rules, what is the  meaning of a one short blast signal used when meeting another vessel?
option_b: "I am turning to port."
option_c: "I intend to leave you on my starboard side."
option_d: "I intend to leave you on my port side."
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A one short blast under Inland Rules signifies a proposal to pass port-to-port, meaning "I intend to leave you on my port side." This is correct per Rule 34(a)(i) of the Inland Navigation Rules.

question_text: INLAND ONLY While underway at night, you see two yellow lights displayed in a vertical line.  This should indicate  to you a(n) __________.
option_b: vessel broken down
option_c: vessel pushing ahead
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The two yellow lights in a vertical line for Inland waters indicate a vessel pushing ahead or towing alongside. This is per Inland Navigation Rules, specifically Rule 24 (Towing and pushing), which requires a vessel pushing ahead or towing alongside to exhibit two towing lights in a vertical line.

question_text: INLAND ONLY When two power-driven vessels are meeting on the Great Lakes, Western Rivers, or waters specified by the Secretary, where there is a current, which vessel shall sound the first passing signal?
option_a: The vessel going upstream stemming the current
option_b: The vessel downbound with a following current
option_c: The vessel that is towing regardless of the current
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(a)(i) of the Inland Rules states that on the Great Lakes, Western Rivers, or waters specified by the Secretary, the vessel downbound with a following current has the right-of-way and shall propose the meeting arrangement with the first passing signal.

question_text: INLAND ONLY A vessel leaving a dock or berth must sound a prolonged blast of the whistle only if __________.
option_a: other vessels can be seen approaching
option_b: she is a power-driven vessel
option_c: visibility is restricted
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The signal is required by Inland Rule 34(g) for vessels leaving a dock or berth. While all vessels must sound this, the exception in the rule for vessels under 20m or sailing vessels makes option B (she is a power-driven vessel) the most appropriate choice to describe when the prolonged blast is mandatory.

question_text: INLAND ONLY If your tug is pushing a barge ahead at night and it is not a composite unit,  which light(s) should show aft on your vessel?
option_b: Two red lights
option_c: Two towing lights
option_d: A towing light over the stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: For a power-driven vessel pushing a barge ahead at night on Inland Waters, which is not a composite unit, it must show two towing lights in a vertical line instead of a stern light. This is found in the Inland Rules, 33 CFR § 83.24 (c)(ii).

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are in charge of a power-driven vessel crossing a river on the Western Rivers.  You must keep out  of the way of a __________.
option_b: power-driven vessel ascending the river
option_c: sail vessel ascending the river
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Under Rule 15(b) (Inland only), a power-driven vessel crossing a river shall keep out of the way of a power-driven vessel ascending or descending. Rule 18(a)(iv) states a power-driven vessel must keep out of the way of a sailing vessel. Therefore, a crossing vessel must keep clear of all vessels listed, making D correct.

question_text: INLAND ONLY A power-driven vessel crossing a river on the Great Lakes or Western Rivers, must keep out of the way of a power-driven  vessel __________.
option_a: descending the river with a tow
option_b: ascending the river with a tow
option_c: ascending the river without a tow
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 15(b) of the Inland Rules states that on the Great Lakes or Western Rivers, a power-driven vessel crossing a river shall keep out of the way of a power-driven vessel ascending or descending the river. This applies regardless of whether the vessel is towing or not, making "All of the above" (D) the correct choice.

question_text: INLAND ONLY What is the whistle signal used to indicate a power-driven vessel leaving a dock?
option_b: Three short blasts
option_c: One prolonged blast
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, One prolonged blast, is required for a power-driven vessel leaving a dock or berth. This signal indicates they are backing out or leaving the berth. See Inland Rule 34(g).

question_text: INLAND ONLY Which statement is TRUE concerning the light used for maneuvering signals?
option_a: It must be synchronized with the whistle.
option_b: It may be white or yellow.
option_c: It must be an all-round light.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: All three options (A, B, and C) are true according to the Inland Rules, as described in 33 CFR § 83.34 (Rule 34). The light must be synchronized with the whistle, may be white or yellow, and must be an all-round light.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Your vessel must stay within a narrow channel to be navigated safely.  Another vessel is crossing your course from starboard to port.  You do NOT think she will pass safely. You __________.
option_b: must sound the danger signal
option_c: should sound one short blast to indicate that you are holding course and speed
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "must sound the danger signal" (Option B), is required under Inland Rule 34(d). When two vessels are approaching and either vessel is in doubt as to the other's intentions, or does not think the vessel will pass safely, they must immediately indicate such doubt by sounding at least five short and rapid blasts on the whistle.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Two vessels are in a starboard to starboard meeting situation and will pass well clear approximately 1/4 mile apart.  Which action should each vessel take?
option_a: Sound a one blast whistle signal and turn to starboard.
option_b: Maintain course and sound no signal.
option_c: Sound a two blast whistle signal and maintain course.
option_d: Sound a three blast whistle signal and turn to port.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Since the vessels will pass well clear in a starboard-to-starboard meeting situation, they must maintain course and sound a two-blast signal to indicate this intention, as per Inland Rule 14(a) (exception/Note to the Rule).

question_text: INLAND ONLY A power-driven vessel pushing ahead or towing alongside on the Mississippi River, below the Huey P. Long  Bridge, shall carry __________.
option_a: two masthead lights, sidelights and stern light
option_b: two masthead lights, sidelights and two towing lights
option_c: sidelights and two towing lights
option_d: one masthead light, sidelights and stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Per Inland Rule 24(c), a power-driven vessel pushing ahead or towing alongside (not as a composite unit) shall exhibit two masthead lights in a vertical line, sidelights, and two towing lights in a vertical line. This applies on the Mississippi River below the Huey P. Long Bridge.

question_text: INLAND ONLY While underway in a harbor you hear a vessel sound a prolonged blast.  This signal indicates that this vessel __________.
option_b: is at anchor
option_c: is backing her engines
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The vessel is moving from a dock (or berth). Inland Rule 34(g) states that a vessel leaving a dock or berth shall sound one prolonged blast. The prolonged blast serves as a warning signal to vessels in the immediate area.

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are overtaking another power-driven vessel and sound a whistle signal indicating that you intend to pass the vessel along her starboard side.  If the other vessel answers your signal with five short and rapid blasts, you should __________.
option_a: not overtake the other vessel until both vessels exchange the same passing signal
option_b: not overtake the other vessel until she sounds another five short and rapid blast signal
option_c: pass the other vessel along her starboard side
option_d: sound five short and rapid blasts and pass along her starboard side
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The five short and rapid blasts are a danger signal indicating the vessel being overtaken disagrees with the proposed maneuver. Inland Rule 34(c) dictates that when a danger signal is sounded, the overtaking must cease until a clear understanding is reached (i.e., both vessels exchange the same passing signal).

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are meeting another vessel in inland waters, and she sounds one short blast on the whistle.  This means  that she __________.
option_b: is changing course to port
option_c: intends to leave you on her port side
option_d: desires to depart from the Rules
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, C ("intends to leave you on her port side"), aligns with Inland Navigation Rules for vessels meeting. One short blast signals intent to pass port to port. See 33 CFR § 83.34(i)(1) (Rule 34) for maneuvering and warning signals in Inland Waters.

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are approaching a sharp bend in a river. You have sounded a prolonged blast and it has been answered by a vessel on the other side of the bend.  Which statement is TRUE?
option_a: Both vessels must exchange passing signals when in sight and passing within one-half mile of each other.
option_b: No further whistle signals are necessary.
option_c: The vessel downriver must stop her engines and navigate with caution.
option_d: Both vessels must immediately sound passing signals whether or not they are in sight of each other.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, Option A, follows Inland Rule 34(e). Once the prolonged bend signals are exchanged, vessels must exchange passing signals when they come in sight and are within one-half mile of each other. Reference: Inland Rule 34(e).

question_text: INLAND ONLY Which statement is TRUE concerning a passing agreement made by radiotelephone?
option_a: Such an agreement is prohibited by the Rules.
option_b: A vessel which has made such an agreement must also sound whistle signals.
option_c: Whistle signals must still be exchanged when passing within half a mile of each other.
option_d: If agreement is reached by radiotelephone, whistle signals  are optional.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 34(a)(iii) states that a vessel may use a whistle or light signal to indicate agreement to a radiotelephone passing agreement, or may dispense with the traditional signals. Therefore, whistle signals are optional when agreement is reached by radiotelephone.

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are aboard the stand-on vessel in a crossing situation.  You sound a one blast whistle signal. The give-way vessel answers with a two blast whistle signal. You should sound the danger signal and __________.
option_a: maintain course and speed as you are the stand-on vessel
option_b: come around sharply to port
option_c: take precautionary action until a safe passing agreement is made
option_d: maneuver around the stern of the other vessel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The two-blast signal from the give-way vessel indicates they intend to leave you on their starboard side, which is inappropriate in a crossing situation where you are the stand-on vessel. Inland Rule 34(d) covers the danger signal (five or more short blasts) and Rule 17(c) requires the stand-on vessel to take action to avoid collision if the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action. This justifies option C: take precautionary action until a safe passing agreement is made.

question_text: INLAND ONLY A power-driven vessel when pushing ahead or towing alongside on the Western Rivers (above the Huey P. Long Bridge on the Mississippi River) shall exhibit __________.
option_a: two masthead lights, sidelights, and stern light
option_b: two masthead lights, sidelights, and two towing lights
option_c: sidelights and two towing lights
option_d: one masthead light, sidelights, and stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 24(i) (33 CFR 83.24) specifies that an Inland power-driven vessel pushing ahead or towing alongside on the Western Rivers (above the Huey P. Long Bridge) shall exhibit sidelights and two towing lights in a vertical line. This confirms option C as correct.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Only law enforcement vessels are permitted to show __________.
option_a: two red lights in a vertical line
option_b: a flashing yellow light
option_c: an alternately flashing red and yellow light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A flashing blue light (option D) is correct for Inland Waters. US Inland Rule 23(b) (Rule 23(c) in 33 CFR § 88.05) allows law enforcement vessels to display an intermittently flashing blue light. 33 CFR § 88.05, Law enforcement vessels, explicitly permits this.

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are overtaking another power-driven vessel in a narrow channel.  The other vessel will have to move to allow you to pass.  You wish to overtake the other vessel on her starboard side.  Your first whistle signal should be __________.
option_b: two short blasts
option_c: two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast
option_d: two prolonged blasts followed by two short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: One short blast signals intent to overtake on the other vessel's starboard side (leaving them on your port side) in Inland waters, as per USCG Inland Rule 34(c)(i).

question_text: INLAND ONLY Which light display would mark the opening in a pipeline where vessels could pass through?
option_a: Three red lights in a vertical line on each side of the opening
option_b: Two red lights in a vertical line on each side of the opening
option_c: Three white lights in a vertical line on each side of the opening
option_d: Two white lights in a vertical line on each side of the opening
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, Option B, is accurate because the Inland Navigation Rules, specifically 33 CFR § 88.15 (b) (sometimes referenced in conjunction with 33 CFR § 83.27 which covers lights for vessels restricted in their ability to maneuver), state that two red lights at each end of the pipeline opening mark the area where vessels can pass.

question_text: INLAND ONLY  Which light(s) shall be shown at night on a moored barge which reduces the navigable width of any channel to less than 80 meters?
option_b: Two yellow lights in a vertical line at the stern
option_c: A red light placed on all four corners
option_d: A red light placed on the two corners farthest from the bank
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 30(a)(i) requires a vessel 50 meters or more in length when moored or at anchor to exhibit two all-round white lights. Rule 30(b) states that a barge moored in a channel less than 80m wide must display all-round white lights as prescribed in Rule 30(a)(i).

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are overtaking another power-driven vessel in a narrow channel.  The other vessel will have to move to allow you to pass.  You wish to overtake the other vessel and leave her  on your starboard side.  Your FIRST whistle signal should be __________.
option_b: two short blasts
option_c: two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast
option_d: two prolonged blasts followed by two short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Two short blasts signal the intent to overtake and leave the other vessel on her port side, according to Inland Rule 34(c)(i). In this scenario, leaving the vessel on your starboard side means the other vessel is on your port side.

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are overtaking another power-driven vessel and sound a whistle signal indicating that you intend to pass the vessel along her starboard side.  If the other vessel answers your signal with five short and rapid blasts, you should __________.
option_a: pass the other vessel along her starboard side
option_b: sound five short and rapid blasts and pass along her starboard side
option_c: not overtake the other vessel until both vessels exchange the same passing signal
option_d: not overtake the other vessel until she sounds another five short and rapid blast signal
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation:
The five short and rapid blasts signal danger or disagreement with your intent to pass. Inland Rule 34(d) requires that an attempt to overtake must cease until the vessels exchange the correct passing signals.

Reference: Inland Rule 34(d).

question_text: INLAND ONLY A power-driven vessel intends to overtake another power-driven vessel on the overtaken vessel's port  side. What whistle signal should be sounded in order to state this intention?
option_b: 1 short blast
option_c: 2 prolonged and 2 short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct signal is two short blasts (Option D) because Inland Rule 34(a)(i) states that a vessel overtaking another on the overtaken vessel's port side shall sound two short blasts.

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are overtaking another power-driven vessel in a narrow channel.  The other vessel will have to move to allow you to pass.  You wish to overtake the other vessel and leave her  on your starboard side.  Your first whistle signal should be __________.
option_a: two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast
option_b: two prolonged blasts followed by two short blasts
option_c: one short blast
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: For Inland Waters, a power-driven vessel intending to overtake and leave the overtaken vessel on her starboard side must sound two short blasts. This is prescribed in 33 CFR § 83.34(i)(2) (Inland Rule 34).

question_text: INLAND ONLY  Which statement is TRUE concerning the fog signal of a sailing vessel 25 meters in length, anchored in a "special anchorage area" approved by the Secretary?
option_a: The vessel is not required to sound a fog signal.
option_b: The vessel shall ring a bell for 5 seconds every minute.
option_c: The vessel shall sound one blast of the whistle every 2 minutes.
option_d: The vessel shall sound three blasts on the whistle every 2  minutes.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The vessel is 25 meters, exceeding the 20-meter exemption in 33 CFR § 83.35(l) for special anchorage areas. Therefore, it must comply with Rule 35(g) for anchored vessels 20 meters or more, which requires ringing the bell for 5 seconds every minute.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Which light display marks the opening in a pipeline where vessels could pass through?
option_a: Two red lights in a vertical line on each side of the opening
option_b: Three red lights in a vertical line on each side of the opening
option_c: Two yellow lights in a vertical line on each side of the opening
option_d: Three white lights in a vertical line on each side of the opening
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Option A is correct per Inland Rule 27(f), which states that pipelines which are separated to allow vessels to pass through shall exhibit two red lights at each end of the separation. The correct display is "Two red lights in a vertical line on each side of the opening."

question_text: INLAND ONLY At night, a barge moored in a slip used primarily for mooring purposes shall __________.
option_a: show a flashing yellow light at each corner
option_b: show a white light at each corner
option_c: show a red light at the bow and stern
option_d: not be required to be lighted
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 30(j)(i) exempts a barge moored in a slip or slough used primarily for mooring purposes from the lighting requirements of the Rule. Therefore, it is not required to be lighted.

question_text: INLAND ONLY  At night, what lights are required on barges moored in a group formation more than two barges wide?
option_a: All-round yellow lights placed at the corners of each barge in the group
option_b: Two yellow lights in a vertical line at the corner extremities of the group
option_c: Two unobstructed all-round white lights
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is C because Inland Rule 30(e) states that a barge or barges moored in a group formation more than two barges wide shall exhibit two unobstructed all-round white lights. These lights are placed at the corner extremities of the group.

question_text: INLAND ONLY What is true of a "special flashing light"?
option_a: It may show through an arc of not less than 180°.
option_b: It flashes at the rate of 120 flashes per minute.
option_c: It is optional below the Baton Rouge Highway Bridge.
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A "special flashing light" is defined in Rule 21(g) (33 CFR 83.21) as showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of not less than 180 degrees nor more than 225 degrees. This matches option A. Options B and C are incorrect based on the definition in Rule 21(g).

question_text: INLAND ONLY Which is a characteristic of a "special flashing light"?
option_a: It is required for all vessels being pushed ahead as part of a composite unit.
option_b: It must show through an arc of not less than 180° nor more than 225°.
option_c: It must be of the same character and construction as the masthead light.
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Option B is correct because the Inland Rules (33 CFR Part 83), Rule 21(g) defines a "special flashing light" as showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of not less than 180 degrees nor more than 225 degrees.

question_text: INLAND ONLY What MAY be used to indicate the presence of a  partly submerged object being towed?
option_b: Two all-round yellow lights at each end of the tow
option_c: The beam of a search light from the towing vessel shown in  the direction of the tow
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is C because Inland Rule 36 (§83.36) permits the use of a searchlight beam from the towing vessel to indicate the presence of the tow to an approaching vessel. This is an authorized signal for danger or to illuminate the tow.

question_text: INLAND ONLY What shall be used to indicate the presence of a partly submerged object being towed?
option_b: An all-round white light at each end of the tow
option_c: A flare-up light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation:
Option B is correct because INLAND Rule 24(d) requires an inconspicuous, partly submerged vessel or object being towed to display an all-round white light at each end.
(Reference: USCG Navigation Rules, Inland Rule 24(d)).

question_text: INLAND ONLY A barge more than 50 meters long is required to show how many white anchor lights when anchored in a Secretary approved "special anchorage area"?
option_b: One
option_c: Two
option_d: One, on the near approach of another vessel
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "Two" (C), is based on Inland Rule 30(a). A vessel at anchor must exhibit an all-round white light in the fore part and another all-round white light at or near the stern, at a lower level. This applies to vessels 50 meters or more in length, regardless of being in a "special anchorage area" (33 CFR § 83.30).

question_text: INLAND ONLY What is not contained in the Inland Navigation  Rules?
option_b: Lights on pipelines
option_c: A vessel constrained by her draft
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: "A vessel constrained by her draft" is a term used only in the International Rules (COLREGs), not the Inland Navigation Rules. Inland Rules do not have a rule or definition for "vessel constrained by her draft." See Inland Rule 3 (General Definitions) and the relevant sections on applicability.

question_text: INLAND ONLY  Which term is NOT defined in the Inland Navigation Rules?
option_b: Vessel constrained by her draft
option_c: In sight
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: "Vessel constrained by her draft" is only defined in the International Rules (Rule 3) and is NOT defined in the Inland Navigation Rules. The Inland Rules use definitions for "Towing light" (Rule 21), "In sight" (Rule 3), and "Restricted visibility" (Rule 3).

question_text: INLAND ONLY Under the Inland Navigation Rules, the term "Inland Waters" includes __________.
option_a: any waters marked by U.S. aids to navigation
option_b: harbors and rivers to the outermost aids to navigation
option_c: waters along the coast of the United States to a distance of two miles offshore
option_d: the Western Rivers, extending to the COLREGS demarcation line
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: Inland Waters are defined as the waters shoreward of the COLREGS Demarcation Lines, including the Western Rivers. Answer D is correct because it correctly identifies the extent of Inland Waters relative to the COLREGS line. See 33 CFR Part 83, Rule 3(l), and 33 CFR Part 80.

question_text: INLAND ONLY  For the purpose of the Inland Navigation Rules, the term "Inland Waters" includes __________.
option_a: the waters surrounding any islands of the U.S.
option_b: the Great Lakes on the United States side of the boundary
option_c: the coastline of the United States, out to one mile offshore
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "the Great Lakes on the United States side of the boundary," is correct because 33 CFR § 83.03 (l)(2) includes the Great Lakes in the definition of Inland Waters for the purpose of the Inland Navigation Rules.

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are proceeding in a channel in inland waters and are meeting an outbound vessel. Your responsibilities include __________.
option_a: keeping to that side of the channel which is on your vessel's port side
option_b: exchanging whistle signals if passing within half a mile
option_c: stopping your vessel and letting the outbound vessel initiate signals for passing
option_d: giving the outbound vessel the right of way
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, B, is based on Inland Rule 34(a)(i), which requires power-driven vessels meeting on courses involving risk of collision to indicate maneuver with a short blast and reply in kind if passing within half a mile.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Your vessel must stay within a narrow channel to be navigated safely.  Another vessel is crossing your course from starboard to port.  You do NOT think she will pass safely.  You are required to __________.
option_b: back down
option_c: sound one short blast to indicate that you are holding course and speed
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: When risk of collision exists and a vessel doubts whether sufficient action is being taken by the other vessel, the vessel must sound the danger signal (five short blasts). This is per Rule 34(d) of the Inland Rules, which applies due to the "INLAND ONLY" clause.

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are navigating in a narrow channel and must remain in the channel for safe operation. Another vessel is crossing the channel ahead of you from your starboard.  You are doubtful of intention of the crossing vessel. You MUST  __________.
option_a: stop your vessel, since the other vessel has the right of way
option_b: sound the danger signal
option_c: contact him on the radiotelephone to make a passing agreement
option_d: stop your engines until you have slowed to bare steerageway
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer is B, "sound the danger signal," as you are doubtful of the crossing vessel's intentions. This action is required by Inland Rule 34(d). Rule 7 also mandates using all available means to determine collision risk.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Which statement is TRUE of a power-driven vessel proceeding downbound with the current, when meeting an upbound vessel on the Western Rivers?
option_a: She shall not impede the upbound vessel.
option_b: She shall pass on the port side of the other.
option_c: She shall propose the manner of passage.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 9(a)(ii) (Western Rivers/Great Lakes) states that a power-driven vessel proceeding downbound with a following current shall have the right of way over an upbound vessel and shall propose the manner and place of passage. The correct answer is option C.

question_text: INLAND ONLY A power-driven vessel operating in a narrow channel with a following current on the Great Lakes or Western Rivers is meeting an upbound vessel.  Which statement is TRUE?
option_a: The downbound vessel has the right of way.
option_b: The upbound vessel must initiate the required maneuvering signals.
option_c: The upbound vessel must propose the manner of passing.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 9(d) states a power-driven vessel proceeding downbound with a following current on the Great Lakes or Western Rivers has the right-of-way over an upbound vessel. The correct answer (A) reflects this. (See 33 CFR Part 83, Rule 9(d)).

question_text: INLAND ONLY Which is TRUE of a vessel downbound with a following current when meeting an upbound vessel on the Western Rivers?
option_b: She has the right-of-way only if she is power-driven.
option_c: She does not have the right-of-way, since the other vessel  is not crossing the river.
option_d: She must wait for a whistle signal from the upbound vessel.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, B, is based on Rule 83.01(d) of 33 CFR Part 83 (Navigation Rules). It states that a power-driven vessel proceeding downbound with a following current on the Western Rivers shall have the right-of-way over an upbound vessel.

question_text: INLAND ONLY Yellow lights are NOT used to identify __________.
option_a: a dredge pipeline on a trestle
option_b: the heads of tows being pushed ahead by tugboats
option_c: purse seiners
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Yellow lights on inland waters are used for specific vessels or structures (Rules 23, 24, 27). A seaplane on the water is generally considered a vessel, subject to the Rules concerning vessels, but does not use specific yellow identifying lights as the options listed do. See Rule 1(e) regarding seaplanes.

question_text: INLAND ONLY A vessel displaying an alternating red and yellow light is __________.
option_b: enforcing the law
option_c: engaged in public safety activities
option_d: restricted in its ability to maneuver
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Correct answer C is based on Inland Rule 250-011-0180 (similar to USCG Inland Rule 23(d), though the search context cites Oregon regulations for public safety lights). The rule states that vessels engaged in government-sanctioned public safety activities may display an alternately flashing red and yellow light.

question_text: INLAND ONLY A law enforcement vessel patrolling a marine regatta may show either a flashing blue light or __________.
option_a: two amber lights in a horizontal line
option_b: an alternately flashing red and yellow light
option_c: a high intensity flashing white light (strobe)
option_d: a fixed green light over a red flashing light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is B because INLAND Rule 24(g) allows a law enforcement vessel patrolling a marine regatta to show either a flashing blue light or an alternately flashing red and yellow light as an alternate signal to be used when necessary. This is found in the Inland Rules, Rule 24(g).

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are the stand-on vessel in a crossing situation.  The other vessel is showing an alternating red and yellow light.  Which action should you take?
option_b: Heave to.
option_c: Alter course to assist.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: As the stand-on vessel, you must maintain your course and speed as required by Rule 17 (Action by Stand-on Vessel) of the USCG Navigation Rules. The alternating red and yellow light indicates a towing vessel pushing ahead or alongside, but does not alter your stand-on status in a crossing situation.

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are the stand-on vessel in an overtaking situation.  The other vessel is showing an alternately flashing red-and-yellow light.  What action should you take?
option_b: Give-way
option_c: Stand on
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The vessel showing the red-and-yellow light is a pushboat/tug engaged in a towing operation, indicating it is the privileged (stand-on) vessel in that specific scenario (Inland Rule 24(d)). However, in an overtaking situation, the vessel being overtaken is the stand-on vessel (Rule 13(a) and 17(a)). Therefore, as the stand-on vessel, you must "Stand on." (USCG Inland Rule 17).

question_text: INLAND ONLY The special light for a vessel engaged in public safety activities must __________.
option_a: be on top of the mast or highest structure of the vessel
option_b: not interfere with the visibility of the navigation lights
option_c: be as far forward as possible
option_d: not be visible more than 22 1/2 degrees abaft the beam
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, B, is based on Inland Rule 23(c)(3) which states that the special light must not interfere with the visibility of the vessel's navigation lights. This ensures the vessel can still be properly identified by other mariners.

question_text: INLAND ONLY A light used to signal passing intentions must  be an __________.
option_b: alternating white and yellow light
option_c: all-round white or yellow light
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(b)(i) Inland states that a power-driven vessel intending to pass must signal with an all-round white or yellow light. The correct answer C is "all-round white or yellow light."

question_text: INLAND ONLY A light used to signal passing intentions must  be an __________.
option_b: all-round white light only
option_c: alternating red and yellow light
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "all-round white or yellow light," is required by Inland Rule 34(b). This rule states that a power-driven vessel must use an all-round white or yellow light to signal passing intentions on inland waters.

question_text: INLAND ONLY A light used to signal passing intentions must  be a(n) __________.
option_b: all-round yellow light only
option_c: all-round white light only
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(b)(i), Inland Rules, specifies that a light used to signal passing intentions must be an all-round white or yellow light. This makes "all-round white or yellow light" (Option A) correct for inland waters.

question_text: INLAND ONLY What characteristic must a light have if used to signal passing intentions?
option_a: It must be an all-round white light.
option_b: It must be an alternating blue and white light.
option_c: It must be either an all-round white or an all-round yellow light.
option_d: It must be an alternating red and yellow light.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 34(c) dictates that a light used to signal passing intentions must be either an all-round white or an all-round yellow light. This applies only to vessels operating on Inland Waters.

question_text: INLAND ONLY What characteristic must a light used to indicate passing intentions have?
option_a: It must be an alternating red and yellow light.
option_b: It must be an all-round white light.
option_c: It must be an all-round yellow light.
option_d: It must be either an all-round white or an all-round yellow light.
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation:
