question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway in fog, you hear a signal of one prolonged blast followed by three short blasts.  This is the fog signal for a vessel __________.
option_b: manned being towed
option_c: unmanned being towed
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The signal of one prolonged blast followed by three short blasts, at intervals of not more than 2 minutes, is sounded by the last vessel if manned in a tow (towing vessel sounds one prolonged plus two short blasts). This is per Rule 35(e) of the USCG's Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning a vessel of 75 meters in length, at anchor?
option_a: She must show an all-round white light forward.
option_b: She must show a second all-round white light aft.
option_c: She may use her working lights to illuminate her decks.
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 30 of the Navigation Rules states a vessel at anchor must exhibit an all-round white light forward and another all-round white light aft, lower than the forward light. Working lights may be used to illuminate decks (Rule 30(e)). All options are correct, making D the right answer.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are approaching another vessel. She is about one mile distant and is on your starboard bow.  You believe she will cross ahead of you.  She then sounds a whistle signal of five short blasts.  You should __________.
option_a: answer the signal and hold course and speed
option_b: reduce speed slightly to make sure she will have room to pass
option_c: make a large course change, and slow down if necessary
option_d: wait for another whistle signal from the other vessel
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Five short blasts is a danger signal (Rule 34(d)) indicating the other vessel believes your proposed action is insufficient to avoid collision. Since you are the stand-on vessel in a crossing situation (Rule 15), and the other vessel is indicating danger, you should take action as the situation requires. Option C, making a large course change and slowing down if necessary, is the prudent action under Rule 2, Responsibility, and Rule 8, Action to Avoid Collision.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND If a rowboat underway does NOT  show the lights specified for a sailing vessel underway, it shall show a __________.
option_a: white light from sunset to sunrise
option_b: combined lantern showing green to starboard and red to port and shown from sunset to sunrise
option_c: combined lantern showing green to starboard and red to port and shown in sufficient time to prevent collision
option_d: white light shown in sufficient time to prevent collision
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 25(d)(ii) of the Navigation Rules states a vessel under oars shall have ready at hand an electric torch or lighted lantern showing a white light which shall be exhibited in sufficient time to prevent collision. Option D accurately reflects this requirement.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel at anchor shall display, between sunrise and sunset, on the forward part of the vessel where it can best be seen __________.
option_b: two black balls
option_c: one red ball
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "one black ball" (Option A), is based on COLREGs Rule 30(a)(i). This rule states that a vessel at anchor shall exhibit where it can best be seen, in the fore part, "one ball" (interpreted as one black ball during daylight hours).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are making headway in fog and hear a fog signal of two prolonged blasts on your starboard quarter.  You should __________.
option_b: change course to the left
option_c: change course to the right
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Two prolonged blasts indicate a power-driven vessel underway, but stopped and not making way. Since the signal is on your starboard quarter, the risk of collision is low, and you should maintain course and speed. This is supported by Rule 19 (e) (i) of the Navigation Rules, which advises reducing speed to bare steerageway or stopping if the risk of collision exists forward of the beam.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are underway, in fog, when  you hear a whistle signal of one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts.  This signal could indicate a vessel __________.
option_b: being towed
option_c: aground
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation:
Rule 35(c) states a vessel "not under command" when making way, or a "vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver," a "sailing vessel," "fishing vessel," or "vessel engaged in towing" must sound one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts in restricted visibility.

Reference: Rule 35(c)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel must exhibit three white masthead lights in a vertical line?
option_b: A vessel whose tow exceeds 200 meters astern
option_c: A vessel not under command, at anchor
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, A vessel whose tow exceeds 200 meters astern, is stipulated in Rule 24 (Towing and pushing). A power-driven vessel when towing astern, and the length of the tow exceeds 200 meters, shall exhibit three masthead lights in a vertical line. See 33 CFR § 83.24 (a)(iii).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND All of the following are distress signals EXCEPT __________.
option_a: the continuous sounding of any fog signal apparatus
option_b: giving five or more short and rapid blasts of the whistle
option_c: firing a gun at intervals of about a minute
option_d: a barrel with burning oil in it, on deck
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer is 'B' because giving five or more short and rapid blasts is a danger/warning signal, not a distress signal. Options A, C, and D are all listed as recognized distress signals in Annex IV of the Navigation Rules (Rule 37).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND If you are approaching a bend,  and hear a whistle signal of one prolonged blast from around the bend, you should answer with a signal of __________.
option_b: a prolonged blast
option_c: one short, one prolonged, and one short blast
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(e) of the USCG Navigation Rules states that a vessel approaching a bend or obstruction that obscures other vessels must sound one prolonged blast. Any approaching vessel hearing this must answer with one prolonged blast. (34(e))

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A "flashing light", by the definition given in the rules, is a light that __________.
option_b: is visible over an arc of the horizon of 360°
option_c: flashes at regular intervals at a frequency of 120 flashes  or more per minute
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A "flashing light" is defined as a light flashing at regular intervals at a frequency of 120 flashes or more per minute. This definition is found in the International and Inland Navigation Rules, specifically Rule 21(f). This confirms that option C is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The term "restricted visibility" as used in the Rules refers __________.
option_b: only to visibility of less than one-half of a mile
option_c: to visibility where you cannot see shore
option_d: to any condition where visibility is restricted
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 3 (General Definitions) of the USCG Navigation Rules states that "restricted visibility" means any condition where visibility is restricted by causes like fog, mist, falling snow, or heavy rainstorms. Therefore, option D, "to any condition where visibility is restricted," is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel engaged in mineclearing shows special identity lights __________.
option_a: in addition to the lights required for a power-driven vessel
option_b: which mean that other vessels should not approach within 1000 meters of the mineclearing vessel
option_c: which are green and show all-round
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in mineclearing shows special identity lights that are: in addition to lights for a power-driven vessel, green and all-round, and indicate other vessels should not approach within 1000 meters. Thus, "All of the above" (D) is correct. See Rule 27(f).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND According to the Navigation Rules, you may depart from the Rules when __________.
option_a: no vessels are in sight visually
option_b: no vessels are visible on radar
option_c: you are in immediate danger
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: The correct answer, C, "you are in immediate danger," is based on Rule 2(b) of the Navigation Rules. This rule allows for a departure from the Rules when special circumstances, including immediate danger, make it necessary to avoid collision or other dangers of navigation.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND An authorized light to assist in the identification of submarines operating on the surface is a(n) __________.
option_b: intermittent flashing amber/yellow light
option_c: flashing white light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "intermittent flashing amber/yellow light," is authorized for submarines operating on the surface. This distinctive light is a high-intensity, all-round flashing yellow or amber light with a frequency of 90 flashes per minute. This is covered in Rule 1(c), which authorizes distinctive signals not prescribed in the Rules, such as this light for submarines, in accordance with 32 CFR 707.7.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning two sailing vessels?
option_a: A sailing vessel with the wind forward of the beam on her port side shall keep out of the way of a sailing vessel with the wind forward of the beam on the starboard side.
option_b: When both vessels have the wind on the same side, the vessel to leeward shall keep out of the way.
option_c: A sail vessel with the wind abaft of the beam must keep out of the way of a vessel sailing into the wind.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Option A is correct per Rule 12(a)(i) of the COLREGs (International and Inland Rules). When vessels have the wind on different sides, the vessel that has the wind on her port side shall keep out of the way. This is commonly known as the port tack gives way to starboard tack rule.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND When underway in a channel, you should keep to the __________.
option_b: starboard side of the channel
option_c: port side of the channel
option_d: side of the channel that has the widest turns
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "starboard side of the channel," aligns with Rule 9 (Narrow channels) of both International and Inland Navigational Rules. Rule 9(a) states a vessel shall keep as near to the outer limit of the channel or fairway which lies on her starboard side as is safe and practicable.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway, in fog, you hear a whistle signal of one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts.  This signal is sounded by a vessel __________.
option_b: being towed
option_c: on pilotage duty
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in pilotage duty (Option C) sounds one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts at intervals of not more than 2 minutes when making way in restricted visibility. The question's correct answer (A) is incorrect for this signal. Rule 35(g).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND When navigating in restricted visibility, a power-driven vessel shall __________.
option_a: stop her engines when hearing a fog signal forward of her beam, even if risk of collision does not exist
option_b: have her engines ready for immediate maneuver
option_c: when making way, sound one prolonged blast at intervals of  not more than one minute
option_d: operate at a speed to be able to stop in the distance of her visibility
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: A power-driven vessel navigating in restricted visibility shall have her engines ready for immediate maneuver. This requirement is found in Rule 19(b) of the COLREGs (Inland and International).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You can indicate that your vessel is in distress by __________.
option_b: displaying three black balls in a vertical line
option_c: sounding four or more short rapid blasts on the whistle
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 37 (Distress signals) and Annex IV 1(b) of the Navigation Rules state that a vessel in distress may use a continuous sounding with any fog signaling apparatus (such as a fog whistle) to indicate distress, which aligns with option D.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND During the day, a dredge will indicate the side on which it is safe to pass by displaying __________.
option_a: two balls in a vertical line
option_b: two diamonds in a vertical line
option_c: a single black ball
option_d: no shape is shown during the day
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "two diamonds in a vertical line," is right because Rule 27(d)(ii) of the Navigation Rules (COLREGS/Inland) states that a vessel engaged in dredging or underwater operations will display two all-round green lights or two diamonds in a vertical line to indicate the side on which another vessel may pass.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A 45-meter vessel is pulling a  210-meter tow.  She may exhibit __________.
option_a: a masthead light forward, and two masthead lights in a vertical line aft
option_b: three masthead lights forward and one aft
option_c: two masthead lights forward and no after masthead light
option_d: three masthead lights aft and none forward
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A tow exceeding 200 meters requires three masthead lights in a vertical line (Rule 24(a)(ii)). The 45-meter vessel is not obliged to exhibit the after masthead light, but may do so (Rule 23(a)(ii) via Rule 24(d)).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning the danger signal?
option_a: When any vessel fails to understand the intentions of an approaching vessel she must sound the danger signal.
option_b: Only the stand-on vessel can sound the danger signal.
option_c: Distress signals may be used in place of the danger signal.
option_d: The danger signal consists of 4 or more short blasts of the whistle.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Option A is correct according to Rule 34(d). It states that if a vessel is in doubt as to the intent of an approaching vessel, or if it is doubtful that sufficient action is being taken to avoid collision, the vessel must sound the danger signal (five or more short, rapid blasts). (Rule 34(d))

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A distress signal __________.
option_a: consists of 5 or more short blasts of the fog signal apparatus
option_b: may be used separately or with other distress signals
option_c: consists of the raising and lowering of a large white flag
option_d: is used to indicate doubt about another vessel's intentions
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "may be used separately or with other distress signals," aligns with Annex IV: Distress Signals. This Annex, referenced by Rule 37 (Distress signals), lists signals that, when used or exhibited "either together or separately," indicate distress.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which is the danger signal?
option_a: A continuous sounding of the fog signal
option_b: Firing a gun every minute
option_c: Five or more short rapid blasts on the whistle
option_d: One prolonged blast on the whistle
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Five or more short rapid blasts on the whistle is the prescribed signal to indicate doubt or danger, as per Rule 34(d) of the Navigation Rules (Whistle Signals in Doubt or Danger). This signal is used both internationally and inland when a vessel fails to understand or doubts the intentions of an approaching vessel.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel is "in sight" of another vessel when __________.
option_a: she can be observed by radar
option_b: she can be observed visually from the other vessel
option_c: she can be plotted on radar well enough to determine her heading
option_d: her fog signal can be heard
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 3(k) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook states that vessels are deemed to be "in sight" of one another only when one can be observed visually from the other. Therefore, option B is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning two sailing vessels approaching each other?
option_a: A sailing vessel overtaking another is the give-way vessel.
option_b: When each is on a different tack, the vessel on the starboard tack shall keep out of the way.
option_c: A sailing vessel seeing another to leeward on an undetermined tack shall hold her course.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Option A is correct based on Rule 13 (Overtaking). Any vessel overtaking another must keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken. This rule overrides other rules concerning right-of-way.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What type of vessel or operation is indicated by a vessel showing two cones with the apexes  together?
option_b: Vessel trawling
option_c: Mineclearing
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The two cones with apexes together (apex-to-apex) is the day shape for a vessel engaged in trawling, as defined in Rule 26(c) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook. This corresponds to option B, "Vessel trawling."

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A power-driven vessel has on her port side a sailing vessel which is on a collision course.  The power-driven vessel is to __________.
option_b: keep clear, passing at a safe distance
option_c: sound one blast and turn to starboard
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 18(a)(iv) states that a power-driven vessel underway shall keep out of the way of a sailing vessel. Therefore, the power-driven vessel is the give-way vessel and must take action to keep clear, passing at a safe distance (Option B). (USCG Navigation Rules, Rule 18)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND At specified intervals, a vessel towing in fog shall sound __________.
option_b: two prolonged blasts
option_c: one prolonged and two short blasts in succession
option_d: one prolonged and three short blasts in succession
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(c) states that a vessel engaged in towing in restricted visibility shall sound one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts at intervals of not more than 2 minutes. This is why option C, "one prolonged and two short blasts in succession," is the correct signal.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel towing in fog shall sound a fog signal of __________.
option_a: one prolonged blast every one minute
option_b: two prolonged blasts every two minutes
option_c: one prolonged and two short blasts every two minutes
option_d: one prolonged blast every two minutes
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A vessel towing is a power-driven vessel "underway" and must sound a signal of one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts at intervals of not more than 2 minutes. This is found in Rule 35(c) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Continuous sounding of a fog whistle by a vessel is a signal __________.
option_b: to request the draw span of a bridge to be opened
option_c: of distress
option_d: that the vessel is broken down and drifting
question_category: Annexes
answer_explanation: A continuous sounding with any fog-signaling apparatus is an international distress signal. The correct answer, "of distress" (Option C), aligns with Rule 37 (Distress signals) and Annex IV 1(b) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  A 50-meter vessel is towing  astern and the length of the tow is 100 meters.  In addition to sidelights, which lights may she show to fully comply with the Rules?
option_a: Two masthead lights forward, a stern light, and a towing light above the stern light
option_b: A masthead light forward, two masthead lights aft, a stern light, and a towing light above the stern light
option_c: No masthead light forward, two masthead lights aft, a stern light, and a towing light above the stern light
option_d: Three masthead lights forward, one masthead light aft, and  two towing lights in a vertical line at the stern
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 24(a) applies. A vessel 50m or more when towing astern exhibits the forward masthead light, two masthead lights in a vertical line (replacing the after masthead light), a stern light, and a towing light in a vertical line above the stern light.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel, which is unable to maneuver due to some exceptional circumstance, shall exhibit __________.
option_a: during the day, three balls in a vertical line
option_b: during the day, three shapes, the highest and lowest being  balls and the middle being a diamond
option_c: when making way at night, two all-round red lights, sidelights, and a stern light
option_d: when making way at night, masthead lights, sidelights, and a stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel "unable to maneuver due to some exceptional circumstance" is considered a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver (RAM), according to Rule 3. RAM vessels making way at night must exhibit two all-round red lights in a vertical line, sidelights, and a stern light (Rule 27(b)(iii)).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which signal, other than a distress signal, can be used by a vessel to attract attention?
option_b: Continuous sounding of a fog signal apparatus
option_c: Burning barrel
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 36, Signals to Attract Attention, states a vessel may direct the beam of its searchlight toward danger, as long as it doesn't confuse other vessels. Option A, "Searchlight beam," is the only one listed in the rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning the light used with whistle signals?
option_a: Use of such a light is required.
option_b: The light shall have the same characteristics as a masthead light.
option_c: It is only used to supplement short blasts of the whistle.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Option C is correct because the maneuvering light, a white all-round light, is used to supplement short blasts when indicating a maneuver. This is covered under Rule 34(b) of the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  What is the minimum sound signaling equipment required aboard a vessel 24 meters in length?
option_b: A whistle only
option_c: A bell and a whistle
option_d: Any means of making an efficient sound signal
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, C (A bell and a whistle), is mandated for vessels 20 meters or more in length but less than 100 meters, such as a 24-meter vessel. This is required by Rule 33(a)(i) of the Navigation Rules, which pertains to Equipment for Sound Signals.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The towing light is a(n) __________.
option_b: yellow light with the same characteristics as the stern light
option_c: all-round yellow light
option_d: yellow light with the same characteristics as the masthead  light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The towing light is a yellow light having the same characteristics as the sternlight. The sternlight is defined in Rule 21(c). This is specified in Rule 21(d) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook (International and Inland).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND An all-round flashing yellow light may be exhibited by a(n) __________.
option_b: air cushion vessel in the nondisplacement mode
option_c: vessel towing a submerged object
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 23(b) of the Navigation Rules states that an air-cushion vessel operating in the non-displacement mode shall exhibit an all-round flashing yellow light. Therefore, option B, "air cushion vessel in the nondisplacement mode," is the correct answer.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND When should the fog signal of a manned vessel under tow be sounded?
option_a: After the towing vessel's fog signal
option_b: Before the towing vessel's fog signal
option_c: Approximately one minute after the towing vessel's fog signal
option_d: If the towing vessel is sounding a fog signal, the  manned vessel being towed is not required to sound any fog  signal.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(f) of the COLREGs (International) and Rule 35(f) (Inland) states that a manned vessel being towed should, if practicable, sound her fog signal immediately after the signal of the towing vessel. This corresponds to option A: "After the towing vessel's fog signal."

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A lantern combining a vessel's  navigation lights may be shown on a __________.
option_b: 20-meter vessel engaged in fishing and making way
option_c: 25-meter power-driven vessel trolling
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 25(b) allows a sailing vessel of less than 20 meters in length to combine her sidelights and stern light in one lantern, carried at or near the top of the mast. The 15-meter sailing vessel fits this requirement.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel engaged in fishing during the day would show __________.
option_b: two cones with bases together
option_c: a cone, apex downward
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in fishing (other than trawling) must show a shape of two cones with their apexes together. This is mandated by Rule 26 (c) (Fishing Vessels) in the Navigation Rules, confirming option D is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A sailing vessel is NOT required to keep out of the way of a __________.
option_b: vessel not under command
option_c: vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: A sailing vessel is the stand-on vessel when encountering a power-driven vessel. COLREG Rule 18 (a) dictates that a power-driven vessel must keep clear of a sailing vessel. Therefore, the sailing vessel is not required to keep out of the way of a power-driven vessel.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel may sound the danger signal?
option_a: The stand-on vessel in a crossing situation
option_b: The give-way vessel in a crossing situation
option_c: A vessel at anchor
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Any vessel may sound the danger signal (five short, rapid blasts) if she is in doubt as to the other vessel's intentions or believes a collision will result from the other vessel's proposed action. This applies to vessels maneuvering (stand-on/give-way) and those at anchor if a danger arises. Rule 34(d).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway in fog, you hear a vessel sound one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts on the whistle.  What does this signal indicate?
option_b: A vessel engaged in pilotage duty
option_c: A vessel being towed
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in towing in restricted visibility shall sound one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts. This is specified in Rule 35(c) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND If you saw flames aboard a vessel but could see the vessel was not on fire, you would  know that the __________.
option_a: crew was trying to get warm
option_b: vessel required immediate assistance
option_c: vessel was attempting to attract the attention of a pilot boat
option_d: vessel was being illuminated for identification by aircraft
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: As an expert in the USCG's Navigation Rules, I can confirm that flames on a vessel, even if not on fire, are a recognized distress signal indicating the vessel requires immediate assistance. This is specified in Rule 37 (Distress signals) of the COLREGs (International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea) and Annex IV, a part of the Navigation Rules Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND By day, when it is impracticable for a small vessel engaged in diving operations to display  the shapes for a vessel engaged in underwater operations, she shall display __________.
option_a: three black balls in a vertical line
option_b: two red balls in a vertical line
option_c: a black cylinder
option_d: a rigid replica of the International Code flag "A"
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "a rigid replica of the International Code flag 'A'", is specified for a vessel engaged in diving operations when displaying the normal shapes is impracticable. This requirement is found in Rule 27(e) of the USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook (International & Inland).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel will NOT show  sidelights when __________.
option_b: making way, not under command
option_c: not under command, not making way
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Sidelights are for vessels underway. A vessel "not under command, not making way" is not considered underway for the purpose of exhibiting sidelights, as it is stationary. Rule 27 details the lights for a vessel not under command.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which display indicates a vessel conducting mineclearance operations?
option_a: Three balls in a vertical line
option_b: Two balls in a vertical line
option_c: One ball near the foremast and one ball at each yardarm
option_d: One diamond near the foremast and one ball at each yardarm
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: COLREG Rule 27(f) requires a vessel engaged in mine clearance to display three balls: one near the foremast head and one at each end of the fore yard. This is to indicate danger within 1000m. The reference can be found in Rule 27 of the USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel MUST show two masthead lights in a vertical line?
option_a: A power-driven vessel less than 50 meters in length with a  20-meter tow
option_b: A sailing vessel towing a small vessel astern
option_c: A vessel not under command
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A power-driven vessel when towing astern must exhibit two masthead lights in a vertical line. The tow length does not change this requirement for a vessel under 50 meters. This is covered in Rule 24 (a)(i) of the Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The duration of each blast of the whistle signals used in meeting and crossing situations is __________.
option_b: 2 or 4 seconds
option_c: 4 to 6 seconds
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "about 1 second," is defined as a short blast. Rule 34(a) states that a short blast shall mean a blast of about one second's duration. These signals are used in meeting and crossing situations under Rules 34(a)(i) and (ii).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What day-shape should a vessel being towed exhibit if the tow EXCEEDS 200 meters?
option_b: Two diamonds
option_c: One ball
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The vessel being towed must exhibit a diamond shape when the length of the tow exceeds 200 meters. This requirement is found in Rule 24(e)(iii) of the COLREGs (International) and Inland Navigation Rules (Inland).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE when you are towing more than one barge astern at night?
option_a: Only the last barge in the tow must be lighted.
option_b: Only the first and last barges in the tow must be lighted.
option_c: All barges in the tow must be lighted.
option_d: All barges, except unmanned barges, must be lighted.
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 24 covers Towing and Pushing. While the exact text about "more than one barge astern" is not explicitly in the search snippets, the general rule for lights on objects being towed, and the context of the question about multiple barges, implies that all objects in the tow must be lighted for safety and visibility at night. The correct statement is that all barges in the tow must be lighted. You can find more detail in Rule 24 of the Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel is being propelled both by sail and by engines.  Under the Rules, the vessel is __________.
option_b: not covered under any category
option_c: a sail vessel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The vessel is classified as a power-driven vessel because it is being propelled by machinery, regardless of whether sails are also being used. See Rule 3(a)(i) of the Navigation Rules, which defines a power-driven vessel.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The white masthead light required for a power-driven vessel under the Rules is visible over how many degrees of the horizon?
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, 225.0°, is specified in the Navigation Rules, Rule 21(a), which defines a "Masthead light" as showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 225 degrees, visible from right ahead to 22.5 degrees abaft the beam on either side of the vessel.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning lights and shapes for towing vessels?
option_a: If a tow exceeds 200 meters in length, the towing vessel will display a black ball during daylight.
option_b: When towing astern, a vessel will carry her identification  lights at the masthead in addition to her regular masthead  light.
option_c: When towing astern, the towing vessel may show either a stern light or a towing light, but not both.
option_d: If the towing vessel is over 50 meters in length, she must  carry forward and after masthead lights.
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct statement (D) is true because a power-driven vessel 50 meters or more in length is required to carry a second masthead light abaft of and higher than the forward one. This requirement applies to towing vessels as well. Refer to Rule 23(a)(ii) and Rule 24(d) in the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel may use any sound or light signals to attract the attention of another vessel as long as __________.
option_b: red and green lights are not used
option_c: the vessel signals such intentions over the radiotelephone
option_d: the signal cannot be mistaken for a signal authorized by the Rules
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 36 (Signals to attract attention) states that any signal used to attract the attention of another vessel must not be mistaken for any signal authorized by the Rules. This directly supports the answer in column G, which is option D.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What type of vessel or operation is indicated by a vessel displaying two cones with the apexes together?
option_b: Trawling
option_c: Minesweeping
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in trawling displays two cones with the apexes together. The vessel is dragging a dredge net or other fishing apparatus through the water. This is covered in Rule 26 (Fishing Vessels) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The rule regarding look-outs applies __________.
option_b: between dusk and dawn
option_c: in heavy traffic
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer is D because Rule 5 (Look-out) states that every vessel "shall at all times maintain a proper look-out." This mandate includes all conditions listed in A, B, and C (restricted visibility, darkness/dusk and dawn, and heavy traffic). See Rule 5 of the Navigation Rules & Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway and towing, your vessel enters fog.  Which fog signal should you sound?
option_b: Two prolonged blasts
option_c: One prolonged blast and two short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(c) states that a vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver, including a vessel engaged in towing, shall sound "One prolonged blast followed by two short blasts" at intervals of not more than two minutes.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel engaged in fishing must display a light in the direction of any gear that extends outward more than 150 meters.  The color of this light is __________.
option_b: green
option_c: red
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation:
Rule 26(c)(iii) states that a vessel fishing with gear extending more than 150 meters horizontally must display a white light in the direction of the gear.

Reference: Rule 26, Annex II (USCG Nav Rules).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is true concerning a towing light when a towing vessel is towing astern?
option_a: When a towing light is shown, no stern light is necessary.
option_b: When a stern light is shown, no towing light is necessary.
option_c: The towing light is shown below the stern light.
option_d: The towing light is shown above the stern light.
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "The towing light is shown above the stern light," is mandated by both International and Inland Rules. Rule 24(a)(iv) states that a power-driven vessel towing astern shall exhibit "a towing light in a vertical line above the sternlight." This is found in 33 CFR 83.24 (International) and 33 U.S.C. 2024 (Inland).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND At night, a vessel which is less than 7 meters in length and anchored in an area where other vessels do not normally navigate is __________.
option_a: not required to show any anchor lights
option_b: required to show a flare-up light
option_c: required to show one white light
option_d: required to show sidelights and a stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 30(f)(i) states that a vessel less than 7 meters in length, when anchored in an area where other vessels do not normally navigate, shall not be required to exhibit anchor lights. This aligns with option A: "not required to show any anchor lights."

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are in charge of a 120-meter power-driven vessel at anchor in fog, sounding the required anchor signals.  You hear the fog signal of a vessel underway off your port bow.  You may sound __________.
option_a: at least five short and rapid blasts
option_b: two short blasts
option_c: one short, one prolonged, and one short blast
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(d) permits a vessel at anchor to sound one short, one prolonged, and one short blast to indicate her position and the possibility of collision to an approaching vessel in restricted visibility.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND When taking action to avoid collision, you should __________.
option_a: make sure the action is taken in enough time
option_b: not make any large course changes
option_c: not make any large speed changes
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "make sure the action is taken in enough time," aligns with Rule 8(a) in both Inland and International Rules. This rule states that any action taken to avoid collision "shall if the circumstances of the case admit, be positive, made in ample time and with due regard to the observance of good seamanship."

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel would have no white lights visible when meeting her head-on?
option_b: A vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
option_c: A vessel mineclearing
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel not under command exhibits two all-round red lights in a vertical line, and no white lights when seen head-on (Rule 27(a)). A vessel trawling exhibits a masthead light and sidelights, while vessels restricted in ability to maneuver or mineclearing exhibit a red-white-red vertical light configuration.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are in restricted visibility and hear a fog signal forward of the beam.  Nothing appears on your radar screen.  You must __________.
option_b: sound two prolonged blasts of the whistle
option_c: sound the danger signal
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 19(e) of the COLREGS (USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook) requires that any vessel hearing a fog signal apparently forward of her beam, or which cannot avoid a close-quarters situation, shall reduce her speed to the minimum at which she can be kept on her course and, if necessary, take all her way off. This is equivalent to slowing to bare steerageway.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  A towing vessel 30 meters in length is pushing barges ahead.  How many white masthead lights is the vessel REQUIRED to show at night?
option_b: Two
option_c: Three
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is Two because a power-driven vessel pushing ahead, except a composite unit, must exhibit two masthead lights in a vertical line instead of the single masthead light required for a typical power-driven vessel. See Rule 24 (c)(i) of the Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway in fog you hear a vessel sound one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts.  What does this signal indicate?
option_b: A vessel being towed
option_c: A pilot vessel engaged on pilotage duty
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The signal of one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts in fog indicates a vessel engaged in towing. This is specified in the USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook, Rule 35(c), concerning sound signals in restricted visibility.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A power-driven vessel with a 150-meter stern tow shall display __________.
option_a: three masthead lights in a vertical line
option_b: a towing light above the stern light
option_c: two towing lights in a vertical line
option_d: a red light over a white light at the masthead
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, B, is required for a vessel towing where the length of the tow is less than 200 meters. It must display a towing light vertically above the sternlight. See Rule 24(a)(iv) in the USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel transferring cargo while underway is classified by the Rules as a vessel __________.
option_b: in special circumstances
option_c: restricted in her ability to maneuver
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: A vessel transferring cargo is considered "restricted in her ability to maneuver" because the nature of the operation limits her ability to keep out of the way of other vessels. This classification is specified in Rule 3(g) of the International and Inland Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel, when anchored at  night, is NOT required to show anchor lights?
option_b: A vessel engaged on pilotage duty
option_c: A vessel dredging
option_d: A vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel dredging is not required to show anchor lights (Rule 30) when anchored, but rather the lights or shapes prescribed in Rule 27(d) for vessels restricted in their ability to maneuver. This is why C, "A vessel dredging," is the correct answer.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel towing is showing three forward white masthead lights in a vertical line.  This means that the length of the __________.
option_a: towing vessel is less than 50 meters
option_b: towing vessel is greater than 50 meters
option_c: tow is less than 200 meters
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation:
Three forward white masthead lights in a vertical line indicate the length of the tow exceeds 200 meters. Rule 24 of the USCG Navigation Rules specifies the lighting for vessels engaged in towing and pushing.
(33 CFR § 83.24)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel is "underway" under the Rules of the Road?
option_a: A vessel at anchor with the engine running
option_b: A vessel with a line led to a tree onshore
option_c: A vessel drifting with the engine off
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: A vessel is "underway" if it is not at anchor, aground, or made fast to the shore. A drifting vessel meets this definition, regardless of whether the engine is on or off. Rule 3(a) of the Rules of the Road defines "underway."

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel may exhibit identifying lights when not actually engaged in her occupation?
option_b: A fishing vessel
option_c: A tug
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is D because vessels are only permitted to exhibit identifying lights when actively engaged in the operation their lights signify. For example, a fishing vessel not fishing must not display fishing lights. See USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook Rule 26(e).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A 25-meter vessel trawling will show the dayshape(s) consisting of __________.
option_b: two balls
option_c: two cones, apexes together
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 26(b)(iii) of the COLREGs (International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea) and Inland Rules states that a vessel engaged in trawling shall exhibit a dayshape consisting of two cones with their apexes together in a vertical line one above the other. This corresponds to option C.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A power-driven vessel underway  shall keep out of the way of a __________.
option_b: vessel engaged in fishing
option_c: sailing vessel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The answer D is correct because Rule 18 of the USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook states that a power-driven vessel underway must keep out of the way of a vessel not under command, a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver, a vessel engaged in fishing, and a sailing vessel. Since options A, B, and C are all included in this hierarchy, "All of the above" is the correct choice.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A fog signal of one short, one  prolonged, and one short blast may be sounded by a __________.
option_b: vessel not under command
option_c: vessel towing
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "vessel at anchor" (A), is correct because this specific fog signal—one short, one prolonged, and one short blast—is prescribed for a vessel at anchor that is warning an approaching vessel of her position and the possibility of collision. This is found in Rule 35(c) of the Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A continuous sounding of a fog-signal apparatus indicates __________.
option_b: the vessel has completed loading dangerous cargo
option_c: it is safe to pass
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Answer A is correct because both International and Inland Rule 37 (Distress signals) and Annex IV 1(b) state that a continuous sounding with any fog-signaling apparatus is a signal used by a vessel in distress and requiring assistance.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are underway in restricted visibility.  You hear the fog signal of another vessel about 22° on your starboard bow.  If danger of collision exists you must __________.
option_a: reduce your speed to bare steerageway
option_b: slow your engines and let the other vessel pass ahead of you
option_c: alter the course to starboard to pass around the other vessel's stern
option_d: alter course to port to pass the other vessel on its port side
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 19(e) states that if a vessel hears a fog signal forward of the beam and believes a collision may exist, she shall reduce her speed to bare steerageway. This action minimizes the risk of collision in poor visibility.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway in fog you hear a whistle signal consisting of one prolonged blast followed immediately by two short blasts.  This signal is sounded in fog by __________.
option_a: vessels at anchor, not engaged in fishing
option_b: vessels underway and towing
option_c: vessels in danger
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The signal of one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts, sounded at intervals of not more than two minutes, indicates a power-driven vessel underway and towing. This is covered under Rule 35(c) of the COLREGS (International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE of a 30-meter sailing vessel underway?
option_a: She must show sidelights and a stern light in restricted visibility.
option_b: She may show an all-round white light at the top of the mast.
option_c: She need not show a stern light if she is showing all-round  lights on the mast.
option_d: If she is using propelling machinery, she shall show forward a shape consisting of two cones, apexes together.
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 25(a) requires a sailing vessel underway to exhibit sidelights and a stern light. These lights must be shown at night and in restricted visibility (Rule 20). A 30-meter sailing vessel is required to comply with these rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A power-driven vessel towing another vessel astern (tow less than 200 meters) shall show __________.
option_a: three masthead lights in a vertical line instead of either the forward or after masthead light
option_b: two masthead lights in a vertical line instead of either the forward or after masthead lights
option_c: two towing lights in a vertical line at the stern
option_d: a small white light aft of the funnel
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 24(a)(i) of the COLREGs (International and Inland Rules) states that a power-driven vessel towing astern shall exhibit two masthead lights in a vertical line instead of the single masthead light prescribed in Rule 23(a)(i) or 23(a)(ii) when the tow is less than 200 meters.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel which is "restricted in her ability to maneuver" under the Rules, is a vessel which is __________.
option_b: engaged in fishing
option_c: at anchor
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: "Mine clearance operations" is specifically listed in Rule 3(g) of the COLREGs (International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea) as an example of a vessel "restricted in her ability to maneuver." The other options are either defined differently (vessel engaged in fishing) or are separate definitions (vessel not under command, vessel at anchor).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND When a vessel signals her distress by means of a gun or other explosive signal, the firing should be at intervals of approximately __________.
option_b: 1 minute
option_c: 1 hour
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, 1 minute (B), aligns with Annex IV, Rule 37 of the COLREGs (found in the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook). It states that a gun or other explosive signal indicating distress shall be fired at intervals of about a minute.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A "head on" situation shall be deemed to exist at night when a power-driven vessel sees another power-driven vessel ahead and __________.
option_a: one sidelight and the masthead light are visible
option_b: the vessels will pass closer than half a mile
option_c: both vessels sound one prolonged blast
option_d: both sidelights and masthead light(s) are visible
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Option D is correct because a head-on situation is deemed to exist when a power-driven vessel sees the masthead light(s) and both sidelights of another power-driven vessel ahead. This is stipulated in Rule 14 (Risk of Collision) of the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A 20-meter vessel is towing another vessel astern.  The length of the tow from the stern of the towing vessel to the stern of the tow is 75 meters.  How many white towing masthead lights shall the towing vessel show at night?
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A towing vessel, with a tow under 200 meters (75 meters in this case), must exhibit two masthead lights in a vertical line. This is prescribed in the International & Inland Navigation Rules, Rule 24(a)(i) (Towing and Pushing).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel engaged in fishing, and at anchor, shall show __________.
option_b: sidelights and a stern light
option_c: three lights in a vertical line, the highest and lowest being red, and the middle being white
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 26(a) states a vessel engaged in fishing, whether underway or at anchor, shall exhibit only the lights prescribed in this Rule. A fishing vessel does not show an anchor light (Rule 30) or the lights in options B/C while actively fishing. Therefore, "None of the above" is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A power-driven vessel underway  shall keep out of the way of a vessel __________.
option_b: restricted in her ability to maneuver
option_c: engaged in fishing
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 18 states that a power-driven vessel underway shall keep out of the way of a vessel not under command (NUC), a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver (RAM), and a vessel engaged in fishing. Since options A, B, and C are all included in Rule 18's hierarchy of precedence, 'All of the above' (D) is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel sounding a fog signal  of one short, one prolonged, and one short blast is indicating that the vessel is __________.
option_b: in distress
option_c: at anchor
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A vessel at anchor may sound the supplemental signal of one short, one prolonged, and one short blast to alert other vessels of their position. This is found in Rule 35 (g) of the Navigation Rules, Inland and International.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Two all-round red lights displayed in a vertical line are shown by a vessel __________.
option_b: pushing a barge ahead
option_c: at anchor
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Option D, "not under command," is correct. A vessel not under command shall exhibit two all-round red lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen. This is found in Rule 27 of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook (33 CFR § 83.27).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Your vessel is underway in reduced visibility.  You hear the fog signal of another vessel about 30° on your starboard bow.  If danger of collision exists, you must __________.
option_a: alter course to starboard to pass around the other vessel's stern
option_b: slow your engines and let the other vessel pass ahead of you
option_c: reduce your speed to bare steerageway
option_d: alter course to port and pass the other vessel on its port side
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 19(e) states that a vessel hearing a fog signal of another vessel forward of the beam, which cannot be avoided, shall reduce her speed to the minimum at which she can be kept on her course (bare steerageway). Proceed with extreme caution until the danger of collision is over. Rule 19(e) of COLREGS/Inland Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are underway in fog and you hear one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts.  This is a vessel __________.
option_b: engaged on pilotage duty
option_c: aground in a fairway
option_d: stopped and making no way through the water
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The signal of one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts, sounded at intervals of not more than 2 minutes in restricted visibility, indicates a vessel engaged in towing. See Rule 35(c) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A sailing vessel is NOT allowed to show the all-round red over green lights on the mast if  __________.
option_b: her sidelights are combined and shown on the fore and aft centerline of the vessel
option_c: she is showing a stern light
option_d: her sidelights and stern light are combined in one lantern and shown on the mast
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 25(b) permits a sailing vessel under 20m to combine sidelights and a stern light in one lantern on the mast. A vessel exhibiting the combined lantern in Rule 25(b) cannot also exhibit the all-round red over green lights. This is based on COLREG Rule 25.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A power-driven vessel, when towing astern, shall show __________.
option_a: two towing lights in a vertical line
option_b: a towing light in a vertical line above the stern light
option_c: two towing lights in addition to the stern light
option_d: a small white light in lieu of the stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 24(a) requires a towing vessel to show two masthead lights in a vertical line, sidelights, a sternlight, and a towing light (yellow) in a vertical line above the sternlight. Option B specifically describes the positioning of the towing light relative to the stern light. See Rule 24 of the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND According to the Rules, which vessel is NOT "restricted in her ability to maneuver"?
option_a: A vessel servicing a navigation marker
option_b: A sailing vessel
option_c: A vessel mineclearing
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 3(g) defines vessels restricted in their ability to maneuver as those unable to deviate from their course due to the nature of their work (servicing markers, mineclearing, dredging). A sailing vessel is defined separately and is not considered restricted. See Rule 3, General Definitions.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Distress signals may be __________.
option_b: smoke signals
option_c: sound signals
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 37 and Annex IV of the Navigation Rules list various distress signals, including red flares, smoke signals, and continuous sound signals, all of which are applicable to both International and Inland waters. Therefore, "Any of the above" is correct. (See 33 CFR § 83.37)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND When anchoring a 25-meter vessel at night, you must show __________.
option_b: two all-round white lights
option_c: one all-round white light and the sidelights
option_d: the sidelights and a stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 30(b) states that a vessel less than 50 meters in length (like a 25-meter vessel) at anchor may exhibit one all-round white light where it can best be seen. This matches option A, making it the correct answer for both International and Inland waters.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are approaching another vessel at night.  You can see both red and green sidelights and, above the level of the sidelights, three white lights  in a vertical line.  The vessel may be __________.
option_b: towing a tow more than 200 meters astern
option_c: trawling
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The vessel is exhibiting three white masthead lights in a vertical line, along with sidelights, indicating a tow exceeding 200 meters in length. The three lights signify the length of the tow. This is mandated by Rule 24 of the International and Inland Navigation Rules (33 CFR § 83.24).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel engaged in fishing, and at anchor, should exhibit __________.
option_b: sidelights and stern light
option_c: three lights in a vertical line, the highest and lowest being red, and the middle being white
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in fishing, even when at anchor, must exhibit only the lights and shapes prescribed for fishing vessels. Since the lights for a vessel engaged in fishing (green over white all-round lights) are not listed, "None of the above" is correct. Refer to Rule 26(a).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In a crossing situation on open waters, a sailing vessel shall keep out of the way of all the following vessels EXCEPT a __________.
option_b: vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
option_c: power-driven vessel approaching on her starboard side
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, C, is a power-driven vessel that is obligated to keep clear of a sailing vessel in a crossing situation, according to Rule 18(a)(iv). A sailing vessel must keep out of the way of vessels listed in Rule 18(a)(i), (ii), and (iii): not under command, restricted in ability to maneuver, and fishing.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are at anchor in fog on a 120-meter power-driven vessel.  You hear the fog signal of a vessel approaching off your port bow.  You may sound __________.
option_a: one prolonged, one short and one prolonged
option_b: two short blasts
option_c: one short, one prolonged, and one short blast
question_category: Part D: Sound and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(g) and Rule 35(h) of the Navigation Rules address sound signals for vessels at anchor in restricted visibility. A vessel at anchor may, in addition to the bell signal, sound the warning signal: one short, one prolonged, and one short blast, to warn an approaching vessel of her position.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A power-driven vessel making way through the water sounds a fog signal of __________.
option_a: one prolonged blast at intervals of not more than two minutes
option_b: two prolonged blasts at intervals of not more than two minutes
option_c: one prolonged blast at intervals of not more than one minute
option_d: two prolonged blasts at intervals of not more than one minute
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Answer A is correct because International and Inland Rule 35(a) requires a power-driven vessel making way through the water to sound one prolonged blast at intervals of not more than two minutes when in restricted visibility.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are on watch in the fog. Your vessel is proceeding at a safe speed when you hear a fog signal ahead of you.  The Rules require you to navigate with caution and, if danger of collision exists, __________.
option_b: stop your engines
option_c: reduce to bare steerageway
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct action is to reduce speed to bare steerageway when danger of collision exists after hearing a fog signal forward of the beam. This is required under the Conduct of Vessels in Restricted Visibility, Rule 19(e).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In restricted visibility, a vessel fishing with nets shall sound at intervals of two minutes __________.
option_b: one prolonged followed by two short blasts
option_c: one prolonged followed by three short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer is B, "one prolonged followed by two short blasts," because Rule 35(c) of the Navigation Rules states that a vessel engaged in fishing in restricted visibility shall sound this signal at intervals of not more than two minutes.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A 20-meter sailing vessel underway must exhibit a __________.
option_b: combined lantern
option_c: red light over a green light at the masthead
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A sailing vessel underway, regardless of length, must exhibit sidelights and a stern light. Option A, "stern light," is a required component. A combined lantern is optional for vessels less than 20 meters. See Rule 25(a) in the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND At night, you are towing a partly submerged vessel, 20 meters in length and 4 meters in breadth.  What lights must you display on the towed vessel?
option_a: A white light at the stern
option_b: Two white lights side by side at the stern
option_c: A white light at the forward end and a white light at the after end
option_d: Two red lights in a vertical line at the after end
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 24(h)(i) and (ii) of the Inland and International Rules states that an inconspicuous, partly submerged vessel being towed must display a white all-round light at the forward end and a white all-round light at the after end, not more than 5m from each end. See Rule 24.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND All of the following vessels are "restricted in their ability to maneuver" EXCEPT a vessel __________.
option_b: dredging
option_c: mineclearing
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: A vessel "not under command" (option D) is defined separately under Rule 3(f) and is not included in the list of vessels "restricted in her ability to maneuver" defined in Rule 3(g). Rule 3(g) lists vessels engaged in operations like laying a pipeline, dredging, or mineclearing.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What lights must be shown on a  barge being towed astern at night?
option_a: A white light at each corner
option_b: A white light fore and aft
option_c: Sidelights and a stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: As a mariner, I confirm that a vessel being towed astern, like a barge, must exhibit sidelights and a stern light. This is required by Rule 24(e) of the Navigation Rules (COLREGs/Inland Rules). The correct answer is C.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel which is unable to maneuver due to some exceptional circumstance, shall show two red lights in a vertical line and __________.
option_a: during the day, three balls in a vertical line
option_b: during the day, three shapes, the highest and lowest being  balls and the middle being a diamond
option_c: when making way at night, sidelights and a stern light
option_d: when making way at night, masthead lights, sidelights, and a stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel Not Under Command (NUC) must exhibit two all-round red lights in a vertical line. When making way through the water, it also exhibits sidelights and a stern light. Therefore, option C is correct. See Rule 27(a)(iii) in the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are underway and approaching a bend in the channel where vessels approaching from the opposite direction cannot be seen.  You should sound __________.
option_a: one blast, 4 to 6 seconds in duration
option_b: three blasts, 4 to 6 seconds in duration
option_c: one continuous blast until you are able to see around the bend
option_d: one blast, 8 to 10 seconds in duration
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(e) of the USCG Navigation Rules (International & Inland) states that a power-driven vessel nearing a bend or an area where other vessels may be obscured must sound one prolonged blast (4-6 seconds) as a warning signal. This corresponds to Option A.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel which is fishing must  show sidelights and a stern light only when __________.
option_b: underway
option_c: dead in the water
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in fishing must show the navigational lights, including sidelights and a stern light, only when it is making way through the water. This is covered under Rule 26 and the general requirements for navigational lights in Rule 23.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A power-driven vessel towing astern shall show __________.
option_a: two towing lights in a vertical line
option_b: a towing light in a vertical line above the stern light
option_c: two towing lights in addition to the stern light
option_d: a small white light in lieu of the stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 24(a)(iv) states that a power-driven vessel when towing astern shall exhibit a towing light in a vertical line above the sternlight. The towing light is a yellow light with the same characteristics as the sternlight.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are underway in fog when you hear the following signal:  one short blast, one prolonged  blast and one short blast in succession.  Which of the following would it be?
option_a: A sailing vessel underway with the wind abaft the beam
option_b: A power-driven vessel underway and making way through the water
option_c: A vessel at anchor
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: This signal is prescribed for a vessel at anchor warning an approaching vessel of her position and the possibility of collision. See USCG Navigation Rules, Rule 35(g).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND If you hear the firing of a gun at one minute intervals from another vessel, this indicates that __________.
option_a: the gun is being used to sound passing signals
option_b: the vessel is in distress
option_c: all vessels are to clear the area
option_d: all is clear and it is safe to pass
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: This is correct because a gun or other explosive signal fired at intervals of about a minute is a signal indicating distress and need of assistance. See Rule 37 (Distress Signals) and Annex IV, paragraph 1(a) of the Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Fog signals, required under the Rules for vessels underway, shall be sounded __________.
option_a: only on the approach of another vessel
option_b: only when vessels are in sight of each other
option_c: at intervals of not more than one minute
option_d: at intervals of not more than two minutes
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The fog signal rules (Rule 35) require sound signals for vessels underway to be sounded at intervals of not more than 2 minutes. For a power-driven vessel making way through the water, Rule 35(a) requires one prolonged blast at intervals of not more than 2 minutes.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A towing vessel is towing two barges astern.  The length of the tow from the stern of the tug to the stern of the last barge is 250 meters.  The towing vessel is 45 meters in length.  How many white masthead lights should be displayed on the tugboat at night?
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The length of the tow (250m) exceeds 200 meters. Per Rule 24(a) of the USCG Navigation Rules, a power-driven vessel towing when the length of the tow is greater than 200 meters must exhibit three white masthead lights in a vertical line.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND At night, a vessel shall indicate that she is restricted in her ability to maneuver  by showing in a vertical line two __________.
option_b: red lights and two white lights
option_c: red lights with a white light in between
option_d: white lights with a red light in between
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "red lights with a white light in between," aligns with Rule 27(b)(i) of the Navigation Rules (COLREGs). This rule specifies that a vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver shall exhibit three all-round lights in a vertical line: the highest and lowest of which are red, and the middle one is white.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Your power-driven vessel is underway when you sight a sailing vessel on your port bow.  Which vessel is the "stand-on" vessel?
option_a: The sailboat, because it is to port of your vessel
option_b: The sailboat, because it is under sail
option_c: Your vessel, because it is a power-driven vessel
option_d: Your vessel, because it is to starboard of the sailboat
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 18 (a)(ii) of the Navigation Rules states that a power-driven vessel must keep out of the way of a sailing vessel. Therefore, the sailing vessel is the stand-on vessel because it is under sail. (USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook Rule 18)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Five or more short blasts on a  vessel's whistle indicates that she is __________.
option_a: in doubt that another vessel is taking sufficient action to avoid a collision
option_b: altering course to starboard
option_c: altering course to port
option_d: the stand-on vessel and will maintain course and speed
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(d) indicates that five or more short and rapid blasts are used to signal doubt or disagreement with another vessel's actions or intentions to avoid collision. Therefore, the vessel is in doubt that another vessel is taking sufficient action. This is covered under Rule 34(d) of the Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement concerning maneuvering in restricted visibility is FALSE?
option_a: A vessel which cannot avoid a close-quarters situation with a vessel forward of her beam shall reduce her speed to bare steerageway.
option_b: A vessel which hears a fog signal forward of her beam shall stop her engines.
option_c: A vessel which hears a fog signal forward of the beam shall navigate with caution.
option_d: If a vessel determines by radar that a close-quarters situation is developing, she shall take avoiding action in  ample time.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 19(e) states a vessel that hears a fog signal forward of the beam shall reduce speed to bare steerageway, or if necessary, take all her way off. It does not mandate stopping the engines, making statement B FALSE. See Rule 19, Conduct of Vessels in Restricted Visibility.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel being towed astern shall show at night __________.
option_a: the lights required for a power-driven vessel underway
option_b: only the required masthead lights
option_c: a stern light only
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, D (sidelights and a stern light), is mandated by Rule 24(e) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook. This rule specifies that a vessel being towed astern must exhibit sidelights and a sternlight at night.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In order for a stand-on vessel  to take action in a situation, she must determine that the  other vessel __________.
option_a: is restricted in her ability to maneuver
option_b: has sounded the danger signal
option_c: is not taking appropriate action
option_d: has not changed course since risk of collision was  determined
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: COLREGs Rule 17(a)(ii) states the stand-on vessel may take action when it becomes apparent that the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action. The stand-on vessel must determine that the other vessel is not taking appropriate action before intervening.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway your vessel approaches a bend in a river where, due to the bank, you cannot see around the bend.  You should __________.
option_a: keep to the starboard side of the channel and sound one short blast
option_b: sound the danger signal
option_c: sound one prolonged blast
option_d: slow your vessel to bare steerageway
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(e) of the Navigation Rules states a vessel nearing a bend or an area where other vessels may be obscured must sound one prolonged blast. This warns any vessel beyond the bend of your approach.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement concerning whistle signals is FALSE?
option_a: When a pushing vessel and a vessel pushed are connected in a composite unit, the unit sounds the fog signal of a power-driven vessel.
option_b: A vessel at anchor may sound one short, one prolonged, and  one short blast.
option_c: A pilot vessel may sound an identity signal on the whistle.
option_d: A vessel engaged in towing in fog shall sound a fog signal  at intervals of one minute.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation:
Statement D is FALSE because a vessel engaged in towing in restricted visibility shall sound one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts at intervals of not more than 2 minutes, not 1 minute.

Reference: USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook, Rule 35 (c).
