question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A sailing vessel of over 20 meters in length underway must show a __________.
option_a: red light over a green light at the masthead
option_b: white masthead light
option_c: combined lantern
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 25(a) of the Navigation Rules states that a sailing vessel underway shall exhibit sidelights and a sternlight. Since the vessel is over 20 meters, it must exhibit a stern light. The option D is "stern light", making it the correct choice.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND An inconspicuous, partly submerged vessel or object being towed, where the length of tow is 100 meters, shall show __________.
option_b: two red lights in a vertical line
option_c: a black ball
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, a diamond shape, is the required day signal for an inconspicuous, partly submerged vessel or object being towed when the length of tow is less than 200 meters. This is mandated by Rule 24(e) of the USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are approaching a narrow channel.  You see a vessel that can only be navigated safely within the channel.  You should __________.
option_a: initiate an exchange of passing signals
option_b: not cross the channel if you might impede the other vessel
option_c: sound the danger signal
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, B, is based on Rule 9(d) of the Navigation Rules (Narrow Channels). A vessel shall not cross a narrow channel or fairway if such crossing impedes the passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within that channel or fairway. See 33 CFR § 83.09.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A man aboard a vessel, signaling by raising and lowering his outstretched arms to each side, is indicating __________.
option_b: all is clear, it is safe to pass
option_c: the vessel is anchored
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Raising and lowering outstretched arms to each side is a distress signal as specified in Annex IV, paragraph 1(k) of the USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook (COLREGs), under Rule 37.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Your 15-meter vessel is crossing a narrow channel and a large cargo vessel to port is within the channel and crossing your course.  You must __________.
option_b: sound the danger signal
option_c: initiate an exchange of passing signals
option_d: do not cross the channel if you might impede the other vessel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: A vessel less than 20 meters (your 15m vessel) shall not impede the passage of a vessel that can safely navigate only within a narrow channel (the large cargo vessel). Rule 9(b) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook requires you to avoid impeding safe passage, making option D correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel towed astern shall show __________.
option_b: sidelights
option_c: a special flashing light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel being towed astern must exhibit sidelights and a sternlight. The sidelights are required for a vessel being towed as per Rule 24(e) of the COLREGs/Inland Rules (33 CFR 83.24(e)).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A power-driven vessel making way through the water sounds which fog signal?
option_a: Two short blasts every one minute
option_b: One short blast every one minute
option_c: Two prolonged blasts every two minutes
option_d: One prolonged blast every two minutes
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A power-driven vessel making way through the water must sound one prolonged blast at intervals of not more than two minutes. This is prescribed by Rule 35(a) of the USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook (Inland and International).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are towing two barges astern.  The length of the tow from the stern of the tug to the stern of the last barge is 150 meters.  How many white  towing identification lights should be displayed on the tugboat at night?
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The length of the tow is 150 meters, which is less than 200 meters. Rule 24(a)(i) of the COLREGS (International & Inland) states that a power-driven vessel when towing astern shall exhibit two masthead lights in a vertical line when the length of the tow is less than 200 meters.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel may show three lights in a vertical line, the top and bottom being red and the middle being white?
option_a: A vessel engaged in diving operations
option_b: A pilot vessel
option_c: A vessel trawling
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in diving operations is restricted in its ability to maneuver and exhibits three all-round lights: red, white, red, in a vertical line. This is specified in Rule 27 (Vessels not under command or restricted in their ability to maneuver) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A power-driven vessel has on her port side a sailing vessel which is on a collision course.  The power-driven vessel is required to __________.
option_b: keep clear
option_c: sound one blast and turn to starboard
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The power-driven vessel is the give-way vessel and must keep out of the way of the sailing vessel, which is the stand-on vessel. This is mandated by COLREGs/Inland Rule 18(a)(iv), which establishes the responsibilities between vessels, prioritizing sailing vessels over power-driven vessels.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A single towing light will be carried  above a vessel's stern light __________.
option_a: only if she is towing astern
option_b: only if the tow exceeds 200 meters
option_c: at any time when towing
option_d: if the towing vessel is part of a composite unit
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 24(a) states a power-driven vessel towing astern exhibits a towing light above the sternlight. The towing light is carried only when towing astern, making option A correct. See Rule 24 (a).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which day-shape must be shown by a vessel 25 meters in length aground during daylight hours?
option_b: Two black balls
option_c: Three black balls
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is "Three black balls" because a vessel aground must exhibit three balls in a vertical line where they can best be seen. This requirement is found in Rule 30(d)(ii) of the Navigation Rules, which applies to both International and Inland waters for vessels of this size.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  An orange flag showing a black circle and square is a __________.
option_b: distress signal
option_c: signal of asking to communicate with another vessel
question_category: Annexes
answer_explanation: The orange flag with a black circle and square is a distress signal. This is specified in Rule 37 (Distress signals) and Annex IV of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook, which lists the signals indicating distress and need of assistance.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND When is a stand-on vessel FIRST allowed by the Rules to take action in order to avoid collision?
option_a: When the two vessels are less than half a mile from each other.
option_b: When the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action to avoid collision.
option_c: When collision is imminent.
option_d: The stand-on vessel is never allowed to take action.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The stand-on vessel is required to maintain its course and speed until it becomes apparent that the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action to avoid collision. This is covered in Rule 17 of the International and Inland Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are crossing a narrow channel in a 15-meter vessel when you sight a tankship off  your port bow coming up the channel.  Which statement is TRUE?
option_a: Yours is the give-way vessel because it is less than 30 meters long.
option_b: You shall not impede the safe passage of the tankship.
option_c: The tankship is the stand-on vessel because it is to port of  your vessel.
option_d: The tankship is the stand-on vessel because it is the larger  of the two vessels.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, B, is based on Rule 9(d), Narrow Channels. A vessel crossing a narrow channel shall not impede the passage of a vessel that can safely navigate only within that channel or fairway, such as a large tankship proceeding along the channel. (33 CFR 83.09(d))

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In restricted visibility, a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver, at anchor, would sound a fog signal of __________.
option_a: the rapid ringing of a bell for five seconds every minute
option_b: two prolonged and two short blasts every two minutes
option_c: one prolonged and two short blasts every two minutes
option_d: two prolonged and one short blast every two minutes
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Per Rule 35(d), a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver when carrying out her work at anchor shall sound one prolonged followed by two short blasts every two minutes. This signal replaces the standard anchoring signal when performing work.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A 15-meter sailing vessel would be required to show __________.
option_a: sidelights, stern light, and a red light over a green light  on the mast
option_b: sidelights, and stern light, but they may be in a combined lantern on the mast
option_c: separate sidelights and stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A 15-meter (less than 20m) sailing vessel must exhibit sidelights and a sternlight (Rule 25(a)). Rule 25(b) allows these lights to be combined in one lantern at or near the top of the mast for vessels under 20 meters.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The use of the signal consisting of five or more short blasts on the ship's whistle __________.
option_b: makes the other vessel the give-way vessel
option_c: indicates doubt as to the other vessel's action
option_d: makes it necessary to slow or stop
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Five or more short blasts are the danger or doubt signal, used when an operator is in doubt as to the intention of the other vessel or if sufficient action is being taken to avoid a collision. This is found in Rule 34(d) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway in fog, you hear the fog signal of another vessel ahead.  If a risk of collision exists, you must __________.
option_a: slow to bare steerageway and navigate with caution
option_b: sound three short blasts and back your engines
option_c: stop your engines and navigate with caution
option_d: continue on your course and speed until the other vessel is sighted
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 19 (d) and (e) of the COLREGs (which the USCG Rules are based on) states that a vessel hearing a fog signal forward of the beam should reduce speed to bare steerageway or take all way off and navigate with extreme caution until the danger is over. Ref: Rule 19.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What lights, if any, would you  exhibit at night if your vessel were broken down and being  towed by another vessel?
option_b: Same lights as for a power-driven vessel underway
option_c: A white light forward and a white light aft
option_d: The colored sidelights and a white stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel being towed must exhibit sidelights (colored) and a sternlight (white). This is because the vessel being towed is considered a vessel "other than those referred to in paragraph (g) of this Rule being towed" and must comply with Rule 24(e) of the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND If your vessel is underway in fog and you hear one prolonged and three short blasts, this indicates a __________.
option_b: sailing vessel
option_c: vessel in distress
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(h) of the USCG Navigation Rules states that a power-driven vessel being towed, or the last vessel of a tow if manned, must sound one prolonged blast followed by three short blasts in restricted visibility. This signal identifies the vessel being towed.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND At night, which lights would you see on a vessel engaged in fishing, other than trawling?
option_a: Two red lights, one over the other
option_b: A green light over a red light
option_c: A red light over a white light
option_d: A white light over a red light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 26(c)(i) states a vessel engaged in fishing, other than trawling, shall exhibit two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being red and the lower being white. Option C, "A red light over a white light," is the correct description.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are on a vessel nearing a bend in the channel where, because of the height of the bank, you cannot see a vessel approaching from the opposite direction. You should sound __________.
option_b: one prolonged blast
option_c: one long blast
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(e) states that a vessel nearing a bend or obstruction to view must sound one prolonged blast. This is the signal required to warn approaching vessels that may be obscured by the bend or bank.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Systems of inbound and outbound lanes to promote the safe flow of vessel traffic in certain areas around the world are known as __________.
option_b: traffic separation schemes
option_c: collision avoidance fairways
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, B, is "traffic separation schemes." A Traffic Separation Scheme (TSS) establishes inbound and outbound lanes to promote the safe flow of vessel traffic, especially in areas of high density, as described in the question. This is addressed in Rule 10 (Traffic Separation Schemes) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A tug is towing three manned barges in line in fog.  The first vessel of the tow should  sound __________.
option_b: one short blast
option_c: one prolonged and three short blasts
option_d: one prolonged, one short, and one prolonged blast
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The first vessel of a tow is not required to sound a fog signal. The rules only require the last vessel of a tow, if manned, to sound a signal: one prolonged and three short blasts. Therefore, "no fog signal" is correct for the first vessel. This is covered in Rule 35(e) of the COLREGs/Inland Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND All fog signals shall be sounded every two minutes with the exception of a vessel __________.
option_b: under sail or under tow
option_c: anchored or aground
option_d: not under command or restricted  in her ability to maneuver
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Vessels "anchored or aground" sound bell and/or gong signals at intervals of not more than one minute, not two minutes like underway vessels. This is covered in Rule 35 (g) and (h) of the COLREGs (International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea), as adopted in the USCG Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In reduced visibility, you hear two prolonged blasts of a whistle.  This signal is sounded  by a __________.
option_a: power-driven vessel dead in the water
option_b: sailing vessel on the port tack
option_c: vessel not under command
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A power-driven vessel underway but stopped, making no way through the water, sounds two prolonged blasts in succession in reduced visibility. Therefore, "power-driven vessel dead in the water" (Option A) is correct. This is found under Rule 35(b) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A 200-meter vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver, at anchor, will sound a fog signal of __________.
option_a: a 5 second ringing of a bell forward and a 5 second sounding of a gong aft at intervals of 1 minute
option_b: one prolonged followed by two short blasts every 2 minutes
option_c: one prolonged followed by three short blasts every minute
option_d: one prolonged followed by three short blasts every 2 minutes
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct fog signal is one prolonged followed by two short blasts every 2 minutes (Option B) because Rule 35(f) states a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver, when at anchor, shall sound this signal at intervals of not more than 2 minutes.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What day-shape is to be shown by a vessel aground?
option_b: Two cones with their apexes together
option_c: Two black balls in a vertical line
option_d: Three black balls in a vertical line
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel aground must exhibit three black balls in a vertical line. This is the correct day-shape as prescribed in Rule 30 (d) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What is NOT a distress signal?
option_b: Continuous sounding of fog signaling apparatus
option_c: International Code Flags "November" over "Charlie"
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, D, "Basket hanging in the rigging," is not listed as a distress signal in Rule 37 and Annex IV of the Navigation Rules, which describes the signals for a vessel requiring assistance.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning a vessel equipped with operational radar?
option_a: She must use this equipment to obtain early warning of risk of collision.
option_b: The use of a radar excuses a vessel from the need of a look-out.
option_c: The radar equipment is only required to be used in  restricted visibility.
option_d: The safe speed of such a vessel will likely be greater than that of vessels without radar.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation:
Rule 7(b) of the COLREGS (International/Inland) requires proper use of operational radar for long-range scanning to obtain early warning of risk of collision. Therefore, option A is correct.

(USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook, Rule 7 - Risk of Collision)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A pilot vessel on pilotage duty shall show identity lights __________.
option_b: while at anchor
option_c: while alongside a vessel
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A pilot vessel is required to show identity lights (a white masthead light and a white all-round light below it) at all times when on pilotage duty, whether underway, at anchor, or alongside a vessel, as they are not restricted to just one operational mode. See Rule 29 of the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are underway in restricted  visibility and hear a fog signal forward of the beam. Nothing appears on your radar screen.  You must __________.
option_b: sound two prolonged blasts of the whistle
option_c: sound the danger signal
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct action is to slow to bare steerageway (D). Rule 19(e) of the COLREGs/USCG Navigation Rules states that a vessel hearing a fog signal forward of the beam, which cannot avoid a close-quarters situation, shall reduce her speed to the minimum at which she can be kept on her course.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A stand-on vessel in a crossing situation is allowed to take action when __________.
option_b: the vessels will pass within one mile
option_c: it becomes apparent to her that the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action
option_d: the relative speed of the vessels indicates collision in less than six minutes
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The stand-on vessel is required to maintain its course and speed (Rule 17(a)(i)). However, Rule 17(a)(ii) allows the stand-on vessel to take action to avoid a collision *as soon as it becomes apparent* that the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Traffic separation schemes established by the International Maritime Organization __________.
option_a: provide inbound and outbound lanes to promote the safe flow of vessel traffic
option_b: provide vessel reporting systems to assist in search and rescue in the event of a vessel casualty
option_c: provide routing and vessel scheduling procedures to reduce  shipping delays
option_d: prohibit vessels carrying hazardous cargos from entering waters that are environmentally sensitive
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Traffic separation schemes establish traffic lanes to separate opposing streams of traffic, promoting the safe flow of vessels. This is the primary function of a TSS as described in Rule 10 (Traffic Separation Schemes) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook (International & Inland).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel is required to sound a fog signal of one prolonged followed by two short blasts?
option_b: A sailing vessel, underway
option_c: A vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver, at anchor
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: This signal is sounded by a vessel not under command, a sailing vessel, a vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver (whether underway or at anchor), a vessel engaged in fishing, and vessels engaged in towing/pushing. Therefore, "All of the above" is correct. See Rule 35.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND At night, a broken down vessel  being towed would show the same lights as __________.
option_b: the towing vessel
option_c: a barge
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel being towed, like the broken-down vessel, exhibits sidelights and a sternlight (Rule 24(e)). A barge being towed, which falls under "a vessel or object other than those referred to in paragraph (g) of this Rule being towed," also shows these lights.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  What is the optional whistle signal which may be sounded by a vessel at anchor?
option_a: Two prolonged followed by one short blast
option_b: One short followed by two prolonged blasts
option_c: One short, one prolonged, followed by one short blast
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The optional warning signal for a vessel at anchor is C: one short, one prolonged, followed by one short blast. This signal may be sounded to warn an approaching vessel of her position and the possibility of collision. This is found in Rule 35(f) of the COLREGS/US Inland Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The minimum length of a power-driven vessel that must show forward and after masthead lights is __________.
option_b: 50 meters
option_c: 75 meters
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 23 (a)(ii) of the Navigation Rules states that a power-driven vessel must exhibit a second masthead light abaft of and higher than the forward one, "except that a vessel of less than 50 meters in length shall not be obliged to exhibit such light but may do so." Therefore, a vessel 50 meters or greater must show both.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What light(s), if any, would you show at night if your vessel was broken down and being towed astern by another vessel?
option_b: Same lights as for a power-driven vessel underway
option_c: A white light forward and a white light aft
option_d: The colored sidelights and a white stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel being towed, other than certain exceptions, must exhibit sidelights and a sternlight. The broken-down vessel is "being towed astern." This requirement is found in Rule 24(e) of the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel not under command making way at night would show __________.
option_a: two all-round red lights in a vertical line
option_b: anchor lights and sidelights
option_c: two all-round white lights in a vertical line, sidelights and a stern light
option_d: two all-round red lights in a vertical line, sidelights, and a stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel not under command that is making way at night must exhibit the lights for a vessel not under command (two all-round red lights in a vertical line) *and* the lights for a power-driven vessel underway (sidelights and a stern light). See Rule 27 (a)(i) and Rule 27 (a)(iii) in the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In a dense fog, you hear a whistle signal of one prolonged blast followed by three short blasts.  This signal is sounded by a __________.
option_b: fishing vessel underway trawling
option_c: pilot vessel underway making a special signal
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The signal of one prolonged blast followed by three short blasts is prescribed for a towing vessel, when manned, or a towed vessel, when manned. This is found in Rule 35(e) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway and pushing a barge ahead, your vessel enters a heavy rain storm.  You should sound __________.
option_a: a prolonged blast every two minutes
option_b: two prolonged blasts every two minutes
option_c: one prolonged and two short blasts every two minutes
option_d: one prolonged and three short blasts every two minutes
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(e) of the COLREGs (International & Inland) states that a vessel engaged in towing or pushing, when in restricted visibility, shall sound one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts at intervals of not more than two minutes.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND On open waters, a power-driven  vessel shall keep out of the way of a __________.
option_a: vessel on her port side that is crossing her course
option_b: vessel that is overtaking her
option_c: seaplane on the water
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "D", is a sailing vessel. Under Rule 18 (Responsibilities Between Vessels), a power-driven vessel underway shall keep out of the way of a sailing vessel. This rule establishes the hierarchy of vessels in open waters.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are overtaking a vessel at  night and you see a yellow light showing above the  stern light of the overtaken vessel.  The overtaken vessel is __________.
option_b: pushing ahead or towing alongside
option_c: towing astern
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The yellow light seen above the stern light is defined as a "towing light" (Rule 21(d)). A power-driven vessel towing astern exhibits a sternlight and a towing light in a vertical line above the sternlight (Rule 24(a)(iii) & (iv) in COLREGs, or similar Inland Rules provisions). Therefore, the vessel is towing astern.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Your vessel is at anchor in fog.  The fog signal of another vessel, apparently underway, has been growing louder and the danger of collision appears to exist.  In addition to your fog signal, what signal may be used to indicate your presence?
option_a: No signal other than your fog signal may be used.
option_b: One prolonged, one short, and one prolonged whistle blast
option_c: One prolonged followed by two short whistle blasts
option_d: One short, one prolonged, and one short whistle blast
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: As per Rule 34(d), a vessel at anchor may sound the danger signal of one short, one prolonged, and one short blast to indicate her presence and warn an approaching vessel of her position and the perceived danger of collision.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND All of the following are distress signals under the Rules EXCEPT __________.
option_b: orange-colored smoke
option_c: red flares
option_d: the repeated raising and lowering of outstretched arms
question_category: Annexes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is A because "International Code Signal 'AA'" is a general call signal, not a recognized distress signal. The accepted distress signals are listed in Rule 37 and Annex IV of the Rules, which include orange smoke, red flares, and raising and lowering arms.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A tug is towing three manned barges in line in fog.  The third barge of the tow should  sound __________.
option_b: one prolonged and two short blasts
option_c: one prolonged and three short blasts
option_d: one prolonged, one short and one prolonged blast
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer is C (one prolonged and three short blasts) because Rule 35(i) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations states that a vessel being towed or the last vessel in a tow, if manned, shall sound one prolonged, and three short blasts. This rule applies to both International and Inland waters.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  Which vessel is NOT classified as "restricted in her ability to maneuver"?
option_a: A vessel picking up a navigation mark
option_b: A vessel transferring cargo while underway
option_c: A vessel whose anchor is fouled
option_d: A vessel in a towing operation that restricts the ability of the vessel and her tow to change their course
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: A vessel with a fouled anchor is considered a "vessel not under command" (NUC) if she cannot maneuver as required by the Rules, not "restricted in her ability to maneuver" (RAM). RAM status is for vessels carrying out specific operations, as defined in Rule 3(g). Rule 3(f) defines NUC.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND During the day, a vessel picking up a submarine cable shall carry __________.
option_a: three shapes, the highest and lowest shall be red balls, and the middle shall be a white diamond
option_b: two black balls
option_c: three shapes; the highest and lowest shall be black balls,  and the middle shall be a red diamond
option_d: three shapes; the highest and lowest shall be black balls and the middle shall be a black diamond
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel picking up a submarine cable is "restricted in its ability to maneuver." Rule 27(b)(i) requires three shapes in a vertical line: ball, diamond, ball. Option D, "three shapes; the highest and lowest shall be black balls and the middle shall be a black diamond," describes this requirement. (Rule 27)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway your vessel enters fog.  You stop your engines and the vessel is dead in the water.  Which fog signal should you sound?
option_a: One prolonged blast every two minutes
option_b: Two prolonged blasts every two minutes
option_c: Three short blasts every two minutes
option_d: One prolonged and three short blasts every two minutes
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct signal is two prolonged blasts every two minutes, as specified in Rule 35(b) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules. This applies to a power-driven vessel underway that is stopped and making no way through the water in restricted visibility. The signal must be sounded at intervals of not more than 2 minutes.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are underway in a fog when  you hear a whistle signal of one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts.  This signal could indicate all of the following EXCEPT a vessel __________.
option_b: not under command
option_c: fishing with trawls
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: One prolonged blast followed by two short blasts is the fog signal for a vessel not under command, restricted in ability to maneuver, sailing vessel, vessel engaged in fishing, or vessel engaged in towing (Rule 35(c)). A vessel "being towed" (A) does not use this signal; the towing vessel sounds it. Rule 35.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A light signal consisting of three flashes means __________.
option_a: "I am in doubt as to your actions"
option_b: "My engines are full speed astern"
option_c: "I desire to overtake you"
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(a)(iii) (Maneuvering and warning signals) states that three short blasts on a vessel's whistle mean "I am operating astern propulsion." This is equivalent to a light signal of three flashes for maneuvering in the presence of other vessels. See 33 CFR § 83.34.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are watching another vessel approach and her compass bearing is not changing.  This means that __________.
option_b: a risk of collision exists
option_c: a special circumstances situation exists
option_d: the other vessel is dead in the water
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, B, is based on Rule 7 (Risk of Collision) of the Navigation Rules, which states that risk of collision shall be deemed to exist if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does not appreciably change. This is known as "constant bearing, decreasing range."

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel 30 meters in length and aground would display a day-shape consisting of __________.
option_b: one black ball
option_c: two black balls in a vertical line
option_d: three black balls in a vertical line
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel 30m aground (over 12m) must display three black balls in a vertical line. The rule for vessels aground is found in Rule 30 (e) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What is NOT a distress signal?
option_a: A continuous sounding of the fog horn
option_b: Firing a gun every minute
option_c: Five or more short rapid blasts on the whistle
option_d: A square flag and ball flown from the mast
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Five or more short, rapid blasts (C) is a danger signal (Rule 34(d)), not a distress signal. Distress signals are listed in Rule 37/Annex IV and include: continuous sounding of the fog horn, firing a gun every minute, and a square flag and ball.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is true concerning a vessel equipped with operational radar?
option_a: The Master of the vessel must be on the bridge when the radar is in use.
option_b: The radar equipment is only required to be used in  restricted visibility.
option_c: The use of a radar excuses a vessel from the need of a look-out.
option_d: This equipment must be used to obtain early warning of risk of collision.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer (D) is supported by Rule 7(b), Risk of Collision, which states that proper use shall be made of radar equipment if fitted and operational, including radar plotting or equivalent systematic observation, to obtain early warning of risk of collision. (USCG Navigation Rules, Rule 7)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway in fog you hear another vessel sounding two prolonged blasts every two minutes.  This signal indicates a vessel __________.
option_b: towing
option_c: drifting
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer is C (drifting) because a vessel not making way through the water sounds two prolonged blasts every two minutes in restricted visibility. A vessel that is drifting is not making way. See Rule 35(b) of the USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Fog bell signals for vessels at anchor or aground shall be sounded at intervals of not more than __________.
option_b: 5 minutes
option_c: 2 minutes
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation:
Rule 35(g) and 35(h) of the USCG Navigation Rules states that a vessel at anchor or aground shall sound their fog signals (bell/gong) at intervals of not more than 1 minute.
(33 CFR § 83.35)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel is carrying three lights in a vertical line.  The highest and lowest of these are red and the middle light is white.  Which statement is  always TRUE?
option_a: During the day, she would display three balls in a vertical line.
option_b: If making way, she would show masthead lights at night.
option_c: If at anchor, she need not show anchor lights while displaying identifying lights.
option_d: Her fog signal would consist of a rapid ringing of a bell for five seconds every minute.
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The lights (red-white-red) signify a vessel "restricted in its ability to maneuver" (RAM), under Rule 27(b). If the vessel is making way, it must also exhibit masthead lights, sidelights, and a sternlight in addition to the R-W-R all-round lights. Therefore, option B is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are on a power-driven vessel in fog. Your vessel is proceeding at a safe speed when you hear a fog signal ahead of you.  The Rules require you to navigate with caution and, if danger of collision exists __________.
option_b: reduce to bare steerageway
option_c: stop your engines
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "reduce to bare steerageway," aligns with Rule 19(e) of the COLREGs/Navigation Rules, which governs the conduct of vessels in restricted visibility. The rule requires that if a vessel hears a fog signal forward of her beam and a danger of collision exists, she shall reduce her speed to the minimum at which she can maintain her course (bare steerageway), and if necessary, take all her way off. This must be done with extreme caution until the danger is over. The relevant rule is Rule 19 - Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway in a fog you hear a signal of three strokes of a bell, a rapid ringing of the bell, and three more strokes of the bell.  This signal is made by a vessel __________.
option_b: aground
option_c: at anchor and greater than 100 meters in length
option_d: not under command and at anchor
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A vessel aground sounds the anchor signal (rapid ringing of the bell) with three distinct strokes before and after. This is mandated by Rule 35(j) of the Navigation Rules, confirming option B is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway in fog, you hear a signal of one prolonged blast followed by three short blasts.  This is the fog signal for a vessel __________.
option_b: being towed (manned)
option_c: under sail
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A vessel being towed, if manned, sounds one prolonged blast followed by three short blasts for her fog signal. This is required by Rule 35(e) of the COLREGS (International/Inland) and explains why 'B' is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel is to sound a fog  signal of one prolonged followed by two short blasts?
option_b: A sailing vessel underway
option_c: A vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver, at anchor
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(c) states that a vessel not under command and a sailing vessel underway must sound one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts. Rule 35(j) covers a vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver, at anchor, and requires the same signal. Therefore, D is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND At night you observe a vessel ahead show three flashes of a white light.  This signal indicates that the vessel ahead is __________.
option_b: approaching a bend in the channel
option_c: operating astern propulsion
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "operating astern propulsion," is based on Inland Rule 34(c) and International Rule 34(c). Three short, distinct flashes of a white light indicate the vessel is operating astern propulsion.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The use of the danger signal __________.
option_b: makes the other vessel the stand-on vessel
option_c: indicates doubt as to another vessels actions
option_d: is the same as a "MAYDAY" signal
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The danger signal, consisting of 5 or more short, rapid blasts, is used when you are in doubt as to the intentions of the approaching vessel or believe its maneuver is dangerous. This aligns with option C. Refer to Rule 34 (Maneuvering and Warning Signals) in the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which power-driven vessel is NOT required to carry a light in the position of the after masthead light?
option_a: A pushing vessel and a vessel being pushed, in a composite  unit and 100 meters in length
option_b: A vessel of 60 meters in length towing astern
option_c: A vessel of 45 meters in length trolling
option_d: Any vessel constrained by her draft
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 23(a)(ii) states a power-driven vessel less than 50 meters in length is not obliged to exhibit the second masthead light (after masthead light). The vessel in option C, at 45 meters, falls under this exception, making it the correct answer.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which requirement must be met in order for a stand-on vessel to take action to avoid collision?
option_b: The give-way vessel must have taken action first.
option_c: The vessels must be within half a mile of each other.
option_d: There are no requirements to be met.  The stand-on vessel may take action anytime.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: A stand-on vessel may take action to avoid collision once it determines that the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action to keep clear, which is when a risk of collision exists. The vessel may take avoiding action only when the risk becomes apparent. (COLREGS Rule 17)

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY  A single vessel being towed alongside shall exhibit __________.
option_b: sidelights and a stern light
option_c: only the outboard sidelight and a stern light
option_d: a masthead light, sidelights, and a stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "sidelights and a stern light" (Option B), is mandated by the International Rules (COLREGs). Rule 24(a)(ii) states that a vessel being towed alongside shall exhibit sidelights and a stern light. The question specifies "INTERNATIONAL ONLY".

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In which situation would risk of collision definitely exist?
option_a: A vessel is 22 degrees on your port bow, range increasing,  bearing changing slightly to the right.
option_b: A vessel is broad on your starboard beam, range decreasing, bearing changing rapidly to the right.
option_c: A vessel is 22 degrees abaft your port beam, range  increasing, bearing is constant.
option_d: A vessel is on your starboard quarter, range decreasing, bearing is constant.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Risk of collision is deemed to exist if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does not appreciably change, as stated in Rule 7(a)(i). Option D is the only situation where the bearing is constant and the range is decreasing, indicating a definite risk of collision. This is found in Rule 7(a)(i) of the Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel nearing a bend or an area of a channel or fairway where other vessels may be obscured by an intervening obstruction shall sound __________.
option_b: one prolonged blast
option_c: the danger signal
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(e) specifies that a vessel nearing a bend or obstruction that obscures other vessels shall sound one prolonged blast. The correct answer, B, is "one prolonged blast."

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In fog, you hear apparently forward of your beam a fog signal of 2 prolonged blasts in  succession every two minutes.  This signal indicates a __________.
option_a: power-driven vessel making way through the water
option_b: vessel being pushed ahead
option_c: vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
option_d: power-driven vessel underway but stopped and making no way  through the water
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A power-driven vessel underway but stopped and making no way through the water sounds two prolonged blasts in succession every two minutes in fog. This is outlined in Rule 35(b) of the COLREGs/US Inland Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel being towed will show  __________.
option_b: sidelights and a stern light
option_c: a towing light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "sidelights and a stern light," is mandated by both International Rule 24(e) and Inland Rule 83.24(e). A vessel or object being towed must exhibit sidelights and a sternlight.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In fog, a vessel being towed, if manned, shall sound a fog signal of __________.
option_b: three short blasts
option_c: one prolonged and two short blasts
option_d: one prolonged and three short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sound and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(h) of the Navigation Rules states that a manned vessel being towed shall sound a fog signal of one prolonged blast followed by three short blasts. This distinguishes it from other vessels and indicates its situation in restricted visibility.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel is directed not to impede the passage of a vessel which can only navigate inside a narrow channel?
option_a: A vessel of less than 20 meters in length
option_b: A vessel not under command
option_c: A vessel engaged in surveying
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 9(b) of the Navigation Rules states a vessel of less than 20 meters in length, or a sailing vessel, shall not impede the passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or fairway.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What day-shape must be shown on a partly submerged vessel which is being towed?
option_b: A cone
option_c: One black ball
option_d: Two black balls in a vertical line
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "A diamond," is mandated by Rule 24(e)(iii) of the Navigation Rules for a partly submerged vessel or object being towed when the length of the tow exceeds 200 meters. Even if the tow is shorter, a diamond shape indicates the presence of a tow.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  Which vessel is to be regarded as a vessel "restricted in her ability to maneuver"?
option_b: A vessel which has lost the use of her steering gear
option_c: A vessel with a draft of such depth that she cannot change  her course
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in mineclearing is specifically listed as a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver under Rule 3(g) of the Navigation Rules (COLREGs). This rule defines such vessels, among others, as those limited in maneuverability due to the nature of their work.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel would show 3 day-shapes in a vertical line, the highest and lowest being  balls and the middle shape being a diamond?
option_b: Vessel constrained by her draft
option_c: Vessel minesweeping
option_d: Vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver exhibits three shapes in a vertical line: ball, diamond, ball. This is required by Rule 27(b) of the COLREGs (International) and Inland Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A power-driven vessel "not under command" at night must show which lights in a vertical line?
option_b: Two red
option_c: Two white
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 27(a) of the COLREGS (International and Inland Rules) states that a vessel "not under command" shall exhibit two all-round red lights in a vertical line. This corresponds to Option B (Two red) in the question.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In order for a vessel to be "engaged in fishing" she must be __________.
option_b: using gear which extends more than 50 meters outboard
option_c: using a seine of some type
option_d: using gear which restricts her maneuverability
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 3(d) defines a vessel engaged in fishing as any vessel fishing with gear that restricts maneuverability. Options A, B, and C do not meet the definition unless they also restrict maneuverability.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY While underway and in sight of another vessel you put your engines on astern propulsion.  Which statement concerning whistle signals is TRUE?
option_a: You must sound three short blasts on the whistle.
option_b: You must sound one blast if backing to starboard.
option_c: You must sound whistle signals only if the vessels are meeting.
option_d: You need not sound any whistle signals.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "You must sound three short blasts on the whistle," is mandated by International Rule 34(a). This rule specifies that three short blasts mean "I am operating astern propulsion." This signal is required when in sight of another vessel.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND When shall the stand-on vessel  in a crossing situation take action to avoid the other vessel?
option_a: When a risk of collision exists
option_b: When action by the give-way vessel alone will not prevent a collision
option_c: When the bearing to give-way vessel becomes steady
option_d: When the vessels become less than 1/2 mile apart
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The stand-on vessel must maintain course and speed until it is apparent that the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action, or when collision cannot be avoided by the give-way vessel's action alone. Answer B reflects the point where the stand-on vessel's obligation shifts to avoiding collision. See Rule 17.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What signal would a vessel aground show during daylight?
option_b: Two black balls
option_c: Three black balls
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel aground must exhibit three black balls in a vertical line during daylight. This is according to Rule 30 (d) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook, which details the shapes required for vessels aground.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which is NOT a distress signal?
option_b: Vertical motion of a white lantern at night
option_c: Code flags "November" and "Charlie"
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, B, is not a distress signal per Rule 37 of the COLREGs (Navigation Rules). Recognized distress signals include flames, "N.C." code flags, and dye markers. Vertical motion of a white light is not listed in Annex IV (33 CFR § 83.37).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement about a 25-meter auxiliary sailboat is TRUE?
option_a: The sidelights and stern light may be combined in one lantern.
option_b: When operating under sail, her fog signal would consist of  one prolonged blast.
option_c: She may show a green light over a red light at the masthead.
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A 25-meter sailing vessel is not allowed to combine its lights into one lantern (Rule 25(b) allows this only for vessels under 20 meters). Therefore, she must exhibit fixed sidelights and a stern light. This is found in Rule 25(a).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel shall NOT impede the passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or fairway?
option_a: A vessel of less than 20 meters in length
option_b: A vessel sailing
option_c: A vessel fishing
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 9 of COLREGs/Inland Rules states that vessels of less than 20 meters, sailing vessels, and vessels engaged in fishing shall not impede the passage of a vessel that can safely navigate only within a narrow channel. Since all three listed vessels must not impede, "All of the above" is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway in a fog, you hear a whistle signal of one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts.  This signal could mean all of the following  EXCEPT a vessel __________.
option_b: towing astern
option_c: fishing with trawls
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The signal (one prolonged and two short blasts) is for a vessel that is NOT "being towed." This signal applies to a vessel: not under command, restricted in its ability to maneuver, constrained by draft, sailing, engaged in fishing, or towing/pushing. A vessel "being towed" sounds one prolonged and three short blasts. See Rule 35(c).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In which situation do you think a risk of collision exists?
option_a: A vessel is 22° on your port bow, range increasing, bearing changing slightly to the right.
option_b: A vessel is broad on your starboard beam, range decreasing, bearing changing rapidly to the right.
option_c: A vessel is 22° abaft your port beam, range increasing, bearing is constant.
option_d: A vessel is on your starboard quarter, range decreasing, bearing is constant.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The risk of collision is deemed to exist if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does not appreciably change and the range is decreasing. This is known as "Constant Bearing, Decreasing Range" (CBDR), and means collision is imminent. This is covered under Rule 7(d)(i) of the COLREGs/Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel aground in fog shall sound, in addition to the proper anchor signal, which of the following?
option_a: Three strokes on the gong before and after sounding the anchor signal
option_b: Three strokes on the bell before and after the anchor signal
option_c: Four short blasts on the whistle
option_d: One prolonged and one short blast on the whistle
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer is B because COLREGs Rule 35(g) states that a vessel aground shall, in addition to the anchor signal, give three separate and distinct strokes on the bell immediately before and after the rapid ringing of the bell.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Two vessels are approaching each other near head on.  What action should be taken to avoid collision?
option_a: The first vessel to sight the other should give way.
option_b: The vessel making the slower speed should give way.
option_c: Both vessels should alter course to starboard.
option_d: Both vessels should alter course to port.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer is 'C' because Rule 14 (Head-on Situation) of the Navigation Rules states that when two power-driven vessels are meeting on reciprocal courses so as to involve risk of collision, each shall alter course to starboard so they pass port side to port side. See 33 CFR § 83.14 (Inland) and Rule 14 (International).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Your vessel is 25 meters long and anchored in restricted visibility. You are required to  sound the proper fog signal at intervals of not more than __________.
option_b: one minute
option_c: two minutes
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(g) of the Navigation Rules states that a vessel at anchor shall, at intervals of not more than one minute, ring the bell rapidly for about 5 seconds. The correct answer, one minute (Option B), aligns with this requirement.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway in fog, you hear a short blast, a prolonged blast, and a short blast of a whistle.  This signal indicates a __________.
option_b: sailboat underway in fog
option_c: vessel being towed in fog
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A signal of one short blast, one prolonged blast, and one short blast is the required signal for a vessel at anchor in restricted visibility to give warning of its position and the possibility of collision to an approaching vessel. This is found in Rule 35(g).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are the stand-on vessel in a crossing situation.  You may hold your course and speed until __________.
option_a: the other vessel takes necessary action
option_b: the other vessel gets to within half a mile of your vessel
option_c: action by the give-way vessel alone will not prevent collision
option_d: the other vessel gets to within a quarter mile of your vessel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The stand-on vessel must maintain course and speed until it is determined that "action by the give-way vessel alone will not prevent collision." At that point, the stand-on vessel must take avoiding action. This is according to Rule 17(a)(ii) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The arc of visibility for sidelights is from right ahead to __________.
option_b: abeam
option_c: 22.5° forward of the beam
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is "22.5° abaft the beam" (A) because sidelights must show an unbroken light from right ahead to 22.5 degrees abaft the beam on their respective side of the vessel. This is specified in Rule 21(b) of the Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In narrow channels, vessels of  less than what length shall not impede the safe passage of  vessels which can navigate only inside that channel?
option_b: 50 meters
option_c: 65 meters
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 9(b) states that a vessel of less than 20 meters in length shall not impede the passage of a vessel that can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or fairway. The correct answer is 20 meters. (Rule 9, Narrow Channels)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway and in sight of  another vessel crossing less than .5 mile away, you put your engines full speed astern. Which statement concerning whistle signals is TRUE?
option_a: You must sound three short blasts on the whistle.
option_b: You must sound one blast if backing to starboard.
option_c: You must sound whistle signals only if the vessels are meeting.
option_d: You need not sound any whistle signals.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The action of putting your engines full speed astern is a vessel maneuvering in reverse. Rule 34(a) states that a vessel operating astern propulsion must sound three short blasts. This signal indicates "I am operating astern propulsion."

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel showing a yellow light over a white light at night is a vessel __________.
option_b: towing astern
option_c: engaged in fishing
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in towing astern (towing vessel only) displays a yellow light above a white light (a towing light above a sternlight) on the stern. The yellow towing light replaces the sternlight when towing. This is found under Rule 24 (a) and (b).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel hearing a fog signal forward of her beam has not determined if risk of collision exists.  She shall reduce speed to __________.
option_b: safe speed
option_c: half speed
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 19(e) states a vessel hearing a fog signal forward of her beam, and not being certain that risk of collision exists, shall reduce her speed to the minimum at which she can be kept on her course, or "bare steerageway." This applies both International and Inland.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Two vessels are in an overtaking situation.  Which of the lights on the overtaken vessel will the overtaking vessel see?
option_b: One masthead light and a sidelight
option_c: Both sidelights
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The overtaking vessel will see only the stern light of the overtaken vessel. The stern light covers an arc of visibility of 135 degrees across the stern. The rule defining an overtaking situation is Rule 13 of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway and making way your vessel enters fog.  Which fog signal should you sound  every two minutes?
option_b: Two prolonged blasts
option_c: Three short blasts
option_d: A prolonged blast and three short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(a) of the COLREGS/Inland Rules states that a power-driven vessel making way through the water shall sound one prolonged blast at intervals of not more than 2 minutes when operating in restricted visibility.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND On open water, a vessel fishing is in a crossing situation with a vessel sailing located on the fishing vessel's starboard side.  Which vessel is the stand-on vessel?
option_a: The fishing vessel because it is to port of the sailing vessel.
option_b: The fishing vessel because it is fishing.
option_c: The sailing vessel because it is to starboard of the fishing vessel.
option_d: The sailing vessel because it is sailing.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The fishing vessel is the stand-on vessel because vessels engaged in fishing have the right of way over sailing vessels according to Rule 18 (Responsibilities Between Vessels). The hierarchy of responsibility dictates the vessel engaged in fishing maintains course and speed.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The lights prescribed by the Rules shall be exhibited __________.
option_a: from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
option_b: at all times
option_c: from sunset to sunrise, and at no other time
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Lights are required from sunrise to sunset when operating in restricted visibility (Rule 20(c)). However, lights are also mandatory from sunset to sunrise (Rule 20(b)), and at all times in restricted visibility. Option A covers the daytime restricted visibility requirement.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Risk of collision may exist __________.
option_a: if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does NOT appreciably change
option_b: even when an appreciable bearing change is evident, particularly when approaching a vessel at close range
option_c: if you observe both sidelights of a vessel ahead for an extended period of time
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Risk of collision exists if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does NOT appreciably change (Rule 7(b)(i)). Risk may also exist even with an appreciable bearing change when approaching a vessel at close range (Rule 7(b)(ii)). Observing both sidelights of a vessel ahead for an extended time is another indication of risk. The correct answer is "All of the above" (D). See Inland and International Rule 7.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND "safe speed" is defined as that speed where __________.
option_a: you can stop within your visibility range
option_b: you can take proper and effective action to avoid collision
option_c: you are traveling slower than surrounding vessels
option_d: no wake comes from your vessel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer is B because both International & Inland Rule 6 defines "safe speed" as a speed where effective action can be taken to avoid collision. This rule dictates that every vessel shall proceed at a safe speed.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel showing a green light  over a white light in a vertical line above the level of the sidelights is __________.
option_b: under sail and power
option_c: a pilot vessel
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation:
The correct answer, trawling, is indicated by the green light over the white light in a vertical line. These are the lights prescribed for a vessel engaged in trawling.

Reference: USCG Navigation Rules, Rule 26(b).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  A vessel being towed at night must show __________.
option_b: sidelights and a stern light
option_c: a flashing yellow light, only
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel being towed at night must show sidelights and a sternlight. This is specified in Rule 24(e) of the COLREGS (International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea) which is part of the USCG Navigation Rules. The correct answer is B.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND To determine if risk of collision exists, a vessel which is fitted with radar must use __________.
option_b: radar plotting
option_c: compass bearings
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Correct answer D is supported by Rule 7, Risk of Collision. A vessel must use all available means appropriate to the circumstances to determine if risk of collision exists. This includes systematic observation (radar scanning), evaluation (radar plotting), and monitoring the compass bearing of an approaching vessel. (33 CFR § 83.07)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND If a vessel is engaged in fishing according to the definitions in the Rules, it will  have __________.
option_a: gear extending from the side or stern
option_b: gear that restricts maneuverability
option_c: less than 50 percent trolling lines
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, B, states the vessel must have "gear that restricts maneuverability." This is per Rule 3(d) of the COLREGs (International and Inland Rules), which defines a "vessel engaged in fishing" as one using fishing apparatus that restricts its maneuverability. This excludes vessels using trolling lines or other gear that does not restrict maneuverability.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway in fog you hear  the rapid ringing of a bell.  What does this signal indicate?
option_b: A sailboat underway
option_c: A vessel at anchor
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The rapid ringing of a bell, sounded for about 5 seconds at intervals of not more than one minute, indicates a vessel at anchor in restricted visibility. This is prescribed in the USCG’s Navigation Rules, specifically Rule 35(g).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Two power-driven vessels are crossing so as to involve risk of collision. Which statement is TRUE, according to the Rules?
option_a: The vessel which has the other on her own port side shall keep out of the way.
option_b: If the stand-on vessel takes action, she shall avoid changing course to port.
option_c: If the give-way vessel takes action, she shall avoid changing course to starboard.
option_d: The give-way vessel should keep the other vessel to her starboard.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The stand-on vessel should avoid changing course to port when taking action in a crossing situation to prevent confusion, especially if the other vessel is on her own port side. See Rule 17(c) in the COLREGs (Inland and International).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What is the minimum vessel length which must show two white masthead lights, one forward and one aft, when underway at night?
option_b: 20 meters
option_c: 50 meters
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A power-driven vessel of 50 meters or more in length is required to show two white masthead lights (one forward and one abaft/higher than the forward one) when underway at night. Vessels less than 50 meters are not obliged to exhibit the second light but may do so. (Rule 23).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Every vessel that is to keep out of the way of another vessel must take positive early action to comply with this obligation and must __________.
option_a: avoid crossing ahead of the other vessel
option_b: avoid passing astern of the other vessel
option_c: sound one prolonged blast to indicate compliance
option_d: alter course to port for a vessel on her port side
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer is based on Rule 16 (Action by Give-way Vessel) and Rule 15 (Crossing Situation) of the COLREGs/Navigation Rules. The vessel directed to keep out of the way must take early and substantial action and "avoid crossing ahead of the other vessel," which is option A.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND At night, a power-driven vessel less than 12 meters in length may, instead of the normal navigation lights, show sidelights and one __________.
option_b: yellow light
option_c: flashing white light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is A, "white light," because Rule 23(c) of the Navigation Rules states that a power-driven vessel less than 12 meters may exhibit an all-round white light and sidelights, in lieu of other lights prescribed in paragraph (a) of the Rule.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are crossing a narrow channel in an 18-meter tug when you sight a loaded tankship off your port bow coming up the channel.  Which statement is correct?
option_a: Neither vessel is the stand-on vessel because the tankship is crossing.
option_b: You cannot impede the safe passage of the tankship.
option_c: The tankship is the stand-on vessel because it is in the channel.
option_d: The tankship is the stand-on vessel because it is the larger  of the two vessels.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, B, is based on Rule 9(b) (Narrow Channels). A vessel crossing a narrow channel shall not impede the passage of a vessel which can safely proceed only within that channel. The tankship is proceeding along the narrow channel, and your tug is crossing it.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel engaged in fishing underway sounds the same fog signal as a __________.
option_a: power-driven vessel stopped and making no way through the water
option_b: vessel being towed
option_c: vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver at anchor
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Both a vessel engaged in fishing underway and a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver sound one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts at intervals of not more than 2 minutes. This is correct according to Rule 35(c).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel 15 meters in length which is proceeding under sail as well as being propelled by machinery shall exhibit during the daytime __________.
option_b: a basket
option_c: a cone with its apex downward
option_d: two cones with their apexes together
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 25(e) states a vessel proceeding under sail and propelled by machinery shall exhibit a conical shape, apex downwards, forward where it can best be seen. Therefore, "a cone with its apex downward" (Option C) is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel should not impede the navigation of a power-driven vessel?
option_b: A vessel engaged in fishing
option_c: A sailing vessel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer is D because a seaplane on the water must generally keep well clear of all vessels and avoid impeding their navigation, according to Rule 18(e) of the Navigation Rules (33 CFR § 83.18(e)).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Your vessel is underway but stopped and making no way through the water when fog sets in.  Which fog signal should you sound?
option_a: One prolonged blast on the whistle
option_b: One prolonged blast and two short blasts on the whistle
option_c: Two prolonged blasts on the whistle
option_d: One short, one prolonged, and one short blast on the whistle
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Correct answer is C, "Two prolonged blasts on the whistle," because a power-driven vessel underway but stopped and making no way through the water must sound two prolonged blasts in succession at intervals of not more than 2 minutes. See Rule 35(b) in the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel underway and fishing shall keep out of the way of a __________.
option_b: vessel not under command
option_c: vessel sailing
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "vessel not under command," is based on Rule 18(c)(i) of the Navigation Rules, which dictates that a vessel engaged in fishing, when underway, must keep out of the way of a vessel not under command. This establishes a hierarchy where a vessel not under command has the right of way over a vessel engaged in fishing.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The whistle signal for a vessel operating astern propulsion is __________.
option_b: one prolonged blast
option_c: three short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, C (three short blasts), is correct because Rule 34(a)(iii) states that a vessel operating astern propulsion shall sound three short blasts. This signal indicates the vessel's intention and that it is operating with engines going astern.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND An anchored vessel is servicing an aid to navigation and is restricted in her ability to maneuver.  Which lights will she show?
option_a: Three lights in a vertical line, the highest and lowest red and the middle white, and anchor lights
option_b: Three lights in a vertical line, the highest and lowest red and the middle white,  ONLY
option_c: Anchor lights ONLY
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 27 and Rule 30. A vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver shows three all-round vertical lights (red-white-red). Since the vessel is also anchored, it must also exhibit anchor lights as required for a vessel at anchor. This combination is specified in option A.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel is a "vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver" under the Rules?
option_b: A vessel engaged in fishing
option_c: A vessel at anchor
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in mineclearing is explicitly listed as a "vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver." This is covered under Rule 3(g) of the Navigation Rules, General Definitions.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What would NOT be a distress signal?
option_b: Continuous sounding of fog horn
option_c: Green star shells fired from a launcher
option_d: Square flag and ball in a vertical line
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Green star shells are not listed as an approved distress signal in Annex IV of the Navigation Rules, which describes the signals of distress (Rule 37). Distress signals include red star shells, not green. Therefore, option C is the one that would NOT be a distress signal.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In a dense fog you hear a whistle signal ahead of one prolonged blast followed by three short blasts.  This signal indicates a __________.
option_b: manned vessel being towed
option_c: pilot vessel underway making a special signal
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The signal, one prolonged blast followed by three short blasts, is the required sound signal for a manned vessel being towed, according to Rule 35(e) of the Navigation Rules (COLREGS). This distinct signal informs other vessels of the situation in restricted visibility.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND If a towing vessel and her tow are severely restricted in their ability to deviate from their course, they may show lights in addition to their towing identification lights.  These additional lights may  be shown if the tow is __________.
option_b: towed alongside
option_c: towed astern
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The tow may show the additional all-round white light(s) for a tow exceeding 200 meters in length (Rule 24(a)(vii)) or the restricted visibility lights (Rule 27(b)) if the operation severely restricts deviation from course, and the tow is towed astern. See Rule 24 and Rule 27(c) for full requirements.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A head-on situation at night is one in which you see __________.
option_a: one sidelight of a vessel ahead of you
option_b: one sidelight and a masthead light of a vessel ahead of you
option_c: one sidelight, a masthead light, and a range light of a vessel ahead of you
option_d: both sidelights of a vessel dead ahead of you
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, D, is because seeing both sidelights (red and green) of a vessel dead ahead indicates a meeting or head-on situation at night. This is covered by Rule 14 (Head-on Situation) of the Inland and International Navigation Rules (COLREGS).
