question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  You are the stand-on vessel in a crossing situation.  If you think the give-way vessel is  NOT taking sufficient action to avoid collision, you should sound __________.
option_a: one short blast and maintain course
option_b: two short blasts, alter to port, and pass astern
option_c: no signal and maneuver at will
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer is the danger signal (D). If the stand-on vessel determines the give-way vessel is not taking sufficient action to avoid collision, they must sound the danger signal (five short and rapid blasts). This is covered in Rule 34(d) of the International and Inland Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A lantern combining the two sidelights and stern light may be shown on a __________.
option_b: 20-meter vessel engaged in fishing and making way
option_c: 25-meter power-driven vessel engaged in trolling
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is 'A' (10-meter sailing vessel). Rule 25(b) of the COLREGs (International) and Inland Rules states that in a sailing vessel of less than 20 meters in length, the sidelights and stern light may be combined in one lantern.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  A vessel aground would show the same day-shape as a __________.
option_b: dredge underway and dredging
option_c: hydrographic survey vessel at anchor and surveying
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel aground must show three balls in a vertical line (Rule 30(d)). The other vessels listed show different day shapes: vessel towing (diamond), dredge underway (ball-diamond-ball), and a surveying vessel at anchor (ball-diamond-ball). Therefore, "None of the above" is correct. Refer to Rule 30(d) of the Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are underway in fog when you hear a signal of three strokes of a bell, a rapid ringing of the bell, and three more strokes of the bell.  This signal  indicates a vessel __________.
option_b: aground
option_c: at anchor, greater than 100 meters
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The signal (three strokes of a bell, rapid ringing, and three more strokes) is the prescribed sound signal for a vessel aground. The USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook, Rule 35(h), specifies this signal for a vessel aground in restricted visibility.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A power-driven vessel "not under command" at night must show her sidelights when __________.
option_b: making no headway
option_c: moored to a buoy
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 27(a)(iii) states that a vessel not under command must show sidelights and a sternlight when making way through the water. This is equivalent to "making headway."

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The term "prolonged blast" means a blast of __________.
option_b: four to six seconds duration
option_c: six to eight seconds duration
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Option B, "four to six seconds duration," is correct because the International and Inland Rules of Navigation define a prolonged blast as a blast of this duration. This can be found in Rule 32 (Definitions) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While you are underway, navigation lights must be displayed on your vessel __________.
option_a: during all periods of restricted visibility
option_b: at all times
option_c: at night only when other vessels may be in the area
option_d: at night only when vessels are detected on radar
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 20(b) requires lights from sunset to sunrise. Rule 20(c) requires them also from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility. While lights are required at night, "during all periods of restricted visibility" is the explicit secondary requirement given in the rules. Rule 20(c).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning risk of collision?
option_a: The stand-on vessel must keep out of the way of the other vessel when risk of collision exists.
option_b: Risk of collision always exists when two vessels pass within one mile of each other.
option_c: Risk of collision always exists when the compass bearing of an approaching vessel changes appreciably.
option_d: Risk of collision may exist when the compass bearing of an  approaching vessel is changing appreciably.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Option D is correct as per Rule 7 (Risk of Collision), which states that risk may sometimes exist even when an appreciable bearing change is evident, especially at close range or when approaching large vessels or tows. The bearing changing appreciably does not guarantee risk *does not* exist.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel nearing a bend where other vessels may be obscured shall sound __________.
option_b: one long blast
option_c: two short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(e) specifies that a vessel nearing a bend or an area of a channel or fairway where other vessels may be obscured must sound one prolonged blast. This signal warns obscured vessels of the approaching vessel.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel that is defined as "restricted in her ability to maneuver" is unable to keep out of the way of another vessel due to __________.
option_b: the nature of her work
option_c: some exceptional circumstances
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, B, is "the nature of her work." A vessel "restricted in her ability to maneuver" is defined as being unable to keep out of the way of another vessel due to the nature of her work. See Rule 3(g) in the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway in fog, you hear a vessel sound four short blasts in succession.  What does  this signal indicate?
option_b: A vessel being towed
option_c: A vessel fishing
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation:
Rule 35(k) (Inland and International) states that a pilot vessel engaged on pilotage duty may sound an identity signal consisting of four short blasts, in addition to other required signals in restricted visibility (fog).
Ref: Rule 35(k)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are in charge of a stand-on vessel in a crossing situation.  The other vessel is 1.5 miles to port.  You believe that risk of collision exists.  You should __________.
option_a: take avoiding action immediately upon determining that risk of collision exists
option_b: immediately sound the danger signal
option_c: take avoiding action only after providing the give-way vessel time to take action, and determining that her action is not appropriate
option_d: hold course and speed until the point of extremis, and then sound the danger signal, taking whatever action will best avert collision
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 17(a)(ii) and 17(d) state the stand-on vessel shall maintain course/speed unless the give-way vessel's action alone is insufficient. Rule 17(c) allows action as soon as it becomes apparent the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action. Therefore, the stand-on vessel must wait a reasonable time before acting. See Rule 17.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND To be considered "engaged in fishing" according to the Rules of the Road, a vessel must  be __________.
option_a: using fishing apparatus which restricts maneuverability
option_b: using trolling lines
option_c: power-driven
option_d: showing lights or shapes for a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 3(d) of the Navigation Rules defines a vessel "engaged in fishing" as one fishing with apparatus which restricts maneuverability. Trolling lines do not count.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway in fog you hear a rapid ringing of a bell ahead.  This bell indicates a __________.
option_b: vessel in distress
option_c: sailboat underway
option_d: vessel backing out of a berth
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A rapid ringing of a bell for 5 seconds every minute is the fog signal for a vessel at anchor, as prescribed in the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook, Rule 35(g). This signal warns other vessels of its position in restricted visibility.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND An overtaking situation would be one in which one vessel is approaching another from more than how many degrees abaft the beam?
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 13 (Overtaking) defines an overtaking situation when a vessel approaches another from a direction more than 22.5 degrees abaft the beam. This arc is where the stern light is visible and the sidelights are not, meaning the approaching vessel is only seeing the stern light of the vessel ahead. This confirms option C is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A stand-on vessel is __________.
option_a: required to give way in a crossing situation
option_b: required to sound the first passing signal in a meeting situation
option_c: free to maneuver in any crossing or meeting situation as it has the right-of-way
option_d: required to maintain course and speed in a crossing situation but may take action to avoid collision
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, D, is based on Rule 17(a)(i) of the Navigation Rules, which states the stand-on vessel shall "keep her course and speed." Rule 17(b) allows the stand-on vessel to take action to avoid collision if the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND An overtaking situation at night would be one in which one vessel sees which light(s) of a vessel ahead?
option_b: One sidelight, the masthead lights and stern light
option_c: Both sidelights
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 13 (Overtaking) of the Navigation Rules states a vessel is overtaking when she can see only the stern light of the vessel ahead. The stern light covers an arc of 135 degrees from dead astern, making it the only light visible to an overtaking vessel.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What lights must sailboats show when underway at night?
option_b: A stern light
option_c: Red and green sidelights
option_d: Red and green sidelights and a stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Option D is correct as Rule 25(a) of the COLREGs (Navigation Rules) states a sailing vessel underway must exhibit sidelights (red and green) and a sternlight. This combination is essential for visibility and collision avoidance at night.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are crossing a narrow channel in a small motorboat.  You sight a tankship off your port bow coming up the channel.  Which statement is TRUE?
option_a: You are the stand-on vessel because the tankship is to port.
option_b: You cannot impede the safe passage of the tankship.
option_c: The tankship is the stand-on vessel because it is to port of  your vessel.
option_d: The tankship is the stand-on vessel because it is the larger  of the two vessels.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation:
The small motorboat must not impede the passage of a vessel that can safely navigate only within the narrow channel, which typically applies to large vessels like tankships. Therefore, the small motorboat cannot impede the tankship's safe passage.

Rule 9 (b) of the Navigation Rules states that a vessel of less than 20 meters in length shall not impede the passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel does NOT sound a fog signal of one prolonged followed by two short blasts?
option_b: A vessel being towed
option_c: A vessel engaged in fishing
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The fog signal of one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts is sounded by vessels that are not under command, restricted in their ability to maneuver, constrained by their draft, engaged in fishing, or sailing vessels (Rule 35(c) & (d)). A vessel being towed sounds one prolonged blast only (Rule 35(a)). The correct answer is B.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which light(s) is(are) AMONG those shown by a 200-meter vessel at anchor?
option_a: In the forepart of the vessel, a 225° white light
option_b: In the after part of the vessel, a 135° white light
option_c: Any available working lights to illuminate the decks
option_d: In the fore part of the vessel, a 135° white light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 30(e) requires a vessel of 100 meters or more at anchor to use available working or equivalent lights to illuminate the decks. While not the required anchor lights, this illumination is a light *among* those shown.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A partly submerged vessel or object being towed, which is not readily noticeable, shall  show __________.
option_b: two red lights in a vertical line
option_c: a black ball
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, D, "a diamond shape," is required by Rule 24(g)(iv) of the Navigation Rules (Towing and Pushing) for an inconspicuous, partly submerged vessel or object being towed. This shape must be exhibited at or near the aftermost extremity of the vessel being towed.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Concerning the identification  signal for a pilot vessel, in fog, which statement is TRUE?
option_a: When at anchor, the pilot vessel is only required to sound anchor signals.
option_b: The identification signal must be sounded any time the pilot vessel is underway.
option_c: The pilot vessel may only sound the identity signal when making way.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A pilot vessel engaged on pilotage duty *may* sound an identity signal (four short blasts) in restricted visibility, *in addition to* other required signals, such as anchor signals when anchored (Rule 35(e) International or Rule 35(k) Inland). Therefore, a pilot vessel at anchor is only *required* to sound anchor signals.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In a crossing situation, a vessel fishing must keep out of the way of a vessel which is __________.
option_b: towing
option_c: restricted in her ability to maneuver
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: A vessel fishing must keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver because, per the hierarchy in Rule 18 (Responsibilities Between Vessels), a restricted vessel has the right-of-way over a fishing vessel.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel would display a cone, apex downward?
option_a: A fishing vessel with outlying gear
option_b: A vessel proceeding under sail and machinery
option_c: A vessel engaged in diving operations
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel proceeding under sail and machinery displays a cone, apex downward, as a day shape. This is required by Rule 25(e) of the COLREGs/US Inland Rules, which applies both internationally and inland.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND When action to avoid a close quarters situation is taken, a course change alone may be the most effective action provided that __________.
option_a: it is done in a succession of small course changes
option_b: it is NOT done too early
option_c: it is a large course change
option_d: the course change is to starboard
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation:
The correct answer, "it is a large course change," is based on Rule 8(b) of the Navigation Rules, which states that any alteration of course and/or speed to avoid collision shall be large enough to be readily apparent to another vessel observing visually or by radar. This applies to both International and Inland rules.

Reference: Rule 8(b) (Action to avoid collision).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are underway in heavy fog.  You hear the fog signal of a vessel which is somewhere ahead of your vessel.  You must __________.
option_a: slow to moderate speed and navigate with caution
option_b: maintain speed and sound the danger signal
option_c: stop engines and navigate with caution
option_d: slow to bare steerageway and navigate with caution
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 19 (d) states that a vessel hearing a fog signal forward of the beam must reduce speed to bare steerageway or take all way off. The vessel shall navigate with extreme caution until the danger of collision is over.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel at anchor will show a __________.
option_b: cone
option_c: cylinder
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is A (ball). Day signals for a vessel at anchor require one black ball where it can best be seen. This is specified in Rule 30(a)(i) of the COLREGs (International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea), which is part of the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What day-shape must be shown by a vessel over 20 meters fishing which has gear extending more than 150 meters horizontally outward from it?
option_b: One diamond shape
option_c: One cone with its apex upwards
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "One cone with its apex upwards" (C), is the day-shape shown on the side where the gear extends more than 150 meters. This is an additional signal to the required two cones with apexes together for fishing vessels. Refer to Rule 26(c) of the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel towing astern  in an operation which severely restricts the towing vessel  and her tow in their ability to change course shall, when making way, exhibit __________.
option_a: the masthead lights for a towing vessel
option_b: the lights for a vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver
option_c: sidelights, stern light and towing light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 24 governs towing lights (A and C), and Rule 27 governs lights for a vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver (B). When a towing vessel is severely restricted in its ability to change course, it must display both sets of lights, as per Rule 27(a)(iii). Therefore, "All of the above" is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel underway but not making way and fishing other than trawling will show which lights?
option_a: A white light over a red light
option_b: A red light over a white light
option_c: A white light over a red light, sidelights, and a stern light
option_d: A red light over a white light, sidelights, and a stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 26(c) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook states that a vessel engaged in fishing, other than trawling, shall exhibit two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being red and the lower white. This configuration applies even if the vessel is underway but not making way.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A 200-meter vessel is aground in restricted visibility.  Which signal is optional?
option_b: A gong signal
option_c: A whistle signal
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(g) dictates that a vessel over 100m aground in restricted visibility must sound the bell and gong signals. The vessel "may" sound an appropriate whistle signal, which means it is optional. The required signals are the bell and gong.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel or object being towed astern shall display a(n) __________.
option_b: after masthead light
option_c: stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel or object being towed astern must exhibit a sternlight. Rule 24(e)(ii) specifies that a vessel or object being towed shall exhibit a sternlight, which corresponds to option C.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The rules state that vessels may depart from the requirements of the Rules when __________.
option_a: there are no other vessels around
option_b: operating in a narrow channel
option_c: the Master enters it in the ship's log
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: Rule 2(b) of the COLREGS allows a vessel to depart from the Rules when necessary to avoid immediate danger, ensuring safety above strict adherence in critical situations.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND For the purpose of the Rules, except where otherwise required, the term __________.
option_b: "seaplane" includes nondisplacement craft
option_c: "vessel engaged in fishing" includes a vessel fishing with  trolling lines
option_d: "vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver" includes fishing vessels
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: The correct answer, A, is confirmed by Rule 3(a) of the Navigation Rules (33 CFR § 83.03, Rule 3). This rule states that the word "vessel" includes every description of watercraft, "including non-displacement craft, WIG craft and seaplanes," used as a means of transportation on water.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning a 75-meter power-driven vessel underway at night?
option_a: She must exhibit an all-round white light at the stern.
option_b: She must exhibit forward and after masthead lights.
option_c: She must exhibit only a forward masthead light.
option_d: She may exhibit a red light over a green light forward.
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A power-driven vessel 75 meters long is over 50 meters, requiring both a forward masthead light and a second masthead light abaft of and higher than the forward one. This is required by Rule 23, Power-driven vessels underway, in the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Every vessel which is directed  by these Rules to keep out of the way of another vessel shall, if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid __________.
option_b: crossing astern of the other
option_c: passing port to port
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 15(a) of the COLREGs (International) and Inland Navigation Rules states that in a crossing situation, the give-way vessel shall, if circumstances admit, avoid crossing ahead of the other vessel. This action prevents further risk of collision.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which signal may be used by a vessel that is in doubt as to whether sufficient action is being taken by another vessel to avoid collision?
option_a: A continuous sounding of the fog horn
option_b: Firing a gun every minute
option_c: Five or more short rapid blasts on the whistle
option_d: One prolonged blast on the whistle
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(d) of the Navigation Rules states that a vessel in doubt about collision-avoiding action being taken by another vessel shall indicate such doubt by giving at least five short and rapid blasts on the whistle.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Navigation lights must be displayed in all weathers from sunset to sunrise. They also __________.
option_a: must be displayed when day signals are being used
option_b: must be displayed when moored to a pier
option_c: may be extinguished at night on open waters when no other vessels are in the area
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Navigation lights must be displayed from sunset to sunrise. According to Rule 20(c) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook, they must also be exhibited from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility and "may be exhibited in all other circumstances," which includes daylight.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What describes a head-on situation?
option_a: Seeing a vessel displaying both sidelights ONLY dead ahead
option_b: Seeing two forward white towing identification lights in a  vertical line on a towing vessel directly ahead
option_c: Seeing both sidelights of a vessel directly off your starboard beam
option_d: Seeing both sidelights  and masthead light(s) of a vessel dead ahead
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Option D is correct because Rule 14 (Head-on situation) of the Navigation Rules states that at night, a head-on situation is indicated if a vessel sees the other vessel's masthead lights in a line or nearly in a line, and/or both sidelights. Seeing both sidelights and masthead light(s) dead ahead fits this description.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND When two vessels are in immediate danger of collision, the stand-on vessel must __________.
option_b: assist in taking whatever action is necessary to avoid collision
option_c: hold course and speed
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: When in immediate danger of collision, COLREG Rule 17(b) requires the stand-on vessel to take action to avoid collision. This overrides the usual requirement to maintain course and speed. See Rule 17(b) in the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel 25 meters in length must have which sound signaling appliance onboard?
option_b: Whistle only
option_c: Whistle and bell only
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 33(a) of the COLREGS and the Inland Rules states that vessels 12 meters or more in length shall be provided with a whistle and a bell. A gong is only required for vessels 100 meters or more in length.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel transferring provisions or cargo at sea shall display during the day __________.
option_a: two black balls in a vertical line
option_b: three black balls in a vertical line
option_c: three shapes in a vertical line; the highest and lowest shall be red balls and the middle a white diamond
option_d: three black shapes in a vertical line; the highest and lowest shall be balls and the middle one a diamond
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation:
Rule 27(d) states that a vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver (like one transferring provisions or cargo) shall exhibit three shapes in a vertical line: ball, diamond, ball. This corresponds to the three black shapes description in option D.

(Reference: USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook, Rule 27(d))

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You see a red sidelight bearing NW (315°).  That vessel may be heading __________.
option_b: east (090°)
option_c: northeast (045°)
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The red sidelight is visible over an arc of 112.5° on the port side, from dead ahead to 22.5° abaft the beam (Rule 23/25). Seeing the red light bearing NW (315°) places the vessel on your port bow, and South (180°) is the standard test answer for this scenario, indicating you are viewing its port side.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Each prolonged blast on whistle signals used by a power-driven vessel in fog, whether making way or underway but not making way, is __________.
option_b: two to four seconds
option_c: four to six seconds
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 32(b) of the COLREGs (International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea) defines a prolonged blast as lasting 4 to 6 seconds. This rule applies to both International and Inland waters.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning a "vessel engaged in fishing"?
option_a: The vessel may be using nets, lines, or trawls.
option_b: The vessel may be trolling.
option_c: The vessel shows 2 lights in a vertical line, white over red.
option_d: The vessel sounds the same fog signal as a vessel underway, making no way.
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 3(d) defines a vessel engaged in fishing as one using nets, lines, trawls, or other apparatus that restrict maneuverability. Option A correctly lists fishing apparatus that qualify a vessel as "engaged in fishing." Option B is incorrect as trolling does not restrict maneuverability. See Rule 3(d).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The Rules state that risk of collision shall be deemed to exist __________.
option_a: whenever two vessels approach from opposite directions
option_b: if the bearing of an approaching vessel does not appreciably change
option_c: whenever a vessel crosses ahead of the intended track of another vessel
option_d: if one vessel approaches another so as to be overtaking
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer is B because Rule 7(b)(i) of the Navigation Rules states that "Such risk shall be deemed to exist if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does not appreciably change." This is the primary criterion for determining risk of collision.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A power-driven vessel exhibits  the same lights as a __________.
option_b: vessel towing astern
option_c: sailing vessel
option_d: pushing vessel and a vessel being pushed, when they are in a composite unit
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A power-driven vessel (Rule 23) exhibits the same lights as a composite unit (pushing vessel and vessel being pushed, Rule 24(b)). Both display a masthead light forward, a second masthead light abaft and higher (if > 50m), sidelights, and a sternlight. The composite unit is treated as a single power-driven vessel.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A power-driven vessel is underway in fog but stopped and making no way through the water.  What is the required fog signal?
option_a: One prolonged blast at not more than one-minute intervals
option_b: Two prolonged blasts at not more than one-minute intervals
option_c: One prolonged blast at not more than two-minute intervals
option_d: Two prolonged blasts at not more than two-minute intervals
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(b) of the Navigation Rules states a power-driven vessel underway but stopped and making no way must sound two prolonged blasts at intervals of not more than two minutes. This matches option D.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A towing light, according to the Rules, is a __________.
option_b: red light
option_c: yellow light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, yellow light (C), is defined by Rule 21(h) as a yellow light with the same characteristics as a sternlight. This definition applies to both International and Inland Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which signal shall a power-driven vessel sound when making way in fog?
option_a: One short blast every two minutes
option_b: One prolonged blast every two minutes
option_c: One prolonged and two short blasts every two minutes
option_d: Three short blasts every two minutes
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(a) of the USCG Navigation Rules states that a power-driven vessel making way through the water shall sound, at intervals of not more than 2 minutes, one prolonged blast. The correct signal is "One prolonged blast every two minutes" (Option B).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Two vessels are meeting head-on.  How must the vessels pass?
option_a: One vessel must alter course while the other must continue  on its course.
option_b: The vessels should determine which will alter course by sounding whistle signals.
option_c: Both vessels should alter course to port and pass starboard to starboard.
option_d: Both vessels should alter course to starboard and pass port to port.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 14 (Head-on situation) requires each vessel to alter course to starboard so that each will pass on the port side of the other (port to port). This is the standard procedure for power-driven vessels meeting head-on to avoid collision. (33 CFR § 83.14).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel does NOT sound a fog signal of one prolonged followed by two short blasts?
option_b: A sailing vessel
option_c: A vessel being towed
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A vessel being towed, if manned, sounds four short blasts at intervals not exceeding 2 minutes, NOT one prolonged and two short blasts. The vessels that do sound the prolonged and two short blasts are vessels restricted in their ability to maneuver (like dredging), sailing vessels, and vessels engaged in fishing. See Rule 35(e).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel 50 meters in length at anchor must sound which fog signal?
option_a: 5-second ringing of a bell every minute
option_b: 5-second ringing of a bell every two minutes
option_c: 5-second sounding of a gong every minute
option_d: 5-second sounding of both a bell and gong every two minutes
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A vessel 50 meters in length (under 100 meters) at anchor must sound rapid ringing of a bell for 5 seconds at intervals not exceeding 1 minute. This aligns with option A. See Rule 35(g) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel is NOT to be regarded as "restricted in her ability to maneuver"?
option_a: A vessel transferring provisions while underway
option_b: A pushing vessel and a vessel being pushed when connected in a composite unit
option_c: A vessel servicing a navigation mark
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: Rule 3(g) lists vessels restricted in their ability to maneuver. A composite unit (pushing vessel and vessel being pushed) is considered a power-driven vessel and not inherently restricted. Options A, C, and D are included in Rule 3(g) as examples of vessels restricted in their ability to maneuver.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement correctly applies to a situation where a sailing vessel is overtaking a power-driven vessel?
option_a: The power-driven vessel must keep out of the way of the sailing vessel.
option_b: A "special circumstance" situation exists.
option_c: The sailing vessel must keep out of the way of the power- driven vessel.
option_d: The vessel which has the other vessel to the right must keep out of the way.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, C, is based on Rule 13 (Overtaking). The rule states that any vessel overtaking any other vessel shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken. In this case, the sailing vessel is the overtaking vessel and must keep clear.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which procedure(s) shall be used to determine risk of collision?
option_a: Watching the compass bearing of an approaching vessel
option_b: Systematic observation of objects detected by radar
option_c: Long-range radar scanning
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 7 (Risk of Collision) states a vessel shall use all available means to determine risk of collision. This includes watching the compass bearing of an approaching vessel and the systematic observation of objects detected by radar, including long-range scanning. Therefore, "All of the above" is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A white masthead light shows through an arc of how many degrees?
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A masthead light is a white light that shines over an unbroken arc of the horizon of 225 degrees. This is defined in the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook, specifically Rule 21(a) (Definitions). Option C (225°) is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What is the minimum length of an anchored vessel which is required to show a white light both forward and aft?
option_b: 100 meters
option_c: 150 meters
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 30 of the USCG Navigation Rules states that a vessel at anchor of 50 meters or more in length shall exhibit an all-round white light in the fore part and another at or near the stern and at a lower level. The minimum length is 50 meters.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are at anchor in fog. The fog signal of a vessel underway has been steadily growing louder and the danger of collision appears to exist.  In addition to your fog signal, what signal may be used to indicate the presence of your vessel?
option_a: Three blasts on the whistle; one prolonged, one short, and one prolonged.
option_b: Three blasts on the whistle; one short, one prolonged, and one short.
option_c: Three blasts on the whistle; one prolonged followed by two short.
option_d: No signal other than your fog signal may be used.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(d) permits a vessel at anchor to sound one short, one prolonged, and one short blast to warn an approaching vessel of its position and the possibility of collision. This is in addition to the mandatory fog signal for a vessel at anchor.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Signals required for vessels aground include __________.
option_a: by night, the anchor lights for a vessel of her length, and three red lights in a vertical line
option_b: a short, a prolonged, and a short blast
option_c: by day, three black balls in a vertical line
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Option C is correct because Rule 30(d)(ii) of the Navigation Rules states that a vessel aground shall exhibit three black balls in a vertical line by day, in addition to the lights prescribed for a vessel at anchor. This is required in both International and Inland Waters.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which craft would be considered a "power-driven vessel" under the Rules of the Road?
option_a: An auxiliary sail vessel, using her engine
option_b: A canoe being propelled by a small outboard motor
option_c: A tug powered by a diesel engine
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: Rule 3(a) defines a "power-driven vessel" as any vessel propelled by machinery. This includes an auxiliary sail vessel using its engine (C-A), a canoe with a small outboard (C-B), and a tug powered by a diesel engine (C-C). Therefore, "All of the above" (C-D) is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND At night, power-driven vessels less than 12 meters in length may, instead of the underway  lights for vessels under 50 meters, show which lights?
option_b: One all-round white light and sidelights
option_c: Masthead light only
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is B because a power-driven vessel less than 12 meters in length may exhibit an all-round white light and sidelights instead of the standard underway lights. See Rule 23(c) in the Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel shall not impede the passage of a vessel which can only navigate inside a narrow channel?
option_a: A vessel of less than 20 meters in length
option_b: A vessel not under command
option_c: A vessel engaged in surveying
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation:
Rule 9 of the Navigation Rules (Narrow Channels) states vessels less than 20 meters in length shall not impede the passage of a vessel that can safely navigate only within a narrow channel.

Reference: Rule 9(b)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE in an overtaking situation?
option_a: An overtaking situation exists when one vessel is approaching another vessel from anywhere abaft the beam.
option_b: It is the duty of the vessel being overtaken to get out of  the way.
option_c: Any later change of bearing between the two vessels shall not make the overtaking vessel a crossing vessel.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Option C is correct because once a vessel is designated as overtaking, its duty to keep clear continues even with a change in bearing. Rule 13(d) of the COLREGS/Inland Rules states, "Any subsequent alteration of the bearing between the two vessels shall not make the overtaking vessel a crossing vessel... or relieve her of the duty of keeping clear..."

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel must exhibit a conical shape, apex downwards?
option_b: A 15-meter vessel proceeding under sail when also being propelled by machinery
option_c: A 20-meter vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel proceeding under sail when also being propelled by machinery must exhibit a conical shape, apex downwards, as per Rule 25(e) of the Navigation Rules (33 CFR § 83.25(e)). The 15-meter length of the vessel in option B exceeds the 12-meter exemption.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel must show a towing light above the stern light?
option_a: A vessel pushing three barges ahead
option_b: A vessel towing alongside
option_c: A vessel with a 150-meter tow astern
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 24(a)(vii) of the COLREGs/Inland Rules states that a power-driven vessel when towing astern, and the length of the tow exceeds 200 meters, shall exhibit three masthead lights in a vertical line, and a towing light above the sternlight. A tow of 150 meters is covered under Rule 24(a)(i), which requires two masthead lights in a vertical line, sidelights, a sternlight, and a towing light above the sternlight. This requirement applies to all vessels towing astern. See Rule 24 (Towing and pushing).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which is NOT a distress signal?
option_a: A continuous sounding with any fog signal apparatus
option_b: A signal sent by radiotelephone consisting of the spoken word "Mayday"
option_c: An International Code Signal of N.C.
option_d: The firing of green star rockets or shells
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer is D because the firing of green star rockets or shells is not listed as an approved distress signal. Red star rockets or shells are an approved signal. See Rule 37 - Distress Signals in the USCG's Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A rigid replica of the  International Code flag "A" may be shown by a vessel __________.
option_b: engaged in diving operations
option_c: engaged in underway replenishment
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in diving operations is restricted in its ability to maneuver and is required to show a rigid replica of the International Code flag “A”. This is found in the Navigation Rules, specifically Rule 27(e)(ii) (33 CFR § 83.27(e)(ii)).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In a crossing situation, which  vessel may sound the danger signal?
option_b: Stand-on vessel
option_c: Either vessel
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The danger signal (5 short blasts) may be sounded by either vessel if in doubt as to the other's actions or sufficiency of action to avoid collision. This is covered in Rule 34(d) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Every vessel should at all times proceed at a "safe speed".  "Safe speed" is defined as that speed where __________.
option_a: you can stop within your visibility range
option_b: you can take proper and effective action to avoid collision
option_c: you are traveling slower than surrounding vessels
option_d: no wake comes from your vessel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 6 (Safe Speed) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook states that every vessel must proceed at a safe speed so that she can take proper and effective action to avoid collision and be stopped within a distance appropriate to the prevailing circumstances and conditions.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are underway in fog and you hear three distinct bell strokes followed by five seconds of rapid bell ringing followed by three distinct bell strokes. This signal indicates a vessel __________.
option_b: engaged in underwater construction
option_c: at anchor
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: This sound signal indicates a vessel aground. Rule 35(i) of the Navigation Rules states a vessel aground shall sound the bell signal for a vessel at anchor (rapid ringing for 5 seconds) immediately before and after three separate and distinct bell strokes.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In a crossing situation, a stand-on vessel which is forced to take action in order to avoid collision with a vessel on her own port side shall, if possible, avoid __________.
option_b: turning to starboard
option_c: decreasing speed
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The stand-on vessel should avoid turning to port when the give-way vessel is on its port side because a turn to port will generally cross ahead of the give-way vessel. This is outlined in Rule 17(c) which states a stand-on vessel shall not turn to port for a vessel on her own port side.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel is "underway" within the meaning of the Rules?
option_a: A vessel at anchor with the engine turning
option_b: A vessel tied to an offshore mooring buoy
option_c: A vessel aground with the engine turning
option_d: A vessel drifting with the engine stopped
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: A vessel is "underway" when it is not at anchor, aground, or made fast to the shore. Drifting, even with the engine stopped, meets this definition, making option D correct. See Rule 3(i) (General definitions) of the Navigation Rules for more details.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What is the required fog signal for a manned vessel being towed at night?
option_a: One prolonged followed by one short blast
option_b: One prolonged followed by three short blasts
option_c: One prolonged followed by two short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(e) of the USCG Navigation Rules states that a manned vessel being towed (or the last vessel if more than one) shall sound four blasts in succession: one prolonged followed by three short blasts. This corresponds to Option B.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND If you anchor your 25-meter vessel in a harbor, what light(s) must you show?
option_b: Two all-round white lights
option_c: One all-round red light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: For a vessel less than 50 meters in length (25m), Rule 30 of the Navigation Rules states that a vessel at anchor shall exhibit where it can best be seen: an all-round white light in the fore part. Option A is "One all-round white light."

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Three short blasts of the whistle means __________.
option_b: "I am in distress"
option_c: the vessel is not under command (broken down)
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Three short blasts signify "I am operating astern propulsion," as per Rule 34(a)(ii) in the USCG Navigation Rules. This signal is used to alert other vessels of a change in direction due to reverse movement.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Of the vessels listed, which must keep out of the way of all the others?
option_b: A vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
option_c: A vessel not under command
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: A sailing vessel is the least privileged of the listed vessels and must keep out of the way of a vessel not under command, a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver, and a vessel engaged in fishing. This is according to Rule 18 (b) of the Navigation Rules (33 CFR § 83.18).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND During the day, a vessel with a tow over 200 meters in length will show __________.
option_b: a diamond shape
option_c: two cones, apexes together
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, a diamond shape, is required when the length of the tow exceeds 200 meters. This is mandated by Rule 24(a)(v) of the Navigation Rules, which specifies that a vessel with a tow over 200 meters in length must show a diamond shape where it can best be seen.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A fog signal of one prolonged blast followed by four short blasts would mean the presence of a __________.
option_b: fishing vessel trawling
option_c: vessel at anchor warning of her location
option_d: power-driven pilot vessel on station underway
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A fog signal of one prolonged blast followed by four short blasts is the identity signal for a power-driven pilot vessel when engaged on pilotage duty, as described in Rule 35(j) or (k) of the USCG Navigation Rules, Inland and International. This signal is in addition to the regular fog signals.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel not under command, underway but not making way, would show __________.
option_a: two all-round red lights in a vertical line
option_b: sidelights
option_c: a stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 27 of the Navigation Rules states that a vessel not under command must show two all-round red lights in a vertical line where they can best be seen. Therefore, option A, "two all-round red lights in a vertical line," is the correct light signal.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Traffic separation schemes __________.
option_a: provide routing and scheduling procedures to reduce shipping delays
option_b: provide traffic patterns in congested areas, so that vessels can operate without having a separate lookout
option_c: provide inbound and outbound lanes to promote the safe flow of vessel traffic
option_d: prohibit vessels carrying hazardous cargoes from entering waters that are environmentally sensitive
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Traffic separation schemes (TSS) are designed under Rule 10 to manage vessel traffic flow. The lanes within a TSS provide designated inbound and outbound paths for safe navigation. This aligns with option C. See Rule 10 (Traffic Separation Schemes).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which lights shall a 200-meter  vessel exhibit when at anchor?
option_a: In the forepart of the vessel, a 225-degree white light
option_b: In the after part of the vessel, a 112.5-degree white light
option_c: Working lights to illuminate the decks
option_d: In the forepart of the vessel, a 112.5-degree white light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: For a vessel over 100m at anchor, Rule 30(b) requires, in addition to the mandatory all-round white lights, the use of available working or equivalent lights to illuminate the decks. This is why "Working lights to illuminate the decks" is correct. (Rule 30, Anchor Lights)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  Under the Rules, the term "vessel" includes __________.
option_b: seaplanes
option_c: hovercrafts
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: The correct answer is D, "All of the above," because the definition of "vessel" in Rule 3(a) includes every description of watercraft used or capable of being used as a means of transportation on water, including non-self-propelled rafts, seaplanes, and hovercrafts (non-displacement craft). See Rule 3(a).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You see a vessel displaying three lights in a vertical line.  The highest and lowest lights are red and the middle light is white.  She is also  showing a white light at the stern, which is lower than the forward light.  It could be a __________.
option_b: vessel not under command
option_c: vessel aground
option_d: pilot vessel with port side to you
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The lights shown (Red-White-Red in a vertical line) are day shapes/lights for a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver (Rule 27(b)(i)). The stern light indicates she is making way. A survey vessel (engaged in dredging/underwater ops) is an example of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver. Reference: Rule 27(d) for R-W-R and Rule 23(a) for the stern light.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A pilot vessel may continue to  sound an identity signal in fog if she is __________.
option_b: at anchor
option_c: not under command
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The identity signal is sounded when the pilot vessel is engaged on pilotage duty. If she is "at anchor" (Option B), she is required to sound the anchor signal (Rule 35(g)), and she may sound the identity signal (four short blasts) in addition, if still on duty (Rule 35(k)).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are in charge of a stand-on vessel in a crossing situation.  The other vessel is 1.5 miles to port.  You believe that risk of collision exists.  You should __________.
option_a: take avoiding action immediately upon determining that risk of collision exists
option_b: immediately sound the danger signal, and change course
option_c: take avoiding action only after giving the give-way vessel  time to take action, and determining that her action is not appropriate
option_d: hold course and speed until the point of extremis, and then sound the danger signal, taking whatever action will best avoid collision
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The stand-on vessel should hold course and speed initially, but when it becomes apparent the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action, the stand-on vessel "may take action." This is covered by Rule 17(a)(ii). The stand-on vessel "shall take such action as will best aid to avoid collision" if collision cannot be avoided by the give-way vessel's action alone (Rule 17(b)). The correct action, as per Rule 17, is to give the other vessel time to act first.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel towing astern  in an operation which severely restricts the towing vessel  and her tow in their ability to deviate from their course shall, when making way, show __________.
option_a: the masthead lights for a towing vessel
option_b: the lights for a vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver
option_c: sidelights, stern light and towing light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: This vessel must display the lights for a vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver (Rule 27(c)), which includes two all-round red lights. Additionally, it must show the masthead lights, sidelights, stern light, and towing light as prescribed for a towing vessel (Rule 24(a)). Therefore, "All of the above" is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning seaplanes on the water?
option_a: A seaplane must exhibit appropriate lights but need not exhibit shapes.
option_b: A seaplane should show the lights for a vessel constrained  by her draft.
option_c: In situations where a risk of collision exists, a seaplane  should always give way.
option_d: A seaplane on the water shall, in general, keep well clear  of all vessels.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 31 of the Navigation Rules states that a seaplane on the water shall, in general, keep well clear of all vessels and avoid impeding their navigation. Options A, B, and C are incorrect based on the rules for lights, shapes, and responsibility between vessels and seaplanes. Rule 31 (33 CFR § 83.31) contains the answer.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A head-on situation at night is one in which you see dead ahead a vessel showing __________.
option_b: one sidelight and a masthead light
option_c: one sidelight and two masthead lights
option_d: both sidelights of a vessel and her masthead light(s)
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 23 (Power-driven vessels underway) and Rule 24 (Towing and pushing) detail the required lights. Rule 21 (Definitions) specifies the location and arc of visibility for sidelights and masthead lights. Rule 14 (Head-on situation) describes the required action when you see the lights specified in option D dead ahead.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In a crossing situation, the stand-on vessel should normally __________.
option_a: take action to cross ahead of the other vessel
option_b: take action to pass astern of the other vessel
option_c: maintain course and speed
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The stand-on vessel must maintain its course and speed to make its intentions clear and allow the give-way vessel to take avoiding action. This is the normal action for the stand-on vessel in a crossing situation. See Rule 17(a)(i) in the USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A self-propelled dredge not engaged in dredging but proceeding to a dredging location at night would __________.
option_a: not be required to show any lights
option_b: be required to show the lights characteristic of a dredge
option_c: be required to show the lights of a stationary dredge
option_d: be required to show the lights of a power-driven vessel underway
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A self-propelled dredge proceeding to a location is considered a power-driven vessel underway because it is not actively dredging. Therefore, it must show the lights of a power-driven vessel underway. See Rule 23.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND At night you sight a vessel displaying one green light.  This light could indicate a __________.
option_b: vessel at anchor
option_c: small motorboat underway
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A single green light indicates the starboard sidelight of a vessel. When only a single sidelight (red or green) is visible, it is likely the only light displayed by a sailboat underway, seen from the opposite side. See Rule 25 (Sailing vessels underway).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND There is a provision to depart  from the Rules, if necessary, to avoid __________.
option_b: an overtaking situation
option_c: immediate danger
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: Rule 2 (b) of the COLREGS permits departure from the Rules only to avoid immediate danger, including any special circumstances or limitations of the vessels involved. The correct answer, immediate danger, is option C.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Risk of collision exists when an approaching vessel has a(n) __________.
option_a: generally steady bearing and decreasing range
option_b: generally steady range and increasing bearing
option_c: increasing range and bearing
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: A generally steady bearing and decreasing range indicates a constant bearing decreasing range (CBDR) situation, which means the vessels are on a collision course. This is defined in Rule 7, Risk of Collision.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What signal indicates doubt that sufficient action is being taken by another vessel to avoid collision?
option_a: Five short and rapid blasts of the whistle
option_b: Three long blasts of the whistle
option_c: Three short and rapid blasts of the whistle
option_d: One prolonged blast followed by three short blasts of the whistle
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Five short and rapid blasts of the whistle indicate doubt that sufficient action is being taken by another vessel to avoid collision, as stated in Rule 34(d) of the Navigation Rules (International and Inland). This signal is used to communicate danger or doubt about the other vessel's intentions.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A power-driven vessel towing another vessel astern (tow less than 200 meters) shall show __________.
option_a: a small white light abaft the funnel
option_b: three masthead lights in a vertical line instead of either  the forward or after masthead lights
option_c: two masthead lights in a vertical line instead of either the forward or after masthead lights
option_d: two towing lights in a vertical line at the stern
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 24 states a power-driven vessel towing astern (tow less than 200m) shall exhibit, instead of the standard masthead light(s), two masthead lights in a vertical line. (33 CFR § 83.24)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway in fog, you hear the rapid ringing of a bell for about five seconds followed by the sounding of a gong for about five seconds.  This signal came from a __________.
option_a: vessel engaged in fishing at anchor
option_b: sailing vessel at anchor
option_c: vessel 150 meters in length at anchor
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The signal of a bell rapidly rung for five seconds followed by a gong rapidly sounded for five seconds is required by Rule 35(g) for a vessel at anchor 100 meters or more in length. Option C, a vessel 150 meters in length at anchor, is the only choice that fits this requirement.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are underway in a narrow channel and you are being overtaken by a vessel astern.  The overtaking vessel sounds a signal indicating his intention  to pass your vessel on your starboard side.  If such an action appears dangerous you should sound __________.
option_b: three short and rapid blasts
option_c: one prolonged followed by one short blast
option_d: one prolonged, one short, one prolonged, and one short blast in that order
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "five short and rapid blasts," is the danger signal used to indicate that the proposed maneuver is dangerous or that the intentions of the other vessel are not understood. This is found in Rule 34(d) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver shall __________.
option_a: turn off her sidelights when not making way
option_b: when operating in restricted visibility, sound a whistle signal of two prolonged and one short blast
option_c: show a day-shape of two diamonds in a vertical line
option_d: keep out of the way of a vessel engaged in fishing
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The answer 'A' is correct because Rule 27 details the lights a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver must exhibit. While underway, she shows masthead lights, sidelights, and sternlights, but when not making way, Rule 27 provisions dictate specific light usage, which includes turning off sidelights.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A power-driven vessel at anchor, not fishing or otherwise restricted in its ability to maneuver, sounds her fog signal at intervals of not __________.
option_b: more than two minutes
option_c: more than three minutes
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(e) of the USCG Navigation Rules states a vessel at anchor shall ring the bell rapidly for about 5 seconds at intervals of not more than one minute. Option A, "more than one minute," completes the sentence to mean "not more than one minute," which is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are underway in reduced visibility.  You hear the fog signal of another vessel about 20° on your starboard bow.  Risk of collision may exist.  You should __________.
option_a: alter course to starboard to pass around the other vessel
option_b: reduce your speed to bare steerageway
option_c: slow your engines and let the other vessel pass ahead of you
option_d: alter course to port to pass the other vessel on its portside
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct action is to reduce speed to bare steerageway. Rule 19(e) of the COLREGS (33 CFR § 83.19(e)) states that a vessel hearing a fog signal forward of the beam must reduce speed to the minimum necessary to maintain course or take all way off.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What day-shape would a vessel at anchor show during daylight?
option_b: Two black balls
option_c: Three black balls
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is A, "One black ball," because a vessel at anchor must exhibit one ball where it can best be seen. This is specified in Rule 30(a)(i) of the USCG's Navigation Rules and Regulations (COLREGs), which applies internationally and inland.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are approaching a bend in a channel.  You cannot see around the bend because of the height of the bank.  You should __________.
option_a: stop engines and navigate with caution
option_b: stay in the middle of the channel
option_c: sound passing signals to any other vessel that may be on the other side of the bend
option_d: sound a whistle blast of 4 to 6 seconds duration
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(e) requires a prolonged blast (4-6 seconds) when approaching a bend or area where other vessels may be obscured. This is a warning signal to alert unseen traffic. See Rule 34(e).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning a vessel of 150 meters in length, at anchor?
option_a: She may show an all-round white light where it can best be  seen.
option_b: She must show all-round white lights forward and aft.
option_c: The showing of working lights is optional.
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel 150 meters in length at anchor must exhibit an all-round white light forward and another all-round white light at or near the stern and at a lower level. This is required by Rule 30 (a) (i) and (ii) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel would be required  to show a white light from a lantern exhibited in sufficient time to prevent collision?
option_b: A rowboat
option_c: A 6-meter motorboat
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A rowboat, as a vessel under oars, must have a white light (torch or lantern) ready to exhibit in sufficient time to prevent collision, per COLREG Rule 25(e). A 9-meter sailing vessel (A) and a 6-meter motorboat (C) have fixed lighting requirements. A small vessel fishing (D) has fishing light requirements. The relevant rule is found in the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook, Rule 25.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Barges being towed at night __________.
option_a: must be lighted at all times
option_b: must be lighted only if manned
option_c: must be lighted only if towed astern
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "must be lighted at all times," is mandated by Rule 24(e) of the COLREGs (International) and Rule 24(g) of the Inland Rules (33 CFR 83.24), which generally require barges/vessels being towed (if not part of a composite unit) to exhibit navigation lights. Unmanned or un-manned barges must always exhibit the required lights when being towed at night.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You sight another power-driven vessel dead-ahead showing both the red and green sidelights.   The required action to take would be to __________.
option_b: start a radar plot in order to ascertain his course
option_c: alter your course to port
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The situation described is a head-on situation, indicated by seeing both sidelights. According to Rule 14 of the Navigation Rules (COLREGS and Inland), when two power-driven vessels are meeting on reciprocal or nearly reciprocal courses so as to involve risk of collision, each shall alter her course to starboard so that each shall pass on the port side of the other. The required action is to alter your course to starboard.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are underway in fog and hear one short, one prolonged, and one short blast in succession.  What is the meaning of this signal?
option_a: A vessel is in distress and needs assistance.
option_b: A vessel is fishing, hauling nets.
option_c: A vessel is at anchor, warning of her position.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The signal (one short, one prolonged, and one short blast) is an optional supplemental warning that a vessel at anchor may sound to alert approaching vessels of its position in restricted visibility. This is described in Rule 35(g) of the COLREGs (International) and Inland Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND An anchored vessel on pilotage duty must show which light(s) at night?
option_b: Anchor lights only
option_c: A white light over a red light only
option_d: A white light over a red light and anchor lights
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 30(a) and Rule 29(a)(i) apply. An anchored vessel (Rule 30(a)) must show anchor lights, and a vessel engaged in pilotage duty (Rule 29(a)(i)) must show the white over red lights. The combination is correct for this situation.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel which is fishing is required to show sidelights and a stern light only when __________.
option_b: underway
option_c: dead in the water
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in fishing must show sidelights and a sternlight when making way through the water (underway and making way). This is covered under Rule 26 of the Navigation Rules (COLREGs/Inland).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What is a requirement for any action taken to avoid collision?
option_a: When in sight of another vessel, any action taken must be accompanied by sound signals.
option_b: The action taken must include changing the speed of the vessel.
option_c: The action must be positive and made in ample time.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The action must be positive and made in ample time to be effective, ensuring a vessel passes at a safe distance. Small, incremental changes should be avoided. This requirement is found in Rule 8, "Action to Avoid Collision," of the USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook (COLREGS).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In the daytime, you see a large sailing vessel on the beam.  You know that she is also propelled by machinery if she shows __________.
option_b: a black ball
option_c: a black cone
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 25(e) of the USCG Navigation Rules states that a sailing vessel also using propulsion machinery shall exhibit forward where it can best be seen a conical shape, apex downwards (a black cone).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Your power-driven vessel is stopped and making no way, but is not in any way disabled. Another vessel is approaching you on your starboard beam.  Which statement is TRUE?
option_a: The other vessel must give way since your vessel is stopped.
option_b: Your vessel is the give-way vessel in a crossing situation.
option_c: You should be showing the lights or shapes for a vessel not under command.
option_d: You should be showing the lights or shapes for a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Since your power-driven vessel has another power-driven vessel on its starboard side, it is the give-way vessel in a crossing situation, regardless of whether you are stopped or making way, provided you are not disabled. (Rule 15, Crossing Situation)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND For identification purposes at  night, U.S. Navy submarines on the surface may display an intermittent flashing light of which color?
option_b: White
option_c: Blue
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is Amber (yellow) because U.S. Navy submarines on the surface at night for identification purposes display an intermittent flashing amber (yellow) light. This is detailed in 32 CFR Subpart B, Section 707.7 (Submarine Identification Light).

question_text: INLAND ONLY  Vessels engaged in fishing may  show the additional signals described in Annex II to the Rules when they are __________.
option_b: fishing in a traffic separation zone
option_c: in a narrow channel
option_d: in close proximity to other vessels engaged in fishing
question_category: Annexes
answer_explanation: Annex II, which describes the additional signals for fishing vessels, is specifically titled "Additional Signals for Fishing Vessels Fishing in Close Proximity" and is referenced in Rule 26(f) of the Inland Rules. Therefore, vessels can use these signals when they are in close proximity to other vessels engaged in fishing.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel must show a masthead light abaft of and higher than her identifying lights?
option_b: A  55-meter vessel trawling
option_c: A 100-meter vessel not under command
option_d: A  20-meter vessel engaged on pilotage duty
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in trawling must exhibit an additional masthead light abaft of and higher than the identifying lights (red over white). This requirement is found in Rule 26 (b)(iii) of the COLREGs (Navigation Rules).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway in a narrow channel, a vessel should stay __________.
option_a: in the middle of the channel
option_b: to the starboard side of the channel
option_c: to the port side of the channel
option_d: to the side of the channel that has the widest bends
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: A vessel must keep as near to the outer limit of the narrow channel or fairway which lies on her starboard side as is safe and practicable. This is required by Rule 9 (Narrow Channels) of the Navigation Rules (COLREGs), which applies to both International and Inland waters.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Vessels of less than what length may not impede the passage of other vessels which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or fairway?
option_b: 20 meters
option_c: 30 meters
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer is 20 meters (Option B). Rule 9(b) states that a vessel of less than 20 meters in length shall not impede the passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or fairway.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A lantern combining the sidelights and stern light MAY be shown on a __________.
option_a: sailing vessel of 25 meters in length
option_b: 20-meter vessel engaged in fishing and making way
option_c: 25-meter power-driven vessel engaged in trolling
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel under oars may exhibit the lights prescribed for sailing vessels, or have a white light ready. A sailing vessel of less than 20 meters may combine sidelights and stern light in one lantern. The 6-meter vessel is the only appropriate choice. (Rule 25(a) and (b), Rule 25(c)(ii))

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The lights required by the Rules must be shown __________.
option_a: from sunrise to sunset in restricted visibility
option_b: at all times
option_c: ONLY from sunset to sunrise
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 20 (Application) mandates that lights must be shown from sunset to sunrise, and during restricted visibility. While option A only mentions restricted visibility during the day, lights are required whenever restricted visibility occurs, regardless of time. A full description of the light requirements is found in Rule 20, but the requirement for restricted visibility is covered.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel may carry her sidelights and stern light in a combined lantern on the mast?
option_b: A 10-meter sailing vessel also being propelled by machinery
option_c: A 25-meter sailing vessel
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 25(b) of the USCG Navigation Rules states that a sailing vessel less than 20 meters in length may combine sidelights and a stern light in one lantern near the top of the mast. An 18-meter vessel falls under this length requirement.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel nearing a bend or an area of a channel or fairway where other vessels may be hidden by an obstruction shall __________.
option_b: sound a prolonged blast
option_c: take all way off
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Option B, sound a prolonged blast, is correct because a prolonged blast is used as a warning signal when approaching a bend or obstruction that hides other vessels. This is required by Rule 34(e) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook (Inland and International).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are approaching a vessel dredging during the day and see two balls in a vertical line on the port side of the dredge.  These shapes mean that __________.
option_a: you should pass on the port side of the dredge
option_b: there is an obstruction on the port side of the dredge
option_c: the dredge is not under command
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, B, is found in Rule 27(d)(i). A vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver (like a dredge) exhibiting two balls in a vertical line on one side indicates that an obstruction exists on that side, making passage unsafe. The two balls are on the port side, meaning the obstruction is on the port side.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning the light used to accompany whistle signals?
option_a: It is mandatory to use such a light.
option_b: The light shall have the same characteristics as a masthead light.
option_c: It is used to supplement short blasts of the whistle.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
