answer_explanation: The correct answer, C, is based on Rule 34(b) of the Navigation Rules (Inland and International). This rule states that a light may be used to supplement short blasts of the whistle during maneuvering and warning signals. The light is a single flashing white light, used in conjunction with the sound signals.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel must sound her fog signal at intervals not to exceed one minute?
option_a: A power-driven vessel underway, not making way
option_b: A vessel constrained by her draft
option_c: A vessel engaged in fishing, at anchor
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A vessel aground must sound a fog signal at intervals not to exceed one minute (rapid ringing of the bell for about 5 seconds before and after the prescribed signal for a vessel at anchor). This is found in Rule 35(g) of the Navigation Rules (33 CFR § 83.35(g)).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND By day, you sight a vessel displaying three shapes in a vertical line.  The top and bottom shapes are balls, and the middle shape is a diamond. It could be a __________.
option_b: mineclearing vessel
option_c: trawler
option_d: vessel engaged in replenishment at sea
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in replenishment at sea is a vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver. Rule 27(b)(ii) states that such a vessel shall exhibit three shapes in a vertical line: a ball, a diamond, and a ball. Therefore, the vessel is engaged in replenishment at sea.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are heading due east (090°) and observe a vessel's red sidelight on your port beam.  The vessel may be heading __________.
option_b: north (000°)
option_c: southeast (135°)
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The red sidelight is on the vessel's port side and is seen on your port beam (000° relative). The sidelight shines from ahead to 22.5° abaft the beam (Rule 21). If the vessel is heading southwest (225°), its port (red) side is facing you, and you are within the 112.5° arc of visibility on its port side. (Rule 21 (b))

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel is, by definition, unable to keep out of the way of another vessel?
option_b: Vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
option_c: Sailing vessel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation:
A "Vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver" is defined as a vessel unable to keep out of the way of another vessel due to the nature of her work. Rule 3(g) of the Navigation Rules defines this term.
Reference: Rule 3(g).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel must exhibit forward and after masthead lights when underway?
option_b: A  50-meter power-driven vessel
option_c: A 100-meter vessel engaged in fishing
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is B because COLREGs Rule 23 (a)(ii) requires a power-driven vessel of 50 meters or more in length to exhibit a second masthead light abaft of and higher than the forward one. Vessels less than 50m are not obliged to, but may.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND As defined in the Rules, a towing light is a yellow light having the same characteristics as a(n) __________.
option_b: all-round light
option_c: sidelight
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The answer is correct based on Rule 21(d) of the Navigation Rules (Lights). A towing light is defined as a yellow light having the same characteristics as a stern light, which is an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 135° fixed to show 67.5° from right aft on each side.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel underway and making way in fog shall sound every two minutes __________.
option_b: two prolonged blasts
option_c: one prolonged blast and three short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Option A is correct because Rule 35(a) (COLREGS/Inland Rule 35(a)) states that a power-driven vessel making way through the water in restricted visibility shall sound one prolonged blast at intervals of not more than 2 minutes.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND When anchoring a 20-meter vessel at night, you must show __________.
option_b: two all-round white lights
option_c: one all-round white light and the stern light
option_d: one all-round white light and a flare up light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel less than 50 meters (20 meters in this case) at anchor may exhibit one all-round white light where it can best be seen. This is per Rule 30(b) of the COLREGs (International) or 33 CFR 83.30(b) (Inland Rules), addressing lights for anchored vessels.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND According to the Navigation Rules, all of the following are engaged in fishing EXCEPT a vessel __________.
option_b: trawling
option_c: using a dredge net
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Trolling does not restrict maneuverability and is therefore not considered "engaged in fishing" under the rules, which define a fishing vessel as one using gear that restricts maneuverability. See Rule 3(d).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND When a vessel sounds three short blasts on the whistle, this indicates that __________.
option_b: her engines are going astern
option_c: the vessel is not under command (broken down)
option_d: all other vessels should stand clear
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, B, is explained by Rule 34(a)(iii). Three short blasts indicate that the vessel is operating its engines astern. This is a maneuvering and warning signal applicable internationally and in inland waters.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel is overtaking when she approaches another from more than how many degrees abaft the beam?
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 13 (Overtaking) of the Navigation Rules states that a vessel is overtaking when approaching from a direction more than 22.5° (two points) abaft the beam of the vessel being overtaken. This angle is where the overtaking vessel can only see the stern light of the vessel ahead at night.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What equipment for fog signals  is required for a vessel 20 meters in length?
option_b: Bell only
option_c: Whistle and bell only
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A vessel 20 meters in length must carry a whistle and a bell. Rule 33 of the USCG’s Navigation Rules requires a vessel 12m or more to have a whistle, and a vessel 20m or more to also have a bell. Therefore, "Whistle and bell only" is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Sailing vessels are stand-on over power-driven vessels except __________.
option_b: in a meeting situation
option_c: when they are the overtaking vessel
option_d: on the inland waters of the U.S.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 13 (Overtaking) states that any vessel overtaking another must keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken. This duty applies regardless of the type of vessels, making the sailing vessel the give-way vessel when overtaking.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning risk of collision?
option_a: Risk of collision never exists if the compass bearing of the other vessel is changing.
option_b: Proper use shall be made of radar equipment to determine risk of collision.
option_c: Risk of collision must be determined before any action can  be taken by a vessel.
option_d: Risk of collision exists if the vessels will pass within half a mile of each other.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 7 (b) of the COLREGs (International and Inland Rules) states that proper use shall be made of radar equipment, if fitted and operational, to determine risk of collision. This includes long-range scanning and systematic observation.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are fishing at night, and you sight a vessel showing three lights in a vertical line. The upper and lower lights are red and the middle light is  white.  Which statement is TRUE?
option_a: You must keep out of the way of the other vessel.
option_b: The other vessel is responsible to keep out of your way.
option_c: The other vessel is at anchor.
option_d: The rule of special circumstances applies.
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The red-white-red vertical lights indicate a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver (Rule 27). As a fishing vessel, you are required by Rule 18(c)(ii) to keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver. Therefore, you must keep out of the way of the other vessel.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel is to sound a fog  signal of one prolonged followed by two short blasts?
option_b: A sailing vessel, underway
option_c: A vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver when carrying out her work at anchor
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(c) states vessels not under command, restricted in ability to maneuver, or sailing vessels (underway) shall sound one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts. Therefore, All of the above (D) is correct. See Rule 35(c) of the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel may exhibit lights other than those prescribed by the Rules as long as the additional lights __________.
option_a: do not interfere with the keeping of a proper look-out
option_b: are not the color of either sidelight
option_c: have a lesser range than the prescribed lights
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 20(e) addresses this: "A vessel may exhibit lights other than those prescribed by these Rules as long as they do not impair the visibility or distinctive character of the prescribed lights or interfere with the keeping of a proper look-out." Option A, "do not interfere with the keeping of a proper look-out," is the correct choice.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning a partly submerged vessel being towed?
option_a: It must show a yellow light at each end.
option_b: It will show red lights along its length.
option_c: A diamond shape will be carried at the aftermost extremity  of the tow.
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A diamond shape is carried at the aftermost extremity of an inconspicuous, partly submerged vessel or object being towed. See Rule 24(e)(iii) (International) and Rule 24(e)(ii) (Inland) regarding shapes for vessels/objects being towed, and Rule 24 for towing shapes in general.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Your vessel enters fog.  You stop your engines, and the vessel is dead in the water. Which fog signal should you sound?
option_a: One prolonged blast every two minutes
option_b: Two prolonged blasts every two minutes
option_c: Three short blasts every two minutes
option_d: One prolonged and two short blasts every two minutes
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(b) (Restricted Visibility) states that a power-driven vessel underway but stopped and making no way through the water shall sound at intervals of not more than two minutes two prolonged blasts in succession with an interval of about two seconds between them.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The term "power-driven vessel"  refers to any vessel __________.
option_a: with propelling machinery onboard whether in use or not
option_b: making way against the current
option_c: with propelling machinery in use
option_d: traveling at a speed greater than that of the current
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: Rule 3(b) states that a "power-driven vessel" means any vessel propelled by machinery. This definition does not require the machinery to be in use, making option C technically incorrect under the international and inland rules. Option A, "with propelling machinery onboard whether in use or not," is often considered the correct interpretation of the rule in practice, as a vessel remains "propelled by machinery" as long as it has the ability to use its engine.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  In which situation do the Rules require both vessels to change course?
option_b: Two power-driven vessels crossing when it is apparent to the stand-on vessel that the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action
option_c: Two sailing vessels crossing with the wind on the same side
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 14 (Head-on Situation) states that when two power-driven vessels are meeting on reciprocal or nearly reciprocal courses, both vessels must alter course to starboard so that each shall pass on the port side of the other. This requires both vessels to change course.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel towing where the tow prevents her from changing course shall carry __________.
option_a: only the lights for a vessel towing
option_b: only the lights for a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
option_c: the lights for a towing vessel and the lights for a vessel  restricted in her ability to maneuver
option_d: the lights for a towing vessel and the lights for a vessel  not under command
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel towing that is restricted in her ability to change course must show the lights for both a towing vessel and a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver. This is according to Rule 24 and Rule 27(c).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning the danger signal?
option_a: May be sounded by the stand-on vessel only
option_b: Indicates that the vessel is in distress
option_c: Is used to indicate a course change
option_d: May be supplemented by an appropriate light signal
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The danger signal (five short and rapid blasts) is used when a vessel doubts the intent of another vessel's action or if a close-quarters situation is developing. Rule 34(d) states this sound signal "may be supplemented by a light signal of at least five short and rapid flashes." (33 CFR § 83.34)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND If a sailing vessel with the wind on the port side sees a sailing vessel to windward and cannot tell whether the other vessel has the wind on the port or starboard side, she shall __________.
option_b: sound the danger signal
option_c: keep out of the way of the other vessel
option_d: turn to port and come into the wind
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 12(a)(iii) states that if a vessel with the wind on the port side sees another to windward and can't determine the other's wind side, the vessel with the wind on the port side shall keep out of the way. (300 character limit: The answer is correct because Rule 12(a)(iii) states that a sailing vessel with the wind on the port side that sees another sailing vessel to windward and cannot determine which side the other vessel has the wind on, shall keep out of the way. This is found in Rule 12 (Sailing Vessels).)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Vessel "A" is on course 000°T.  Vessel "B" is on a course such that she is involved in a head-on situation and is bearing 355°T, 2 miles away from vessel "A".  To ensure a safe passing, vessel "A" should __________.
option_b: alter course to port
option_c: alter course to ensure a starboard to starboard passing
option_d: maneuver to ensure a port to port passing
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Vessel A is in a head-on situation with Vessel B. COLREGs Rule 14 mandates that when two power-driven vessels are meeting on reciprocal or nearly reciprocal courses so as to involve risk of collision, each shall alter her course to starboard so that each shall pass on the port side of the other (port-to-port).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What is a vessel "restricted in her ability to maneuver"?
option_b: A vessel constrained by her draft
option_c: A vessel underway in fog
option_d: A vessel towing unable to deviate from her course
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver is one whose work, such as a towing operation severely restricting deviation from course (Option D), prevents compliance with the Rules. This is defined in Rule 3(g) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook (COLREGs/Inland).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND All of the following are distress signals under the Rules EXCEPT __________.
option_b: orange-colored smoke
option_c: red flares
option_d: the repeated raising and lowering of outstretched arms
question_category: Annexes
answer_explanation: A green star signal is not listed as a distress signal in Rule 37 (Distress Signals) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations. The recognized signals include red flares, orange-colored smoke, and the repeated raising and lowering of outstretched arms.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The Rules state that vessels may depart from the Rules when __________.
option_a: there are no other vessels around
option_b: operating in a narrow channel
option_c: the Master enters it in the ship's log
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: Rule 2(b) of the Navigation Rules states that a departure from the Rules may be necessary to avoid immediate danger. Therefore, 'necessary to avoid immediate danger' (D) is the correct answer.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel is towing and carrying the required lights on the masthead.  What is the visibility arc of these lights?
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A masthead light is defined as showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 225 degrees, fixed to show the light from right ahead to 22.5 degrees abaft the beam on either side of the vessel. This characteristic is the same regardless of whether the vessel is towing or underway. (Rule 21(a))

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which situation would be a "special circumstance" under the Rules?
option_b: More than two vessels meeting
option_c: Speed in fog
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: "More than two vessels meeting" is a situation not specifically covered by the Steering and Sailing Rules (Rules 4-19), making it a special circumstance where Rule 2 (Responsibility) applies, allowing a necessary departure from the Rules to avoid immediate danger.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are approaching another vessel on crossing courses.  She is approximately half a mile distant and is presently on your starboard bow.  You believe she will cross ahead of you.  She then sounds a whistle signal of five short blasts.  You should __________.
option_a: answer the signal and hold course and speed
option_b: reduce speed slightly to make sure she will have room to pass
option_c: make a large course change, accompanied by the appropriate  whistle signal, and slow down if necessary
option_d: wait for another whistle signal from the other vessel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Five short blasts is the danger/doubt signal (Rule 34(d)). Since the other vessel is expressing doubt about your intentions in a crossing situation, you must take immediate avoiding action, which requires a substantial course change and/or slowing down, as indicated in C. The general prudential considerations of Rule 2 apply.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  You are approaching another vessel and are not sure whether danger of collision exists. You must assume __________.
option_b: you are the give way vessel
option_c: the other vessel is also in doubt
option_d: All of the above are correct.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 7(a) (33 CFR § 83.07) states that if there is any doubt regarding danger of collision, such risk shall be deemed to exist. Therefore, you must assume "there is risk of collision," which is option A.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel may use the danger signal?
option_a: The vessel to starboard when two power-driven vessels are crossing
option_b: A vessel engaged in fishing, crossing the course of a sailing vessel
option_c: Either of two power-driven vessels meeting head-on
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The danger signal (5 short, rapid blasts) is used when a vessel doubts if sufficient action is being taken by the other vessel to avoid collision. This applies to all three scenarios presented as they are all potential collision situations. See Rule 34(d).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What is the minimum sound signaling equipment required aboard a vessel 10 meters in length?
option_b: A whistle only
option_c: A bell and a whistle
option_d: Any means of making an efficient sound signal
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 33(b) states a vessel under 12 meters in length (like this 10-meter vessel) is not required to carry a bell and whistle, but must have "some other means of making an efficient sound signal." Therefore, "Any means of making an efficient sound signal" is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE regarding equipment for sound signals?
option_a: A vessel of less than 12 meters in length need not have any sound signaling equipment.
option_b: Any vessel over 12 meters in length must be provided with a gong.
option_c: Manual sounding of the bell and gong must always be possible.
option_d: Automatic sounding of the signals is not permitted.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Option C is correct because the rules require manual operation of the bell and gong to be possible, even if a power-driven striker is used. This is found in 33 CFR § 86.02 (Construction, part of Rule 33 requirements).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement concerning an overtaking situation is correct?
option_a: The overtaking vessel is the stand-on vessel.
option_b: Neither vessel is the stand-on vessel.
option_c: The overtaking vessel must maintain course and speed.
option_d: The overtaking vessel must keep out of the way of the other.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, D, is accurate because Rule 13 (Overtaking) of the Navigation Rules states that any vessel overtaking another shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken. This is a fundamental concept in collision avoidance found in both International and Inland Rules (Rule 13).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The Rules state that a vessel overtaking another vessel is relieved of her duty to keep clear when __________.
option_a: she is forward of the other vessel's beam
option_b: the overtaking situation becomes a crossing situation
option_c: she is past and clear of the other vessel
option_d: the other vessel is no longer in sight
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, C, is based on Rule 13 (d) of the Navigation Rules, which states that the overtaking vessel must keep clear until she is "finally past and clear" of the overtaken vessel.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning fog signals?
option_a: All fog signals for sailing vessels are to be given at intervals of not more than one minute.
option_b: A vessel not under command sounds the same fog signal as a vessel towed.
option_c: A pilot vessel underway and making way sounds the pilot identity signal and no other signal.
option_d: A vessel aground may sound a whistle signal.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A vessel aground must sound the anchor signal and may give an additional signal. Rule 35(g) and Rule 35(i) of the COLREGs (International) and Inland Navigation Rules (Inland) detail the sound signals for a vessel aground.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which day-shape would a vessel aground show during daylight?
option_b: Two black balls
option_c: Three black balls
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct day-shape is "Three black balls" because a vessel aground must exhibit three balls in a vertical line during the day. This is specified in Rule 30(d)(ii) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook (Inland and International).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel must have a gong,  or other equipment which will make the sound of a gong?
option_b: Any vessel over 50 meters
option_c: Any vessel over 100 meters
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 33(a)(iii) requires vessels 100 meters or more in length to be provided with a gong or other equipment that will make the sound of a gong. This is for making the required sound signals when at anchor or aground.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A sailing vessel is proceeding  along a narrow channel and can safely navigate ONLY inside  the channel.  The sailing vessel approaches a vessel engaged in fishing.  Which statement is TRUE?
option_a: The fishing vessel is directed not to impede the passage of the sailing vessel.
option_b: The sailing vessel must keep out of the way of the fishing vessel.
option_c: Each vessel should move to the edge of the channel on her port side.
option_d: Each vessel should be displaying signals for a vessel constrained by her draft.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 9 (b) & (c) states that a vessel, such as one engaged in fishing, shall not impede the passage of a vessel that can safely navigate only within a narrow channel. Since the sailing vessel can only navigate inside the channel, the fishing vessel must not impede its passage. Ref: Rule 9 (b) & (c), Narrow Channels.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Day-shapes MUST be shown __________.
option_b: during daylight hours except in restricted visibility
option_c: ONLY between 8 AM and 4 PM daily
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Day-shapes, under International and Inland Rule 25(i) of the Navigation Rules, must be shown during daylight hours. This is because they serve as visual signals to indicate a vessel's status (e.g., anchoring, constrained by draft) when navigational lights are not required.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Rule 14 describes the action to be taken by vessels meeting head-on. Which of the following conditions must exist in order for this rule to apply?
option_b: They must be meeting on reciprocal or nearly reciprocal courses.
option_c: The situation must involve risk of collision.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 14 (Head-on Situation) applies when two power-driven vessels are meeting on reciprocal or nearly reciprocal courses AND there is a risk of collision. Since all conditions listed in A, B, and C must exist, D (All of the above) is the correct answer. The rule is found in the USCG’s Navigation Rules Handbook, Rule 14.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The stern light shall be positioned such that it will show from dead astern to how many degrees on each side of the stern of the vessel?
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 21(c) of the COLREGs (Navigation Rules) defines a sternlight as a white light showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 135 degrees. This arc is fixed to show the light 67.5 degrees from dead astern on each side of the vessel. Therefore, Option B (67.5°) is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel aground at night is required to show two red lights in a vertical line as well  as __________.
option_b: restricted in her ability to maneuver lights
option_c: anchor lights
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel aground must exhibit the lights prescribed for a vessel at anchor (anchor lights) in addition to two all-round red lights in a vertical line. This is per Rule 30 (Anchored vessels and vessels aground) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND When towing more than one barge astern at night __________.
option_a: only the last barge on the tow must be lighted
option_b: only the first and the last barges in the tow must be lighted
option_c: each barge in the tow must be lighted
option_d: only manned barges must be lighted
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 24 covers towing and pushing. When towing more than one barge astern at night, each vessel being towed shall exhibit the required lights for a vessel being towed, meaning each barge must be lighted. This is generally found under Rule 24(e) of the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Your vessel is aground in fog.  In addition to the regular anchor signals, you will be sounding __________.
option_a: three strokes of the gong before and after the rapid ringing of the gong
option_b: a blast on the whistle
option_c: three strokes of the bell before and after the rapid ringing of the bell
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: This is correct based on Rule 35(g) and (h) of the Inland and International Rules of the Road. A vessel aground in restricted visibility must first and last sound three separate and distinct strokes on the bell, with a rapid ringing of the bell for five seconds in between.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In a crossing situation, the vessel which has the other on her own starboard side shall  __________.
option_a: if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid crossing ahead of the other
option_b: change course to port to keep out of the way
option_c: reduce her speed
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The vessel with the other on its starboard side is the give-way vessel (Rule 15). The give-way vessel is required to keep out of the way of the other vessel and, as stated in Rule 15(a), "if the circumstances of the case admit, avoid crossing ahead of the other."

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are on vessel "A" in DIAGRAM 32, and hear vessel "B" sound a signal indicating her intention to overtake you.  You feel it is not safe for vessel "B" to overtake you at the present time.  You should __________.
option_a: sound five or more short rapid blasts
option_b: sound two short blasts
option_c: not answer the whistle signal from vessel "B"
option_d: sound three blasts of the whistle
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: If you feel it is unsafe for vessel "B" to overtake, you must sound the danger signal. This signal is five or more short and rapid blasts. This is required under Inland and International Rule 34(d).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel sounds the same fog signal when underway or at anchor?
option_b: A vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
option_c: A vessel constrained by her draft
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Both a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver and a vessel not under command (Option D) sound the same fog signal (one prolonged followed by two short blasts) when underway or at anchor. The provided correct answer 'B' is for 'A vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver'. A vessel not under command (Option D) is also correct. Assuming the provided answer 'B' is the intended correct answer from the list, the vessel sounds one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts when underway or at anchor. See Rule 35(c) and 35(e).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are approaching a bend in a river where, due to the bank, you cannot see around the other side.  A vessel on the other side of the bend sounds  one prolonged blast.  You should __________.
option_b: not sound any signal until you sight the other vessel
option_c: sound a prolonged blast
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(e) states that a vessel approaching a bend where other vessels may be obscured must sound one prolonged blast. The correct answer (C) is required to warn any vessel on the other side of the bend.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel is "underway" according to the Rules?
option_a: A vessel made fast to a single point mooring buoy
option_b: A purse seiner hauling her nets
option_c: A pilot vessel at anchor
option_d: A vessel which has run aground
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: A vessel "underway" is not at anchor, made fast to the shore, or aground. A purse seiner hauling nets meets this definition, making it underway even though restricted in ability to maneuver. Reference: Inland/International Rule 3(i) (33 CFR 83.03(i)).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND When two power-driven vessels are crossing, the vessel which has the other to starboard must keep out of the way if __________.
option_b: the situation involves risk of collision
option_c: the vessels will pass within half a mile of each other
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The rule applies when there is a risk of collision (Option B). This is found in Rule 15 (Crossing Situation) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook, which states the vessel with the other to starboard must keep out of the way when crossing so as to involve risk of collision.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which signal may at some time be exhibited by a vessel trawling?
option_a: Two white lights in a vertical line
option_b: A white light over a red light in a vertical line
option_c: Two red lights in a vertical line
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 26 governs fishing vessel signals. A trawler exhibits two white lights (when shooting nets) and a white light over a red light (when hauling nets) at different times. These are covered in options A and B, supporting the answer D, "All of the above." (Inland and International Rule 26).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Risk of collision is considered to exist if __________.
option_b: a vessel has a steady bearing at a constant range
option_c: there is any doubt that a risk of collision exists
option_d: a special circumstance situation is apparent
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer is C because Rule 7(a) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook states that if there is any doubt whether a risk of collision exists, such risk shall be deemed to exist. This mandates caution and confirms that option C, "there is any doubt that a risk of collision exists," is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are underway in low visibility and sounding fog signals. What changes would you make in the fog signal immediately upon losing propulsion?
option_a: Begin sounding two prolonged blasts at two-minute intervals.
option_b: Begin sounding one prolonged blast followed by three short  blasts at two-minute intervals.
option_c: Begin sounding one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts at two-minute intervals.
option_d: No change should be made in the fog signal.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The vessel has become "not under command" due to loss of propulsion. Rule 35(e) states that a vessel not under command, when making way through the water, shall sound at intervals of not more than two minutes, one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A power-driven vessel shows the same lights as a __________.
option_a: vessel engaged in towing, when not underway
option_b: vessel towing astern
option_c: sailing vessel
option_d: pushing vessel and a vessel being pushed, when they are rigidly connected in a composite unit
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: When a pushing vessel and a vessel being pushed ahead are rigidly connected in a composite unit, they are regarded as a power-driven vessel and exhibit the lights prescribed in Rule 23. This is found in Rule 24(b) of the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel shall NOT show her sidelights?
option_a: A fishing vessel that is not making way
option_b: A sailing vessel which is becalmed
option_c: A vessel engaged in underwater operations
option_d: A vessel that is not under command making way
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A fishing vessel not making way is not required to show sidelights because it is not underway "making way through the water." Sidelights are only required when making way. See Rule 25(c) and Rule 26(c) and (e) which reference the requirement to show sidelights when making way.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel is overtaking when she can see which light(s) of a vessel ahead?
option_a: Only the stern light of the vessel
option_b: One sidelight and a masthead light of the vessel
option_c: Only a sidelight of the vessel
option_d: The masthead lights of the vessel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer is "Only the stern light of the vessel" (Option A). Rule 21(a) and Rule 13 state that an overtaking vessel is approaching from two points abaft the beam, meaning they can only see the overtaken vessel's stern light (or overtaking light).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement about the Navigation Rules is TRUE?
option_a: The rules require vessels to comply with Traffic Separation Scheme regulations.
option_b: The rules use the term "safe speed."
option_c: The Rules permit a stand-on vessel to take action prior to  being in extremis.
option_d: All of the above are correct.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: All statements are true. Compliance with Traffic Separation Schemes is required (Rule 10). The term "safe speed" is used (Rule 6). A stand-on vessel may take action before being in extremis (Rule 17).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A "short blast" on the whistle  has a duration of __________.
option_b: 4 to 6 seconds
option_c: 8 to 12 seconds
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "1 second," is defined as a "short blast" in Rule 3(j) of the USCG's Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook. This definition applies to both International and Inland rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND As defined in the Rules, the term "vessel" includes __________.
option_b: nondisplacement craft
option_c: barges
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: Rule 3(a) of the COLREGs (33 CFR § 83.03) defines "vessel" as every description of water craft, including nondisplacement craft and seaplanes. Barges are watercraft; therefore, all options listed (seaplanes, nondisplacement craft, and barges) are included.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  A vessel shall slacken her speed, stop, or reverse her engines, if necessary, to __________.
option_b: allow more time to assess the situation
option_c: be stopped in an appropriate distance
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 8(e) of the Navigation Rules states that a vessel shall slacken her speed, stop, or reverse engines if necessary to avoid collision or allow more time to assess the situation. Actions taken must also allow the vessel to be stopped in an appropriate distance. Therefore, "All of the above" is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND An anchor ball need NOT be exhibited by an anchored vessel if she is __________.
option_a: under 50 meters in length, and anchored in an anchorage
option_b: over 150 meters in length
option_c: rigged for sail
option_d: less than 7 meters in length, and not in or near an area where other vessels normally navigate
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, D, is accurate because Rule 30 of the Navigation Rules (33 CFR 83.30) states that a vessel under 7 meters in length is not required to exhibit an anchor ball or anchor lights when anchored, unless she is in or near a narrow channel, fairway, or anchorage, or where other vessels normally navigate. Rule 30.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  A vessel that is not equipped with towing lights should show that it has a vessel in tow by __________.
option_b: sounding one prolonged followed by two short blasts at intervals of not more than two minutes
option_c: shining a searchlight on the towline of the towed vessel
option_d: None of the above; a vessel shall not engage in towing at night without proper navigation lights
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 24(h) states that a vessel not equipped with the lights prescribed in Rule 24 (a) or (c) when engaged in towing at night shall exhibit a searchlight directed toward the towline. Therefore, option C is correct. See Rule 24 (h) in the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway at night you are coming up on a vessel from astern.  What lights would you expect to see?
option_b: Two white lights
option_c: One white light and red and green sidelights
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, One white light (D), is the sternlight. Vessels seen from astern show only the sternlight. This light is visible from dead astern up to 67.5 degrees on either side. See Rule 21(d) and Rule 23/24/25, which all require a sternlight.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What describes a head-on situation?
option_a: Seeing one red light of a vessel directly ahead
option_b: Seeing two forward white towing lights in a vertical line on a towing vessel directly ahead
option_c: Seeing both sidelights of a vessel directly off your starboard beam
option_d: Seeing both sidelights of a vessel directly ahead
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: A head-on situation is when a vessel sees both sidelights (red and green) of another vessel directly ahead. This means they are meeting on reciprocal courses, involving a risk of collision, as described in Rule 14 (Head-on Situation) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel anchored in fog may warn an approaching vessel by sounding __________.
option_b: one short, one prolonged, and one short blast of the whistle
option_c: five or more short and rapid blasts of the whistle
option_d: three distinct strokes on the bell before and after sounding the anchor signal
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A vessel at anchor may sound three blasts in succession (one short, one prolonged, and one short) to warn an approaching vessel of its position and the possibility of collision. This is an optional signal in addition to the mandated bell signal. (Rule 35(g) and subsequent text).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway in fog, you hear a vessel ahead sound two prolonged blasts on the whistle. You should __________.
option_a: sound two blasts and change course to the left
option_b: sound whistle signals only if you change course
option_c: sound only fog signals until the other vessel is sighted
option_d: not sound any whistle signals until the other vessel is sighted
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: When a vessel hears the sound signal of another vessel ahead in restricted visibility, the rules require you to only sound fog signals (Rule 35(e)) and to navigate with caution. The two prolonged blasts signal a vessel towing or pushing ahead.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  You are operating in restricted visibility and hear a signal of a rapidly ringing bell followed by the rapid sounding of a gong. It could be a __________.
option_b: 150-meter power-driven vessel aground
option_c: vessel in distress
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer is D because Rule 35(g) of the COLREGs (Sound Signals in Restricted Visibility) states that a vessel 100 meters or more in length at anchor shall ring the bell rapidly for about 5 seconds in the fore part, and immediately after, sound the gong rapidly for about 5 seconds in the after part. This describes a 300-meter power-driven vessel at anchor.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel being towed, if manned, shall sound a fog signal of __________.
option_b: three short blasts
option_c: one prolonged and two short blasts
option_d: one prolonged and three short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation:
Rule 35(e) of the COLREGs/Navigation Rules states that a manned vessel being towed shall sound at intervals of not more than 2 minutes one prolonged blast followed by three short blasts.

(See Rule 35(e) for details.)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel using a traffic separation scheme shall __________.
option_a: only anchor in the separation zone
option_b: cross a traffic lane at as small an angle as possible
option_c: avoid anchoring in areas near the termination of the scheme
option_d: utilize the separation zone for navigating through the scheme if she is impeding other traffic due to her slower speed
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 10(g) (Traffic Separation Schemes) states that a vessel shall, so far as practicable, avoid anchoring in a traffic separation scheme or near its terminations. This rule applies to both International and Inland waters.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A proper look-out shall be maintained  __________.
option_b: only during restricted visibility
option_c: at night and during restricted visibility
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: Rule 5 (Look-out) of the Navigation Rules states: "Every vessel shall at all times maintain a proper look-out..." Therefore, the correct answer is D, at all times, to ensure a full appraisal of the situation and risk of collision. This applies to both International and Inland waters.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Risk of collision may be deemed to exist __________.
option_a: if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does NOT appreciably change
option_b: even when an appreciable bearing change is evident, particularly when approaching a vessel at close range
option_c: if you observe both sidelights of a vessel ahead for an extended period of time
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Risk of collision is deemed to exist if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does NOT appreciably change (A), per Rule 7(d)(i). It may also exist even with an appreciable bearing change, particularly when approaching at close range (B), per Rule 7(d)(ii). Observing both sidelights (C) often means the vessel is dead ahead, indicating a potential collision course or dangerous closeness. Therefore, All of the above (D) is correct. See Rule 7, Risk of collision.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The Rules state that certain factors are to be taken into account when determining safe  speed.  Those factors include __________.
option_a: state of wind, sea, and current, and the proximity of navigational hazards
option_b: maximum attainable speed of your vessel
option_c: temperature
option_d: aids to navigation that are available
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "state of wind, sea, and current, and the proximity of navigational hazards," is directly listed as a factor to be taken into account when determining safe speed by all vessels. This is covered in Rule 6 (Safe Speed) of the USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel, when anchored at  night, would NOT be required to show anchor lights?
option_b: A vessel on pilotage duty
option_c: A vessel dredging
option_d: A vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel dredging, when at anchor, is considered a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver (Rule 3(g) and Rule 27(d)). Therefore, she must exhibit the lights/shapes prescribed in Rule 27(d) instead of the anchor lights required by Rule 30.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel not under command shall display __________.
option_a: two red lights at night and two black balls during daylight
option_b: two red lights at night and three black balls during daylight
option_c: three red lights at night and two black balls during daylight
option_d: three red lights at night and three black balls during daylight
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 27(a) states a vessel not under command (NUC) shall exhibit two all-round red lights in a vertical line at night, and two balls or similar shapes in a vertical line during daylight. Option A matches this requirement. (33 CFR 83.27)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel engaged in fishing while at anchor shall sound a fog signal of __________.
option_a: one prolonged and two short blasts at two-minute intervals
option_b: one prolonged and three short blasts at two-minute  intervals
option_c: a rapid ringing of the bell for five seconds at one-minute  intervals
option_d: a sounding of the bell and gong at one-minute intervals
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in fishing, whether making way or at anchor, is a vessel engaged in fishing and must sound one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts at intervals of not more than two minutes. See Rule 35(c) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Underway at night you see the red sidelight of a vessel well off your port bow.  Which statement is TRUE?
option_a: You are required to alter course to the right.
option_b: You must stop engines.
option_c: You are on a collision course with the other vessel.
option_d: You may maintain course and speed.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Seeing a red sidelight (port side) well off your port bow indicates a crossing situation where you are the stand-on vessel (seeing their red means they are on your port side). Since the other vessel is "well off," there is no risk of collision. Maintain course and speed is correct per Rule 17 (Action by Stand-on Vessel).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel would sound a fog  signal consisting of the ringing of a bell for 5 seconds?
option_a: A vessel engaged in fishing, at anchor
option_b: A vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver, at anchor
option_c: A sailing vessel, at anchor
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A vessel at anchor, regardless of type (including a sailing vessel), is required to rapidly ring the bell for 5 consecutive seconds every minute when in restricted visibility. Therefore, a sailing vessel at anchor (C) would sound this signal. See Rule 35(f) of the COLREGs/USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel towing a barge astern  would show, at the stern __________.
option_b: a towing light above the stern light
option_c: two towing lights in a vertical line
option_d: two white lights in a vertical line
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "a towing light above the stern light," is mandated by Rule 24 of the USCG Navigation Rules, which covers lights for towing and pushing vessels. Specifically, a power-driven vessel towing astern must exhibit a sternlight and a towing light, with the towing light higher. (33 CFR § 83.24)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A fog signal consisting of one  prolonged blast followed by four short blasts would indicate the presence of a __________.
option_b: fishing vessel engaged in trawling
option_c: vessel at anchor warning of her location
option_d: power-driven pilot vessel on station underway
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer is D because Rule 35 (j) states that a pilot vessel when engaged on pilotage duty may, in addition to the signals prescribed in subparagraphs (a), (b) or (g) of this Rule, sound an identity signal of four short blasts. Since (a) is a power-driven vessel making way (one prolonged blast), the combined signal is one prolonged plus four short blasts. (33 CFR § 83.35)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In addition to sidelights what  light should a vessel being towed astern show?
option_b: A masthead light
option_c: Not under command lights
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel being towed, in addition to sidelights, shall exhibit a sternlight. This is mandated by Rule 24(d)(ii) of the International and Inland Navigation Rules (COLREGs/Inland).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A pilot vessel may continue to  sound an identity signal if she is __________.
option_b: at anchor
option_c: not under command
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A pilot vessel may sound an identity signal (four short blasts) when engaged in pilotage duty. This signal is in addition to the signals for a vessel "at anchor" (Option B). This is found in Rule 35(i) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND When two power-driven vessels are meeting head-on and there is a risk of collision, each  shall __________.
option_b: alter course to starboard
option_c: sound the danger signal
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Option B, "alter course to starboard," is correct. Rule 14 (Head-on Situation) of the Navigation Rules states that when two power-driven vessels are meeting head-on and a risk of collision exists, each shall alter course to starboard so that each shall pass on the port side of the other.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A power driven vessel when towing and the length of the tow exceeds 200 meters shall exhibit during daylight hours where they can best be seen which of the following shapes?
option_b: two cones, apexes together
option_c: a black ball
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 24 states that a power-driven vessel when towing, and the length of the tow exceeds 200 meters, shall exhibit a diamond shape where it can best be seen during daylight hours. This is why "a diamond shape" (Option A) is the correct answer.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What is the minimum length of vessels required to show two anchor lights?
option_b: 50 meters
option_c: 60 meters
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 30(a) and 30(b) state that vessels 50 meters or more in length must exhibit two all-round white anchor lights (fore and aft). Vessels under 50 meters may show only one.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel showing a rigid replica of the International Code flag "A" is engaged in __________.
option_b: dredging
option_c: fishing
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Flag "A" of the International Code of Signals indicates a vessel is restricted in its ability to maneuver due to diving operations. This is found in Rule 27(e) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules, which details signals for vessels engaged in diving operations.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In determining "safe speed", all of the following must be taken into account EXCEPT the __________.
option_b: presence of background lights at night
option_c: draft of your vessel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, A, is the maximum horsepower because Rule 6 (33 CFR 83.06) specifies conditions and circumstances to consider for safe speed, such as visibility, traffic, maneuverability, and draft, but does not list maximum horsepower as a factor.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are aboard the give-way vessel in a crossing situation.  What should you NOT do in obeying the Rules?
option_a: Cross ahead of the stand-on vessel
option_b: Make a large course change to starboard
option_c: Slow your vessel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The give-way vessel must take early and substantial action to keep well clear and avoid crossing ahead of the stand-on vessel. Crossing ahead increases the risk of collision. This is covered in Rule 15 (Crossing Situation) and Rule 16 (Action by Give-way Vessel).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel, which does not normally engage in towing operations, is towing a vessel in distress.  She __________.
option_a: need not show the lights for a vessel engaged in towing, if it is impractical to do so
option_b: may show the lights for a vessel not under command
option_c: must show a yellow light above the stern light
option_d: must show the lights for a vessel towing
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation:
The vessel is not normally engaged in towing and may be excused from showing towing lights if impractical due to the distress situation, as per Rule 24(h) of COLREGs.

Rule 24 covers the required lights for vessels towing and pushing.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND An all-round flashing yellow light may be exhibited by a(n) __________.
option_b: vessel towing a submerged object
option_c: vessel not under command
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: An air-cushion vessel operating in the nondisplacement mode must exhibit an all-round flashing yellow light. This is specified in the USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook under Rule 23 (b), Power-driven vessels underway.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Working lights shall be used to illuminate the decks of a vessel __________.
option_b: not under command
option_c: constrained by her draft
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 30(c) of the Navigation Rules states that a vessel 100 meters or more in length at anchor shall use available working or equivalent lights to illuminate her decks. Therefore, "over 100 meters at anchor" is the correct condition.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel may show identifying lights when not actually engaged in her occupation?
option_b: A pilot vessel
option_c: A mineclearance vessel
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Per the USCG Navigation Rules: Rule 26(e) states a fishing vessel not fishing must not show fishing lights. Rule 29(b) states a pilot vessel not on pilotage duty must not show pilot lights. Therefore, none of the listed vessels may show identifying lights when not engaged in their occupation. The answer is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A pilot vessel may continue to  sound an identity signal if she is __________.
option_b: aground
option_c: being towed
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 29(a)(iii) states that a pilot vessel "when at anchor, shall in addition to the lights prescribed in Rule 30 for vessels at anchor, exhibit at or near the masthead a white light and below it a red light." Rule 29(a)(i) says that a pilot vessel "when engaged on pilotage duty and underway shall exhibit at or near the masthead a white light and below it a red light." Option A, "underway, but not making way," is a type of vessel underway. Rule 35(e) allows a pilot vessel to sound an identity signal (four short blasts) "in addition to any other signal prescribed in paragraph (c) or (d) of this Rule." Rule 29 of the COLREGs/USCG Navigation Rules covers pilot vessels.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND If your vessel is the stand-on vessel in a crossing situation __________.
option_a: you must keep your course and speed
option_b: you may change course and speed as the other vessel must keep clear
option_c: the other vessel must keep her course and speed
option_d: both vessels must keep their course and speed
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: As the stand-on vessel, you must maintain your course and speed. This is mandated by Rule 17 of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook (Action by the Stand-on Vessel). The rule requires the stand-on vessel to hold its position until the give-way vessel's failure to act makes collision unavoidable.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel proceeding along a narrow channel shall __________.
option_a: avoid crossing the channel at right angles
option_b: not overtake any vessels within the channel
option_c: keep as near as safe and practicable to the limit of the channel on her starboard side
option_d: when nearing a bend in the channel, sound a long blast of the whistle
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 9(a) of the COLREGs (International) and Inland Rules states a vessel proceeding along a narrow channel must keep as near as safe and practicable to the limit of the channel on their starboard side. This is why C is the correct answer.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel would exhibit sidelights when underway and not making way?
option_b: A vessel trawling
option_c: A vessel not under command
option_d: A vessel engaged in dredging operations
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A power-driven vessel when towing astern, and is underway (even if not making way), must exhibit sidelights. All power-driven vessels underway must exhibit sidelights (Rule 23). Rule 24 specifies the lights for a vessel towing astern, including sidelights.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel is NOT to impede the passage of a vessel which can only navigate safely within a narrow channel?
option_a: Any vessel less than 20 meters in length
option_b: Any sailing vessel
option_c: A vessel engaged in fishing
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer is D, All of the above, according to Rule 9(b) of the COLREGs (International) and Inland Rules (33 CFR § 83.09). This rule states that a vessel less than 20 meters in length, a sailing vessel, or a vessel engaged in fishing shall not impede the passage of a vessel that can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or fairway.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A tug is towing three manned barges in line in fog.  The second vessel of the tow should sound __________.
option_b: one short blast
option_c: one prolonged and three short blasts
option_d: one prolonged and two short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Only the last vessel in a tow, if manned, is required to sound a fog signal (one prolonged and three short blasts). Intermediate vessels in the tow, such as the second barge, sound no fog signal. See Rule 35(e).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The steering and sailing rules  for vessels in restricted visibility apply to vessels __________.
option_a: in sight of one another in fog
option_b: navigating in or near an area of restricted visibility
option_c: only if they are showing special purpose lights
option_d: only if they have operational radar
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 19 (a) of the COLREGS (Conduct of Vessels in Restricted Visibility) states that the rule applies to vessels not in sight of one another when navigating in or near an area of restricted visibility, making option B correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The Navigation Rules state that a vessel shall be operated at a safe speed at all times so  that she can be stopped within __________.
option_b: 1/2 the distance of visibility
option_c: a distance appropriate to the existing circumstances and conditions
option_d: the distance that it would require for the propeller to go  from full ahead to full astern
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, C, aligns with Rule 6 (Safe Speed) of the Navigation Rules (33 CFR 83.06). A vessel must proceed at a speed where it can take proper and effective action to avoid collision and be stopped within a distance appropriate to the existing circumstances and conditions.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A towing vessel 35 meters in length, with a tow 100 meters astern, must show a minimum of how many masthead lights?
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The towing vessel must show a minimum of two masthead lights in a vertical line. Rule 24(a)(i) of the Navigation Rules (COLREGs) states a power-driven vessel towing astern shall exhibit two masthead lights in a vertical line instead of the single masthead light required for a power-driven vessel underway.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What must be TRUE in order for a stand-on vessel to take action to avoid collision by her maneuver alone?
option_a: She must be in sight of the give-way vessel.
option_b: There must be risk of collision.
option_c: She must determine that the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer is 'All of the above' (D) because for a stand-on vessel to take action to avoid collision by maneuver alone, all three conditions (A, B, and C) must be true according to Rule 17, Action by Stand-on Vessel.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel being towed astern, where the length of the tow exceeds 200 meters, will exhibit __________.
option_a: two balls in a vertical line
option_b: a diamond shape where it can best be seen
option_c: a ball on each end of the tow
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 24(a)(v) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations states that when the length of the tow exceeds 200 meters, the vessel being towed shall exhibit "a diamond shape where it can best be seen." This matches option B, confirming it as the correct day-shape.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND For a stand-on vessel to take action to avoid collision she shall, if possible, NOT __________.
option_b: increase speed
option_c: turn to port for a vessel on her port side
option_d: turn to starboard for a vessel on her port side
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 17(d)(i) states a stand-on vessel must avoid changing course to port for a vessel on its own port side, as this generally turns the vessel toward the give-way vessel. Such action increases the risk of collision. This is the correct action to NOT take.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  You hear the fog signal of another vessel forward of your beam.  Risk of collision may exist. You MUST __________.
option_b: stop your engines
option_c: begin a radar plot
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 19(e) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules states that a vessel that hears a fog signal forward of the beam and determines a risk of collision exists must reduce speed to the minimum necessary to maintain course, known as bare steerageway, until the danger of collision is over.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Two barges are being pushed ahead by a tugboat.  Which statement is TRUE concerning lights on the barges?
option_b: Each vessel should show at least one white light.
option_c: The barges should be lighted as separate units.
option_d: The barges should be lighted as one vessel.
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, D, is true because when two barges are being pushed ahead by a tugboat, the whole unit must be lighted as a single vessel. This is stated in Rule 24 of the USCG Navigation Rules, concerning towing and pushing.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The Rules state that a seaplane shall __________.
option_a: not be regarded as a vessel
option_b: in general, keep well clear of all vessels
option_c: proceed at a slower speed than surrounding vessels
option_d: when making way, show the lights for a vessel not under command
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, option B, is supported by Rule 31 (a) of the COLREGs (International) and Inland Navigation Rules, which states that a seaplane on the water shall, in general, keep well clear of all vessels and avoid impeding their navigation.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND If practical, when shall a manned vessel being towed sound her fog signal?
option_a: Immediately before the towing vessel sounds hers
option_b: Immediately after the towing vessel sounds hers
option_c: As close to the mid-cycle of the towing vessel's signals as possible
option_d: At any time as long as the interval is correct
question_category: Part D: Sound and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(i) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook states that a manned vessel being towed, if practicable, shall sound her fog signal immediately after the towing vessel sounds hers. This is why "Immediately after the towing vessel sounds hers" is the correct answer.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Your tug is underway at night and NOT towing.  What light(s) should your vessel show aft  to other vessels coming up from astern?
option_b: Two white lights
option_c: One white light and one yellow light
option_d: One white light and two yellow lights
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A tug underway and not towing is considered a power-driven vessel underway. Such a vessel must exhibit a sternlight (one white light) shown aft to vessels coming from astern. This requirement is found in Rule 23(a)(iv) of the Navigation Rules, which specifies a sternlight for power-driven vessels underway.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel conducting mineclearing operations will show __________.
option_a: three balls in a vertical line
option_b: two balls in a vertical line
option_c: one ball near the foremast and one ball at each fore yard
option_d: one diamond near the foremast head and one ball at each fore yard
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Option C is correct because a vessel engaged in mineclearing operations must show three balls, one near the foremast head and one at each end of the fore yard. This is specified in Rule 27(f) of the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel sailing shall keep out of the way of all of the following vessels except a vessel  __________.
option_b: engaged on pilotage duty
option_c: restricted in her ability to maneuver
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, B, is a vessel engaged on pilotage duty. Under Rule 18 (Responsibilities Between Vessels), a sailing vessel must keep out of the way of vessels not under command, restricted in ability to maneuver, and engaged in fishing. A vessel on pilotage duty does not have priority over a sailing vessel.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning a vessel under oars?
option_a: She must show a stern light.
option_b: She is allowed to show the same lights as a sailing vessel.
option_c: She must show a fixed all-round white light.
option_d: She must show a day-shape of a black cone.
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel under oars may show the same lights as a sailing vessel. This is stated in Rule 25, which details the lighting requirements for sailing vessels underway and vessels under oars. See 33 CFR § 83.25.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A power-driven vessel is underway and fishing with trolling lines.  This vessel __________.
option_a: must keep out of the way of sailing vessels
option_b: must sound a one prolonged, two short blasts signal in restricted visibility
option_c: is the stand-on vessel when overtaking power-driven vessels
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The vessel is considered a power-driven vessel, not a "vessel engaged in fishing," because trolling lines do not restrict maneuverability (Rule 3). As a power-driven vessel, it must keep out of the way of a sailing vessel (Rule 18(a)(iv)).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND At night you sight a vessel displaying a single green light.  This is a __________.
option_b: small motorboat underway
option_c: vessel drifting
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A single green light indicates the starboard sidelight of a vessel, meaning you are seeing its right side. If only a single green light is visible at night, it most commonly identifies a sailing vessel. This relates to Rule 25, which details lights for sailing vessels underway.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND When two power-driven vessels are crossing, which vessel is the stand-on vessel?
option_a: The vessel which is to starboard of the other vessel
option_b: The vessel which is to port of the other vessel
option_c: The larger vessel
option_d: The vessel that sounds the first whistle signal
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: In a crossing situation, the vessel that has the other on its own starboard side is the give-way vessel (Rule 15). Therefore, the stand-on vessel is the one that is to starboard of the give-way vessel. The vessel which is to starboard of the other vessel is the stand-on vessel. (Rule 15 - Crossing Situation)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel must exhibit forward and after white masthead lights when making way?
option_a: A  75-meter vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
option_b: A 100-meter sailing vessel
option_c: A 150-meter vessel engaged in fishing
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A 75-meter vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver must exhibit the lights of a power-driven vessel of 50 meters or more, which includes a forward and a second after masthead light. This is required by Rule 23 for power-driven vessels and compounded by Rule 27.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND By radar alone, you detect a vessel ahead on a collision course, about 3 miles distant.   Your radar plot shows this to be a meeting situation.  You should __________.
option_b: turn to starboard
option_c: maintain course and speed and sound the danger signal
option_d: maintain course and speed and sound no signal
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 14 of the Inland and International Rules states that in a meeting situation, each vessel shall alter course to starboard so that each shall pass on the port side of the other. Therefore, you should turn to starboard. (Rule 14, Head-on Situation).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A sailing vessel underway at night may show __________.
option_a: a red light over a green light at the masthead
option_b: a green light over a red light at the masthead
option_c: two white lights in a vertical line at the stern
option_d: an all-round white light at the bow
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A sailing vessel underway may, in addition to sidelights and a sternlight, exhibit two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper red and the lower green, at or near the top of the mast. (Rule 25(c))

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel engaged in trawling will show identification lights of __________.
option_a: a red light over a white light
option_b: a white light over a red light
option_c: a green light over a white light
option_d: two red lights in a vertical line
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "a green light over a white light," is mandated by Rule 26 (b) (iii) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook. This rule specifies that a vessel engaged in trawling shall exhibit two all-round lights in a vertical line, the upper being green and the lower white.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What is required of a vessel navigating near an area of restricted visibility?
option_a: A power-driven vessel shall have her engines ready for immediate maneuver.
option_b: She must sound appropriate sound signals.
option_c: If she detects another vessel by radar, she shall determine if risk of collision exists.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: All of the actions listed (engines ready, sound signals, determining collision risk) are required under Rule 19, Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility (33 CFR § 83.19). A vessel must proceed at a safe speed, have engines ready for maneuver, sound appropriate signals, and assess collision risk when detecting other vessels by radar.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND By night, you sight the lights  of a vessel engaged in underwater operations. If an obstruction exists on the port side of the vessel, it will  be marked by __________.
option_b: two red lights in a vertical line
option_c: a single red light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation:
Rule 27(d)(ii) of the Navigation Rules states that a vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver (such as one engaged in underwater operations) shall exhibit two all-round red lights in a vertical line to indicate the obstructed side (port side in this case). This marks the side another vessel may not pass.
Reference Rule 27(d)(ii).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel may carry her sidelights and stern light in one combined lantern?
option_b: A 15-meter vessel propelled by sail and machinery
option_c: A 10-meter sailing vessel
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A sailing vessel under 20 meters in length may combine sidelights and a stern light in one lantern carried at or near the top of the mast. Rule 25(b) of the Navigation Rules covers this, and a 10-meter sailing vessel falls under this size limit.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which lights would be shown at  night by a vessel which is restricted in her ability to deviate from her course?
option_a: Three red lights in a vertical line
option_b: Three white lights in a vertical line
option_c: Three lights in a vertical line, the highest and lowest white and the middle red
option_d: Three lights in a vertical line, the highest and lowest red and the middle white
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
