answer_explanation: Rule 27 of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook specifies that a vessel restricted in its ability to deviate from its course (restricted in its ability to maneuver) shall exhibit three all-round lights in a vertical line: the highest and lowest red, and the middle white.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel engaged in fishing shall keep out of the way of a vessel __________.
option_b: restricted in her ability to maneuver
option_c: crossing a channel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in fishing must keep out of the way of vessels restricted in their ability to maneuver because they have a higher priority in the "pecking order" of right-of-way. This is outlined in Rule 18 (Responsibilities Between Vessels).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessels shall turn off their sidelights?
option_a: All vessels that are not under command
option_b: All fishing vessels that are not making way
option_c: All sailing vessels which are becalmed
option_d: All vessels engaged in underwater operations
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Fishing vessels are required to exhibit the lights for a vessel *at anchor* or *aground* when not making way. This means they turn off sidelights. See Rule 25, which discusses lights for sailing vessels and vessels under oars, and Rule 26 for fishing vessels' lights.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel fishing at night, with gear extending more than 150 meters horizontally outwards,  will show in the direction of the gear  __________.
option_b: two vertical white lights
option_c: one yellow light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 26(c) states that a vessel engaged in fishing, other than trawling, with outlying gear extending more than 150m horizontally, must exhibit an all-round white light in the direction of the gear. This corresponds to option A, "one white light."

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In restricted visibility, a vessel which detects by radar alone the presence of another vessel shall determine if a close quarters situation is developing or risk of collision exists.  If so, she shall __________.
option_b: when taking action, make only course changes
option_c: avoid altering course toward a vessel abaft the beam
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "avoid altering course toward a vessel abaft the beam," is required by Rule 19(d)(i) for a vessel taking action based on radar detection in restricted visibility. Rule 19 outlines the conduct of vessels when not in sight of one another.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A 60-meter vessel which is trawling is required to show how many white masthead lights at night?
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in trawling must show a white masthead light abaft of and higher than the all-round lights. While Rule 26(b)(iii) requires a second masthead light for vessels 50m or more, the minimum requirement is one white masthead light as stated in Rule 26(b).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel servicing a pipeline during the day shall display __________.
option_a: three black shapes in a vertical line; the highest and lowest are balls, and the middle one is a diamond
option_b: three shapes in a vertical line; the highest and lowest are red balls, and the middle one is a white diamond
option_c: three black balls in a vertical line
option_d: two black balls in a vertical line
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel servicing a pipeline is restricted in its ability to maneuver and must display three shapes in a vertical line: ball, diamond, ball. This is required by Rule 27(d) of the USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In fog you observe your radar and determine that risk of collision exists with a vessel which is 2 miles off your port bow.  You should __________.
option_b: sound the danger signal at two-minute intervals
option_c: hold course and speed until the other vessel is sighted
option_d: take avoiding action as soon as possible
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "take avoiding action as soon as possible," is derived from Rule 19(d), Conduct of Vessels in Restricted Visibility. When risk of collision is determined by radar in fog, avoiding action must be taken immediately to ensure vessels pass at a safe distance.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning a towing vessel which, due to the nature of her work, is unable to keep out of the way of another vessel?
option_a: By day, she shall carry a black cylinder shape.
option_b: By day, she shall carry two black balls in a vertical line.
option_c: By night, she would show the same lights as a vessel not under command.
option_d: By day, she would show the same shapes as a vessel  restricted in her ability to maneuver.
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A towing vessel unable to keep out of the way due to the nature of her work is considered a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver (Rule 3(g)). Such vessels, by day, show the same shapes: three shapes in a vertical line: ball, diamond, ball (Rule 27(b)). This information can be found in the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE regarding equipment for bell & gong signals?
option_a: A vessel of less than 12 meters in length need not have any sound signaling equipment.
option_b: Manual sounding of the signals must always be possible.
option_c: Any vessel over 12 meters in length must be provided with a gong.
option_d: Signals must be able to be sounded manually and automatically.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 33(b) (Equipment for Sound Signals) requires that the equipment for any sound signal prescribed in Rule 33 must be capable of being operated manually. The equipment must be readily available for immediate use.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are approaching a narrow channel.  You see a vessel that can only be navigated safely within the channel.  You MUST __________.
option_b: sound the danger signal
option_c: not cross the channel if you might impede the other vessel
option_d: initiate an exchange of passing signals
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 9(b) of the COLREGs/Inland Rules states that a vessel shall not cross a narrow channel if such crossing impedes the passage of a vessel that can safely navigate only within that channel. The correct action is to not impede the other vessel, which is option C.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What is the minimum sound signaling equipment required aboard a vessel 10 meters in length?
option_a: Any means of making an efficient sound signal
option_b: A bell only
option_c: A whistle only
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: For vessels less than 12 meters in length (like a 10m vessel), Rule 33(a) of both International and Inland Rules requires only "some other means of making an efficient sound signal." Option A, "Any means of making an efficient sound signal," is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel must have a gong,  or other equipment which will make the sound of a gong?
option_b: Any vessel over 50 meters
option_c: A power driven vessel over 75 meters
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 33 (Equipment for sound signals) states a vessel 100m or more must have a whistle, a bell, and a gong. The gong requirement applies to vessels of this length when anchored or aground in restricted visibility (Rule 35).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway and in sight of  another vessel, less than one half mile away, you put your engines on astern propulsion.  Which statement concerning whistle signals is TRUE?
option_a: You need not sound any whistle signals.
option_b: You must sound one blast if backing to starboard.
option_c: You must sound whistle signals only if the vessels are meeting.
option_d: You must sound three short blasts on the whistle.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation:
Rule 34(a)(iii) states that a vessel operating astern propulsion (backing up) must indicate this maneuver with three short blasts. This applies regardless of the proximity or situation of other vessels while underway.
Reference: Rule 34(a)(iii) of the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  Which statement is TRUE concerning the light used with whistle signals?
option_a: Use of such a light is required.
option_b: Its purpose is to supplement short blasts of the whistle.
option_c: The light shall have the same characteristics as a masthead light.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer is B. Rule 34(b) of the International and Inland Rules states that a light may be used to supplement short blasts of the whistle during maneuvering signals, specifically for vessels 50 meters or more in length. The light is not required and does not have the characteristics of a masthead light.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What determines if a vessel is "restricted in her ability to maneuver"?
option_a: Whether or not all of the vessel's control equipment is in  working order
option_b: The vessel's draft in relation to the available depth of water
option_c: Whether the nature of the vessel's work limits maneuverability required by the Rules
option_d: Whether or not the vessel is the give-way vessel in a meeting situation
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: The correct answer is C because Rule 3 (g) of the Navigation Rules defines a vessel "restricted in her ability to maneuver" as one limited by the nature of her work from maneuvering as required by the rules. The definition specifically relates to the vessel's work, not its equipment or draft.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is true concerning the light used to accompany whistle signals?
option_a: It is only used to supplement short blasts of the whistle.
option_b: It is mandatory to use such a light.
option_c: The light shall have the same characteristics as a masthead light.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(b) (International) states that a vessel may use a light signal to supplement the sound signals, consisting of flashes of light, and is generally used with short blasts. This is only for supplementing short blasts for meeting, crossing, and overtaking situations. (Rule 34)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning the danger signal?
option_a: Only the stand-on vessel can sound the danger signal.
option_b: Radio transmissions may be used in place of the danger signal.
option_c: A vessel in doubt as to the other vessel's intentions must sound the danger signal.
option_d: The danger signal consists of 5 or more prolonged blasts of the whistle.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A vessel in doubt of another vessel's intentions, or feeling a proposed maneuver is dangerous, is required to sound the danger signal (five or more short and rapid blasts). This is covered in Rule 34(d) of the Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel may sound the danger signal?
option_a: Either vessel in a meeting situation
option_b: The give-way vessel in a crossing situation
option_c: A vessel at anchor
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The danger signal (five or more short, rapid blasts) is used when a vessel doubts the intentions or safety of another vessel's action. This signal may be sounded by any vessel whenever risk of collision exists and understanding or safety is in doubt. The situations described (meeting, crossing) or vessel status (at anchor, if threatened) all warrant sounding the danger signal if necessary. See Rule 34(d).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  You are on watch in fog.  Which vessel is "in sight"?
option_a: A vessel that you can see from the bridge
option_b: A radar target of which you have determined the course and  speed
option_c: A vessel from which you can hear the fog signal
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation:
A vessel is "in sight" when it can be visually observed. Radar or hearing a fog signal does not satisfy the definition. Rule 3(k) defines "vessels in sight of one another" as "when one can be observed visually from the other."

Reference: USCG Navigation Rules, Rule 3(k).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In a meeting situation, which vessel may sound the danger signal?
option_b: Give-way vessel
option_c: Either vessel
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer is "Either vessel" (C). Under Rule 34(d) of both International and Inland Rules, if either vessel is in doubt of the other's intentions or actions to avoid collision, that vessel shall sound the danger signal (five short blasts).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are underway in a narrow channel and are being overtaken by a vessel astern.  The overtaking vessel sounds a signal indicating her intention  to pass you on your starboard side.  If such an action appears dangerous, you should sound __________.
option_a: one prolonged followed by one short blast
option_b: one prolonged, one short, one prolonged, and one short blast in that order
option_c: five short and rapid blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer is C because Rule 34(d) of the Navigation Rules states that if a vessel is in doubt as to the intentions of another vessel, or if it determines that insufficient action is being taken to avoid collision, it shall sound five short and rapid blasts. This signal indicates danger or doubt regarding the overtaking vessel's intention to pass safely. (Rule 34(d))

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which is a light signal authorized by the Secretary of the Navy as an additional navigational light for a ship of war?
option_a: Intermittent flashing amber (yellow) beacon for submarines
option_b: Green masthead and yardarm lights indicating mine clearance operations
option_c: Red-white-red lights in a vertical line for a carrier, launching aircraft
option_d: Yellow flares indicating torpedo firing exercises
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 1(e) authorizes the Secretary of the Navy to prescribe additional station and signal lights. 32 CFR 707.7 states that submarines may display an intermittent flashing amber (yellow) beacon as an additional navigational light when surfaced. This is specific to naval vessels.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  Day-shapes must be displayed __________.
option_b: only between 8 AM and 4 PM
option_c: during daylight hours in any visibility
option_d: during daylight hours in unrestricted visibility only
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 20(d) of the Navigation Rules states: "The Rules concerning shapes shall be complied with by day." "By day" means sunrise to sunset (daylight hours), and unlike lights, shapes are displayed regardless of visibility, making "during daylight hours in any visibility" (C) correct. (Rule 20(d))

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel may exhibit lights other than those prescribed by the Rules as long as the additional lights __________.
option_a: are not the same color as either side light
option_b: have a lesser range of visibility than the prescribed lights
option_c: do not impair the visibility or distinctive character of the prescribed lights
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 20 (b) of the Navigation Rules states that additional lights must not impair the visibility or distinctive character of the prescribed lights. Exhibit C aligns with this rule.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel may exhibit lights other than those prescribed by the Rules as long as the additional lights __________.
option_a: do not interfere with the keeping of a proper look-out
option_b: do not impair the visibility or distinctive character of the prescribed lights
option_c: cannot be mistaken for the lights specified elsewhere in the Rules
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "All of the above," is mandated by Rule 20(b) of the Navigation Rules, which permits additional lights, provided they do not interfere with a proper look-out, impair the visibility or distinctive character of prescribed lights, or be mistaken for lights specified elsewhere in the Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The stern light shall be positioned such that it will show from dead astern to how many degrees on each side of the stern of the vessel?
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 21(c) defines a sternlight as a white light showing an unbroken arc of the horizon of 135 degrees (67.5° on each side of dead astern). The light must be fixed to show from dead astern to 67.5° on each side. The answer C (67.5°) is correct because the question asks how many degrees on each side of the stern the light will show.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You see a red sidelight bearing NW (315°).  That vessel may be heading __________.
option_b: east (090°)
option_c: southwest (225°)
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A red sidelight is visible from dead ahead to 22.5° abaft the port beam (112.5° arc). If you see it at 315°, the vessel's heading must place 315° within its port arc. A heading of SW (225°) makes the port arc 225° to 337.5°, which includes 315°. See Rule 23(a)(iii) and Annex I, Section 9.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What does the word "breadth" mean?
option_b: Molded breadth
option_c: Breadth on the main deck
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: The word "breadth" of a vessel means her greatest breadth, as defined in Rule 3(j) (General definitions) of the Navigation Rules. This is why "Greatest breadth" (Option A) is the correct answer.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND If underway in low visibility and sounding fog signals, what changes would you make in the fog signal IMMEDIATELY upon losing the power plant and propulsion?
option_a: Begin sounding one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts at two-minute intervals.
option_b: Begin sounding one prolonged blast followed by three short  blasts at two-minute intervals.
option_c: Begin sounding two prolonged blasts at two-minute intervals.
option_d: No change should be made in the fog signal.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, A, aligns with Rule 35(c) of the COLREGs (Inland and International). A power-driven vessel that loses its power plant and propulsion is considered "not under command." A vessel not under command must sound one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts at intervals of not more than 2 minutes.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel engaged in fishing while at anchor shall sound a fog signal of __________.
option_a: one prolonged and three short blasts at one minute  intervals
option_b: a rapid ringing of the bell for five seconds at one minute  intervals
option_c: one prolonged and two short blasts at two minute intervals
option_d: a sounding of the bell and gong at one minute intervals
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(c) states that a vessel engaged in fishing, or restricted in ability to maneuver, at anchor, shall sound the signal prescribed in paragraph (c)—one prolonged followed by two short blasts—at intervals of not more than two minutes.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What is the fog signal for a  vessel 75 meters in length, restricted in her ability to maneuver, at anchor?
option_a: One prolonged blast followed by two short blasts at intervals of not more than two minutes
option_b: Five second ringing of a bell at intervals of not more than one minute
option_c: Four short blasts at intervals of not more than two minutes
option_d: Five second ringing of a bell and five second sounding of a gong at intervals of not more than one minute
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(c) of the COLREGs (International & Inland) states that a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver (whether underway or at anchor) shall sound one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts at intervals of not more than two minutes.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel sounds the same fog signal when underway or at anchor?
option_b: A vessel constrained by her draft
option_c: A vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver sounds one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts, regardless of whether she is underway or at anchor. This signal is the same for vessels constrained by draft, fishing vessels, and tugs. See Rule 35.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel would sound a fog  signal consisting of the ringing of a bell for 5 seconds?
option_a: A vessel engaged in fishing, at anchor
option_b: A vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver, at anchor
option_c: A sailing vessel, at anchor
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: All vessels at anchor must sound a fog signal of a bell ringing rapidly for about 5 seconds at intervals of not more than one minute. Since option C is the only one not required to sound an additional signal, it is the best answer. See Rule 35(g).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A 200-meter vessel is aground in fog.  Which signal is optional?
option_b: A whistle signal
option_c: A gong signal
option_d: All of the above are mandatory.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(h) of the USCG Navigation Rules states a vessel aground "may in addition sound an appropriate whistle signal." For a vessel over 100m, a bell and gong signal are mandatory (Rule 35(g)). Since the whistle is stated as "may in addition," it is optional.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What is NOT a vessel "restricted in her ability to maneuver"?
option_a: A vessel laying engaged in laying submarine cable
option_b: A vessel towing with limited maneuverability due to a large unwieldy tow
option_c: A deep-draft vessel that can only navigate in a dredged channel
option_d: A towing vessel underway with a fuel barge alongside and taking on fuel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: A deep-draft vessel is "constrained by her draft," not "restricted in her ability to maneuver." Rule 3(g) defines vessels "restricted in their ability to maneuver," and Rule 3(h) defines "vessel constrained by her draft." The latter only applies to International Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A 200-meter vessel is aground in restricted visibility.  Which signal is optional?
option_b: A gong signal
option_c: A bell signal
option_d: All of the above are optional.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A 200-meter vessel aground must sound a bell and a gong signal at specified intervals (Rule 35(g) and (h)). The whistle signal is not a required signal for a vessel aground in restricted visibility; it is suggested by some but not mandated by the Rules. Therefore, the whistle signal is optional. Reference Rule 35, Sound Signals in Restricted Visibility.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning fog signals?
option_a: All fog signals for sailing vessels are to be given at intervals of not more than one minute.
option_b: A vessel aground may sound a whistle signal.
option_c: A vessel not under command sounds the same fog signal as a  vessel towed.
option_d: The identity signal of a pilot vessel is the only fog signal sounded by such a vessel.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A vessel aground must sound the anchor signal (rapid ringing of the bell for 5 seconds every minute) and may supplement it with a whistle signal. This is stated in Rule 35(h) of the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway in fog, you hear a vessel ahead sound two short blasts on the whistle.  You should __________.
option_a: not sound any whistle signals until the other vessel is sighted
option_b: sound only fog signals until the other vessel is sighted
option_c: sound whistle signals only if you change course
option_d: sound two short blasts and change course to the left
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A vessel ahead sounding two short blasts in fog is likely indicating they are stopping or taking way off (Rule 35(c)). Since you are underway in fog and hear a signal ahead, you should sound fog signals (Rule 35(a)) and proceed with caution until the other vessel is sighted (Rule 19(e)(i)).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are underway in fog when you hear the rapid ringing of a bell for five seconds followed  by the sounding of a gong for five seconds.  This signal indicates a vessel __________.
option_b: fishing while making no way through the water
option_c: more than 100 meters in length, at anchor
question_category: Part D: Sound and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The fog signal—rapid ringing of a bell for 5 seconds followed immediately by a gong for 5 seconds—is the signal for a vessel 100 meters or more in length, at anchor. This is specified in Rule 35(g) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook (Inland & International).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A tug is towing three barges astern in restricted visibility.  The second vessel of the  tow should sound __________.
option_a: one prolonged and two short blasts
option_b: one prolonged and three short blasts
option_c: one short blast
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(e) of both International and Inland Rules states that only the last vessel of a tow, if manned, is required to sound a fog signal (four short blasts). Since the vessel in question is the second of three barges, it is not the last and therefore sounds no signal.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What is the identity signal which may be sounded by a vessel engaged on pilotage duty in fog?
option_b: 3 short blasts
option_c: 4 short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer is C (4 short blasts) because a pilot vessel engaged on pilotage duty may sound an identity signal consisting of four short blasts in restricted visibility. This is covered in Rule 35(k) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What does the word "length" refer to?
option_b: Length overall
option_c: Waterline length
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: The word "length" refers to the vessel's length overall, which is option B. This definition is stated in both the International and Inland Rules of the Road, Rule 3(j), which says, "The words ‘length’ and ‘breadth’ of a vessel mean her length overall and greatest breadth."

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A fog signal of one prolonged blast followed by four short blasts would mean the presence of a __________.
option_b: power-driven pilot vessel on station underway
option_c: fishing vessel trawling
option_d: vessel at anchor warning of her location
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(k) states that a pilot vessel engaged on pilotage duty may sound an identity signal consisting of four short blasts, in addition to the regular fog signals. The one prolonged blast is the standard fog signal for a power-driven vessel making way, per Rule 35(a), identifying a power-driven pilot vessel on station underway.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are heading due east (090°) and observe a vessel's red sidelight on your port beam.  The vessel may be heading __________.
option_b: southeast (135°)
option_c: northeast (045°)
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The red sidelight indicates the other vessel's port side (left). If the vessel is on your port beam (270° relative) and showing its red light, it is crossing from port to starboard. A heading of southwest (225°) shows the red light to your vessel heading 090°. Refer to Rule 23 (Power-driven vessels underway) and Rule 15 (Crossing situation).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A towing light is a yellow light having the same characteristics as a(n) __________.
option_b: anchor light
option_c: stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A towing light is defined as a yellow light having the same characteristics as a stern light (showing an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of 135 degrees). This is specified in Rule 21(c) of the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  The masthead light may be located at other than the fore and aft centerline on a vessel __________.
option_b: less than 20 meters in length
option_c: of special construction
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The masthead light may be located off the centerline on a vessel of special construction, as specified in Rule 21(a) of the Navigation Rules (Definitions). This allows for flexibility in light placement when a vessel's design makes compliance with the centerline requirement impractical.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In complying with the Rules, of what must the mariner take due regard?
option_a: Limited backing power of his vessel
option_b: Radar information about nearby vessels
option_c: The occupation of the other vessel, if known
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: Rule 2 (Responsibility) requires due regard to all dangers of navigation and collision, and any special circumstances, including the limitations of the vessels involved. The specific options (a, b, and c) are examples of special circumstances or limitations that fall under the general requirement of taking "due regard."

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A "flashing light" is a light that __________.
option_a: flashes at regular intervals at a frequency of 120 flashes or more per minute
option_b: is yellow in color
option_c: is visible over an arc of the horizon of not less than 180° nor more than 225°
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 21(f) of the Navigation Rules defines a "Flashing light" as one flashing at regular intervals at a frequency of 120 flashes or more per minute. This directly matches option A.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway at night you are coming up on a vessel from astern.  Which light(s) would you expect to see?
option_b: Two masthead lights
option_c: Both sidelights and the stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is A because a vessel seen directly from astern only exhibits a sternlight. The sternlight covers an arc of 135 degrees from dead astern. This is covered in Rule 21(a) and Rule 23(a)(iv) for power-driven vessels underway, and Rule 25(a)(ii) for sailing vessels underway.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel would exhibit sidelights when underway and not making way?
option_b: A vessel not under command
option_c: A vessel engaged in dredging
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A power-driven vessel underway exhibits sidelights, regardless of whether it is making way or not. "Underway" means not at anchor, aground, or made fast to the shore. Rule 23 of the Navigation Rules dictates the lights for a power-driven vessel underway.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel would exhibit sidelights when underway and not making way?
option_b: A vessel not under command
option_c: A pilot vessel
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A pilot vessel, when engaged on pilotage duty, exhibits sidelights and masthead lights only when underway, even if not making way. This is covered in Rule 29(a)(iii). Other vessels mentioned would exhibit different lights when not making way.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What equipment for fog signals  is required for a vessel 20 meters in length?
option_b: Whistle only
option_c: Bell only
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 33 (a) of the COLREGs (International) states that a vessel 20 meters or more in length shall be provided with a whistle and a bell. Therefore, "Whistle and bell only" is correct for a 20-meter vessel. For Inland Rules, 33 CFR 86.05 references this same equipment.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel would exhibit sidelights when underway and not making way?
option_b: A vessel pushing ahead
option_c: A vessel engaged in dredging
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel pushing ahead exhibits sidelights per Rule 24(c)(ii). Sidelights are lights shown from the side of a vessel. Even if not making way, as long as it is "underway" it would exhibit these navigation lights. A vessel not under command, dredging, or trawling would exhibit different lights.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What is a "vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver"?
option_a: A deep-draft vessel that can only navigate in a dredged channel
option_b: A vessel fishing with a bottom trawl that must remain on course
option_c: A large tanker that is being towed as a dead ship to dry dock
option_d: A vessel laying revetment mats to provide bank protection along a channel
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: Option D is correct because vessels engaged in operations like laying revetment mats are restricted in their ability to maneuver by the nature of their work. This definition is found in Rule 3(g) of the USCG Navigation Rules. A vessel is "restricted" when it cannot comply with the rules due to its operation.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which day-shape should a vessel  being towed exhibit if the tow EXCEEDS 200 meters?
option_b: A cone, apex upward
option_c: A diamond
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "A diamond," is mandated for a vessel being towed when the length of the tow exceeds 200 meters. This requirement is found in Rule 24(e)(iii) of the USCG's Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook (COLREGs). The diamond shape indicates the extended length of the tow, aiding collision avoidance.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A sailing vessel underway at night MAY show __________.
option_a: a green light over a red light
option_b: a red light over a white light
option_c: two white lights at the stern
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A sailing vessel underway at night MUST exhibit sidelights and a sternlight (Rule 25(a)). It MAY combine these in one lantern if under 20m (Rule 25(b)). The lights listed in A, B, and C are incorrect for a standard sailing vessel, making D (None of the above) the correct answer.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel when anchored at night, would not be required to show anchor lights?
option_a: A vessel engaged in underwater operations
option_b: A vessel engaged in mine clearance
option_c: A vessel engaged on pilotage duty
option_d: A vessel engaged in survey operations
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in underwater operations is a vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver and exhibits lights under Rule 27(d), which are shown instead of the anchor lights required by Rule 30. See Rule 27(d)(iii) in the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel, when anchored at  night, is not required to show anchor lights?
option_b: A vessel engaged in survey operations
option_c: A vessel engaged on pilotage duty
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in fishing is not required to show anchor lights. Instead, it must exhibit the lights or shapes for a vessel engaged in fishing. This is covered in Rule 30 (e), which states a vessel engaged in fishing does not have to exhibit anchor lights when anchored.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What is the minimum sound signaling equipment required aboard a vessel 24 meters in length?
option_a: Any means of making an efficient sound signal
option_b: A bell only
option_c: A whistle only
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A vessel 20 meters or more in length is required to carry a whistle and a bell. 24 meters is greater than 20 meters, making the answer D correct (A bell and a whistle). This requirement is found in Rule 33(a) of the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A tug is towing three unmanned  barges astern in fog.  The third vessel of the tow should sound __________.
option_b: one short blast
option_c: one prolonged and three short blasts
option_d: one prolonged, one short, and one prolonged blast
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(g) requires a vessel being towed to sound a signal of one prolonged and three short blasts if manned. Unmanned barges are generally exempt from this requirement and sound no fog signal. The tug sounds the towing signal (Rule 35(c)). See also Rule 24 (Towing and Pushing).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE, according to the Rules?
option_a: A vessel engaged in fishing shall keep out of the way of a sailing vessel.
option_b: A vessel not under command shall keep out of the way of a vessel engaged in fishing.
option_c: A vessel engaged in fishing while underway shall, so far as possible, keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver.
option_d: A vessel not under command shall keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Option C is correct because a vessel engaged in fishing while underway must, so far as possible, keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver. This hierarchy of responsibilities between vessels is found in Rule 18 (Responsibilities between vessels).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  Which statement is TRUE, according to the Rules?
option_a: A vessel engaged in fishing shall keep out of the way of a sailing vessel.
option_b: A vessel engaged in fishing while underway shall, so far as possible, keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver.
option_c: A vessel not under command shall keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver.
option_d: A vessel not under command shall keep out of the way of a vessel engaged in fishing.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Vessels restricted in their ability to maneuver are higher in the "Pecking Order" of right-of-way than vessels engaged in fishing. Therefore, the fishing vessel must keep out of the way. This is detailed in Rule 18 (Responsibilities between Vessels).

question_text: INLAND ONLY  Which of the following signals  may be exhibited by a vessel trawling in close proximity to other fishing vessels?
option_a: Two white lights in a vertical line
option_b: A red light over a white light in a vertical line
option_c: Two fixed yellow lights in a vertical line
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Inland Rule 26(d) states that a vessel engaged in trawling may exhibit two all-round white lights in a vertical line when shooting, hauling, or operating their gear. This signal is often used when maneuvering near other fishing vessels. Rule 26.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Additional light signals are provided in the Annexes to the Rules for vessels __________.
option_b: engaged in fishing
option_c: engaged in towing
question_category: Annexes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is "engaged in fishing" (B). Annex II to the Rules provides additional signals for vessels engaged in fishing in close proximity to other vessels engaged in fishing. This is detailed in Rule 26(d) of the COLREGs/Navigation Rules Handbook.

question_text: INLAND ONLY  Vessels engaged in fishing may  show the additional signals described in Annex II to the Rules when they are __________.
option_b: fishing in a traffic separation zone
option_c: in close proximity to other vessels engaged in fishing
question_category: Annexes
answer_explanation: Annex II, which addresses additional signals, is referenced in Rule 26(f) of the Inland Rules. It allows vessels engaged in fishing to show these signals when "in close proximity to other vessels engaged in fishing" to indicate that they are hampered by their gear.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A distress signal __________.
option_a: consists of 5 or more short blasts of the fog signal apparatus
option_b: consists of the raising and lowering of a large white flag
option_c: may be used separately or with other distress signals
option_d: is used to indicate doubt about another vessel's intentions
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer is C because distress signals, as listed in Annex IV/Rule 37 of the Navigation Rules, may be used individually or in combination with other approved signals (e.g., flares and Mayday call). See 33 CFR § 83.37 for Rule 37 (Distress Signals).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel may use any sound or light signals to attract the attention of another vessel as long as __________.
option_b: red and green lights are not used
option_c: the signal cannot be mistaken for a signal authorized by the Rules
option_d: the vessel signals such intentions over the radiotelephone
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Option C is correct because a vessel may use sound or light signals to attract attention only if the signal cannot be mistaken for an authorized signal. This is found in Rule 36: Signals to attract attention (33 CFR § 83.36).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND One of the signals, other than a distress signal, that can be used by a vessel to attract attention is a(n) __________.
option_b: searchlight
option_c: burning barrel
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, 'searchlight' (B), is authorized under Rule 36 (Signals to Attract Attention) of the COLREGs/Inland Rules. A vessel may "direct the beam of her searchlight in the direction of the danger" to attract attention without being mistaken for other signals.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In restricted visibility a towed vessel must sound a fog signal when it is __________.
option_a: the last vessel in the tow
option_b: the last vessel in the tow and it is carrying a crew
option_c: manned, regardless of its position in the tow
option_d: None of the above are correct
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation:
Rule 35(g) states that a vessel being towed or pushed, if manned, shall at intervals of not more than 2 minutes sound 4 short blasts. If unmanned, only the last vessel in the tow must sound the signal (4 short blasts) if manned. However, Rule 35(g)(ii) specifically states that when a manned vessel is being towed, the signal prescribed in Rule 35(g)(i) shall be sounded by an interval of not more than 2 minutes by the last vessel of the tow, if manned.

The correct choice B, "the last vessel in the tow and it is carrying a crew," is a simplification of Rule 35(g)(ii). The full rule is complex, but this option reflects the requirement for the last vessel in a tow to sound a signal if it is manned. However, the rule generally states a manned vessel being towed sounds 4 short blasts every 2 minutes. The question may be simplified for test purposes.

The correct answer (B) is derived from COLREG Rule 35(g)(ii). When in restricted visibility, the last vessel of a tow, if manned, shall sound a fog signal of four short blasts at intervals of not more than 2 minutes. The question's option B aligns with this requirement.

See USCG Navigation Rules, Rule 35(g)(ii). The last vessel in the tow must sound a signal (4 short blasts) if it is manned.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are approaching a narrow channel.  Another vessel in the channel can only be navigated safely in that channel.  You should __________.
option_a: not cross the channel if you might impede the other vessel
option_b: hold your course and speed if she is on your port bow
option_c: sound three short blasts, and take all way off your vessel
option_d: sound two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Option A is correct because a vessel must not cross a narrow channel or fairway if it impedes the passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within that channel or fairway. This is covered under Rule 9(d) of the USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  You are the stand-on vessel in a crossing situation.  If you think the give-way vessel is NOT taking sufficient action to avoid collision, you should sound __________.
option_a: one short blast and maintain course
option_b: five short and rapid blasts
option_c: no signal and maneuver at will
option_d: two short blasts, alter to port, and pass astern
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(d) of the Navigation Rules states that a vessel nearing a bend or an area where other vessels may be obscured must sound one prolonged blast. The question is incorrect; the signal for a stand-on vessel to warn a give-way vessel is five short and rapid blasts, found in Rule 34(d).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  Which statement is TRUE, according to the Rules?
option_a: A vessel not under command shall keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver.
option_b: A vessel not under command shall keep out of the way of a vessel engaged in fishing.
option_c: A vessel engaged in fishing while underway shall, so far as possible, keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver.
option_d: A vessel engaged in fishing shall keep out of the way of a sailing vessel.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Vessels restricted in their ability to maneuver have higher priority than fishing vessels. Therefore, a vessel engaged in fishing must keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver. This is covered in Rule 18 of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are approaching a narrow channel.  Another vessel in the channel can only be navigated safely in that channel.  You should __________.
option_a: hold your course and speed if he is on your port bow
option_b: sound three short blasts, and take all way off your vessel
option_c: not cross the channel if you might impede the other vessel
option_d: sound two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 9(d) of the USCG Navigation Rules states that a vessel shall not cross a narrow channel if such crossing impedes the passage of a vessel that can safely navigate only within that channel. Therefore, option C is correct, as you must not impede the other vessel.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway in fog, you hear a vessel ahead sound two prolonged blasts on the whistle. You should __________.
option_a: sound two blasts and change course to the left
option_b: sound whistle signals only if you change course
option_c: not sound any whistle signals until the other vessel is sighted
option_d: sound only fog signals until the other vessel is sighted
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer is D because two prolonged blasts from a vessel ahead in restricted visibility is its fog signal (Rule 35(b) - Power-driven vessel underway, making way). You must continue sounding your own required fog signal (Rule 35) until the other vessel is sighted or you have determined no risk of collision exists.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  You are the stand-on vessel in a crossing situation.  If you think the give-way vessel is  NOT taking sufficient action to avoid collision, you should sound __________.
option_b: two short blasts, alter to port, and pass astern
option_c: no signal and maneuver at will
option_d: one short blast and maintain course
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer is "the danger signal" (five or more short, rapid blasts) because the stand-on vessel must sound this signal if she determines the give-way vessel is not taking sufficient action. This is mandated by Rule 34(d).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  A vessel engaged in  mineclearance operations shows special identity lights __________.
option_b: which mean that other vessels should not approach within 1000 meters
option_c: that are 225° green lights
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in mineclearance operations exhibits three all-round green lights to indicate that other vessels must not approach within 1000 meters. This is found in Rule 27(f) of the COLREGs/Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are about to cross a narrow channel when you see an approaching vessel that can only be navigated safely within the channel.  You should __________.
option_a: cross the channel as you are the stand-on vessel
option_b: cross only if the vessel in the channel is approaching on your port side
option_c: not cross the channel if you might impede the other vessel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation:
A vessel crossing a narrow channel shall not impede the passage of a vessel that can safely navigate only within that channel. Option C aligns with this requirement. This is covered in Rule 9 (d) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.
Ref: 33 CFR 83.09 (d).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  What is a light signal authorized by the Secretary of the Navy as an additional navigational light for a ship of war?
option_a: Two yellow lights in a vertical line for a carrier  launching aircraft
option_b: Green masthead and yardarm lights for a vessel engaged in mineclearing operations
option_c: Flashing amber beacon for submarines
option_d: Yellow flares indicating torpedo firing exercises
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, C, is a Flashing amber beacon for submarines. Rule 1(e) of the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (COLREGs) and the Inland Navigation Rules allows the Secretary of the Navy to authorize special lights for vessels of war. The specific authorization is found in 32 CFR § 707.13, Special flashing light for submarines.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND According to the Navigation Rules, you may depart from the Rules when __________.
option_a: you do so to avoid immediate danger
option_b: no vessels are visible on radar
option_c: you are in a close quarters situation
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "you do so to avoid immediate danger," is found in Rule 2(b) - Responsibility. This rule permits a necessary departure from the Rules to avoid immediate danger, considering all dangers of navigation and special circumstances.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The Rules state that vessels may depart from the requirements of the Rules when __________.
option_b: operating in a narrow channel
option_c: necessary to avoid immediate danger
option_d: the Master enters it in the ship's log
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: The correct answer is C because Rule 2(b) of the Navigation Rules (General Prudential Rule) states that departure from the Rules is necessary to avoid immediate danger. This rule emphasizes that while following the Rules is paramount, preventing a collision or danger takes precedence.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The Rules state that vessels may depart from the Rules when __________.
option_a: there are other vessels in the vicinity
option_b: operating in a traffic separation scheme
option_c: engaged in a situation involving more than two vessels
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: The correct answer, D ("necessary to avoid immediate danger"), is based on Rule 2(b) (Responsibility). This rule states that a departure from the Rules may be necessary to avoid immediate danger, prioritizing safety over strict adherence to the regulations.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The term "restricted visibility", when used in the Rules, refers to __________.
option_a: situations when you can see vessels on radar that you cannot see visually
option_b: visibility of less than half a mile
option_c: any condition where visibility is restricted
option_d: visibility where you cannot see shore
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "any condition where visibility is restricted," is found in Rule 3(l) of the COLREGs (which is adopted by the USCG in the Navigation Rules), defining "restricted visibility" as any condition where visibility is restricted by fog, mist, falling snow, heavy rainstorms, sandstorms, or any other similar causes. This broadly covers option C.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The Navigation Rules define a "vessel not under command" as a vessel which __________.
option_a: from the nature of her work is unable to keep out of the way of another vessel
option_b: does not have a proper look-out
option_c: by taking action contrary to the Rules has created a special circumstance situation
option_d: through some exceptional circumstance is unable to maneuver as required by the Rules
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Option D is the correct definition for a "vessel not under command" because it accurately describes a vessel unable to maneuver due to an exceptional circumstance. This definition is found in the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook, Rule 3(f).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which craft is a "power-driven  vessel" under the Rules of the Road?
option_a: An auxiliary sailing vessel, using her engine
option_b: A canoe propelled by a small outboard motor
option_c: A trawler on her way to the fishing grounds
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: A "power-driven vessel" is defined as any vessel propelled by machinery (Rule 3(b)). An auxiliary sailing vessel using its engine, a canoe with an outboard motor, and a trawler all fit this definition. Therefore, "All of the above" is correct. Refer to 33 CFR § 83.03 (Rule 3).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel is "in sight" of another vessel when she __________.
option_b: has determined that risk of collision exists
option_c: is sounding a fog signal which can be heard on the other vessel
option_d: can be observed visually from the other vessel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, D, is defined by the rule. Vessels are "in sight" only when one can be observed visually from the other. This is stated in Rule 3(k) of the USCG's Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook, which defines the general definitions for both International and Inland Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning a "vessel engaged in fishing"?
option_a: The vessel is classified as "restricted in her ability to maneuver".
option_b: Her gear will not affect the vessel's maneuverability.
option_c: The vessel may be using nets, lines, or trawls.
option_d: She sounds the same fog signal as a vessel underway but stopped and making no way.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct statement, C, is based on the definition in Rule 3(d). A "vessel engaged in fishing" includes any vessel using fishing gear such as nets, lines, or trawls, provided this apparatus restricts maneuverability. This definition is consistent across International and Inland Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  To be considered "engaged in fishing" under the Rules, a vessel must be __________.
option_b: showing lights or shapes for a vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver
option_c: using nets
option_d: using fishing apparatus which restricts maneuverability
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: Rule 3(d) of the Navigation Rules defines "a vessel engaged in fishing" as any vessel fishing with nets, lines, trawls, or other fishing apparatus which restrict maneuverability. The key is the restriction on maneuverability.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The word "vessel", in the Rules, includes __________.
option_a: a barge permanently affixed to the shore
option_b: nondisplacement craft
option_c: a drilling unit attached to the Outer Continental Shelf
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: The word "vessel" includes every description of water craft, including nondisplacement craft. Rule 3(a) of the Navigation Rules explicitly states this inclusion. Options A and C describe structures generally considered not "capable of being used as a means of transportation on water." (Rule 3(a))

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel is, by definition, unable to keep out of the way of another vessel?
option_b: Vessel not making way
option_c: Vessel sailing
option_d: Vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, Vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver, is defined in Rule 3(g) as a vessel that is "restricted in her ability to maneuver as required by these Rules and is therefore unable to keep out of the way of another vessel." See Rule 3.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel "restricted in her ability to maneuver" is one which __________.
option_a: through some exceptional circumstance is unable to  maneuver as required by the Rules
option_b: from the nature of her work is unable to maneuver as required by the Rules
option_c: due to adverse weather conditions is unable to maneuver as required by the Rules
option_d: has lost steering and is unable to maneuver
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: Rule 3(g) of the Navigation Rules defines a vessel "restricted in her ability to maneuver" as one which, from the nature of her work, is unable to keep out of the way of another vessel. Option B accurately reflects this definition.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What determines if a vessel is  "restricted in her ability to maneuver"?
option_a: Whether or not all of the vessel's control equipment is in working order
option_b: The vessel's draft in relation to the available depth of water
option_c: Whether the vessel is operating in a narrow channel
option_d: The nature of the vessel's work, limiting maneuverability required by the Rules
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, D, is based on the definition found in Rule 3(g) of the USCG Navigation Rules. A vessel "restricted in her ability to maneuver" is limited by the nature of its work, which prevents it from complying with the Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  A vessel is considered to be "restricted in her ability to maneuver" under the Rules if  she is __________.
option_b: mineclearing
option_c: engaged in fishing
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "mineclearing," is one of the operations that classifies a vessel as "restricted in her ability to maneuver." Other options like "at anchor," "engaged in fishing," and "engaged in towing" have separate classifications under the Rules. This is defined in Rule 3(g) and further detailed in Rule 27 of the USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel transferring cargo while underway is classified by the Rules as a vessel __________.
option_a: restricted in her ability to maneuver
option_b: in special circumstances
option_c: not under command
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: A vessel transferring cargo while underway is considered "restricted in her ability to maneuver" because the nature of the work impedes her ability to deviate from her course. See Rule 3(g) of the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  Which vessel is "underway" according to the Rules?
option_a: A vessel made fast to a single point mooring buoy
option_b: A vessel engaged in towing, not making way
option_c: A pilot vessel at anchor
option_d: A vessel which has run aground
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: A vessel is "underway" if it is not at anchor, made fast to the shore, or aground. "A vessel engaged in towing, not making way" meets this definition, as confirmed in Rule 3(i) (General definitions) of the Navigation Rules. The other options are either made fast (A), at anchor (C), or aground (D).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND According to the Rules, a vessels length is her __________.
option_b: length along the waterline
option_c: length overall
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation:
Rule 3(a) of the COLREGS (International & Inland Rules) defines "The word 'vessel' includes every description of water craft...". While the Rules use "length" frequently (e.g., for light and shape requirements), Rule 3 does not explicitly define a vessel's length as her "length overall." However, "length overall" is the general standard used throughout the Rules for determining compliance requirements.

Length overall (LOA) is used when defining vessel size for requirements such as lights, shapes, and fog signals (e.g., Rule 21/23). See Rule 3(a) and Rules 21, 23, and 33.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  What does the word "breadth" mean in the Rules?
option_a: Breadth on the uppermost continuous deck
option_b: Molded breadth
option_c: Greatest breadth
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: The word "breadth" in the Rules means the "Greatest breadth" of a vessel, making C the correct answer. This definition is established in the General Definitions under Rule 3(j) of the Navigation Rules, which applies to both International and Inland Waters.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In determining "safe speed", the Rules list all of the following as factors which must be taken into account EXCEPT the __________.
option_b: presence of background lights at night
option_c: maximum horsepower of your vessel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 6 (Safe Speed) lists factors for determining safe speed, including visibility, traffic density, maneuverability, and radar limitations. Maximum horsepower of the vessel is NOT listed as a required factor to take into account.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The rules require which factor  to be taken into account when determining safe speed?
option_b: The experience of the vessel's crew
option_c: The location of vessels detected by radar
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "The location of vessels detected by radar," is a factor specifically required to be considered for vessels with operational radar when determining safe speed, as detailed in Rule 6(b)(v) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND The Rules state that certain factors are to be taken into account when determining safe speed.  One of the factors is the __________.
option_b: maximum speed of your vessel
option_c: temperature
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Current is a factor listed under environmental conditions that must be considered when determining a safe speed. Adverse current can significantly affect a vessel's speed over the ground and maneuverability. This is detailed in Rule 6, Safe Speed, of the USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook (33 CFR § 83.06).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND "safe speed" is defined as that speed where __________.
option_a: you can stop within your visibility range
option_b: the vessel is not subject to vibrations
option_c: you are traveling slower than surrounding vessels
option_d: you can take proper and effective action to avoid collision
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Option D is correct because safe speed is defined as the speed where you can take proper and effective action to avoid collision. This is covered in Rule 6 - Safe Speed of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  The Rules state that risk of collision shall be deemed to exist __________.
option_a: whenever two vessels are on opposite courses
option_b: whenever a vessel crosses ahead of the intended track of another vessel
option_c: if the bearing of an approaching vessel does not appreciably change
option_d: if one vessel approaches another so as to be overtaking
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 7 of the Navigation Rules states that risk of collision shall be deemed to exist "if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does not appreciably change." This is reflected in option C. (33 CFR § 83.07)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND.  In which situation would you  consider a risk of collision to exist?
option_a: A vessel is one point on your starboard bow, range  increasing, bearing changing slightly to the right.
option_b: A vessel is broad on your starboard beam, range decreasing, bearing changing rapidly to the right.
option_c: A vessel is two points abaft your port beam, range  decreasing, bearing constant.
option_d: A vessel is on your starboard quarter, range increasing, bearing is constant.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Risk of collision is deemed to exist if the compass bearing of an approaching vessel does not appreciably change, especially if range is decreasing. "Bearing constant" and "range decreasing" is the classic indicator. This is found in Rule 7 (Risk of collision) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  What is TRUE when operating in fog and other vessels are detected by radar?
option_a: You should make an ample change to port for a vessel crossing on the starboard bow.
option_b: You should maneuver in ample time if a close-quarters situation is developing.
option_c: You should determine the course and speed of all radar contacts at six minute intervals.
option_d: Long-range scanning will provide early warning of ALL other vessels within the radar's range.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 19(d) of the Navigation Rules states a vessel detecting another by radar shall determine if a close-quarters situation is developing and, if so, take avoiding action in ample time. The correct answer (B) aligns with this rule.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are approaching another vessel on crossing courses.  She is about one mile distant  and is on your starboard bow.  You believe she will cross ahead of you but she sounds a whistle signal of five short  blasts.  You should __________.
option_a: answer the signal and hold course and speed
option_b: reduce speed slightly
option_c: initiate a passing signal that will allow for a half mile clearance
option_d: make a large course change, and slow down if necessary
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Five short blasts are the danger signal (Rule 34(d)). As the give-way vessel (Rule 15), you must take immediate, ample action (Rule 8) to avoid collision, since the other vessel indicates danger/disagreement. A large course change and reducing speed is the proper response.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are approaching another vessel on crossing courses.  She is approximately half a mile distant on your starboard bow.  You believe she will cross ahead of you but she sounds a whistle signal of five  short blasts.  You should __________.
option_a: sound a signal of one prolonged blast
option_b: make a large course change
option_c: reduce speed slightly to make sure she will have room to pass
option_d: wait for another whistle signal from the other vessel
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Five short blasts is the danger signal (Rule 34(d)). The stand-on vessel, believing the other vessel will cross ahead, should take immediate, substantial action to avoid collision (Rule 17(a)(ii) and Rule 8(b)). A large course change is the proper maneuver.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  Under the Rules, any vessel may slacken her speed, stop, or reverse her engines to  __________.
option_b: allow more time to assess the situation
option_c: attract the attention of another vessel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The answer is correct based on Rule 8(e) of the Navigation Rules (33 CFR 83.08(e)), which applies to both International and Inland waters. This rule explicitly states that a vessel shall slacken her speed or take all way off if necessary to avoid collision or "allow more time to assess the situation."

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND When in sight of another vessel and there is sufficient sea room, any action taken to avoid collision must __________.
option_b: not result in another close quarters situation
option_c: include a speed change
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 8, Action to avoid collision, states that any action must be substantial enough to avoid a close-quarters situation and result in passing at a safe distance. See Rule 8(d) in the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  A vessel approaching a narrow  channel shall __________.
option_a: avoid crossing the channel if it impedes another vessel navigating in the channel
option_b: not overtake any vessels within the channel
option_c: keep as close as possible to the edge of the channel on her port side
option_d: anchor only in the middle of the channel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Answer A is correct because Rule 9(d) of the Navigation Rules (Narrow Channels) states that a vessel shall not cross a narrow channel if such crossing impedes the passage of a vessel that can safely navigate only within that channel.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  When underway in a channel, you should if safe and practicable __________.
option_a: stay near the middle of the channel
option_b: keep to the starboard side of any vessels you meet
option_c: exchange whistle signals with any other vessels in the channel
option_d: keep to the side of the channel which lies to your starboard
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, D, is based on Rule 9(a) (Narrow Channels) of the Navigation Rules, which states a vessel proceeding along a narrow channel or fairway shall keep as near to the outer limit of the channel or fairway which lies on her starboard side as is safe and practicable.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  A sailing vessel is proceeding along a narrow channel and can safely navigate ONLY inside  the channel.  The sailing vessel approaches a vessel engaged in fishing in the narrow channel.  Which statement is TRUE?
option_a: Each vessel should move to the edge of the channel on her port side.
option_b: The vessels are required to exchange signals.
option_c: The fishing vessel is directed not to impede the passage of the sailing vessel.
option_d: Each vessel should be displaying signals for a vessel constrained by her draft.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 9(b) of the Navigation Rules states that a vessel engaged in fishing shall not impede the passage of any vessel navigating in a narrow channel. This means the fishing vessel must yield to the sailing vessel which can only safely navigate within the channel. (Rule 9 - Narrow Channels)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  A vessel engaged in  mineclearance operations shows special identity lights __________.
option_a: in addition to the lights required for a power-driven vessel
option_b: which means that other vessels should not approach closer than 500 meters on either side of the vessel
option_c: that are green and show through an arc of the horizon of 225°
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel engaged in mine clearance operations must exhibit the lights for a power-driven vessel in addition to three all-round green lights (in a vertical line where they can best be seen). This is found in Rule 27(f).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND When navigating in thick fog with the radar on, you should __________.
option_a: station the look-out in the wheelhouse to keep a continuous watch on the radar
option_b: secure the sounding of fog signals until a vessel closes within five miles
option_c: station a look-out as low down and far forward as possible
option_d: keep the radar on the shortest available range for early detection of approaching vessels
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 5 requires a proper look-out by sight & hearing. In thick fog, a look-out stationed low and forward maximizes the chance of hearing faint fog signals and seeing low-lying vessels or debris early, even with radar on. This improves collision risk appraisal.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are underway in thick fog.  You have not determined if risk of collision exists. Which statement is TRUE?
option_a: Your speed must be reduced to bare steerageway.
option_b: A look-out is not required if the radar is on.
option_c: Fog signals are only required when a vessel is detected by radar.
option_d: The radar should always be kept on a short-range scale.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 19(b) requires every vessel to proceed at a safe speed adapted to restricted visibility. If a vessel detects another forward of her beam or cannot avoid a close-quarters situation, Rule 19(e) states she shall reduce her speed to the minimum at which she can be kept on her course (bare steerageway).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A sailing vessel is proceeding  along a narrow channel and can safely navigate ONLY inside  the channel.  The sailing vessel approaches a vessel engaged in fishing.  Which statement is TRUE?
option_a: The fishing vessel must sound the danger signal.
option_b: The fishing vessel shall not impede the passage of the sailing vessel.
option_c: Each vessel should move to the edge of the channel on her port side.
option_d: Both vessels should be displaying the signal for a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 9(b) of the Narrow Channel rules states a vessel of less than 20 meters in length or a sailing vessel shall not impede the passage of a vessel that can safely navigate only within a narrow channel. As the sailing vessel is restricted to the channel, the fishing vessel must not impede its passage.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which vessel shall NOT impede the passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel or fairway?
option_b: A sailing vessel
option_c: A vessel servicing an aid to navigation
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 9 states that a sailing vessel (option B), a vessel less than 20m, or a vessel engaged in fishing shall not impede the passage of a vessel that can only safely navigate within a narrow channel or fairway. A vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver (like dredging or servicing an aid to navigation) is not required to yield.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  Your 15-meter vessel is crossing a narrow channel and a large cargo vessel to starboard is within the channel and crossing your course. You should __________.
option_b: sound the danger signal
option_c: keep out of the way of the cargo vessel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 9(d) of the Navigation Rules states a vessel should not cross a narrow channel if it impedes a vessel that can only safely navigate within it, such as a large cargo vessel. Your 15-meter vessel must keep out of the way of the large cargo vessel. This is found in Rule 9 (Narrow Channels).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND If two sailing vessels are running free with the wind on the same side, which one must keep clear of the other?
option_a: The one with the wind closest abeam
option_b: The one to windward
option_c: The one to leeward
option_d: The one that sounds the first whistle signal
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 12 (Sailing Vessels) states that when two sailing vessels have the wind on the same side, the vessel which is to windward shall keep out of the way of the vessel which is to leeward. Therefore, "The one to windward" (B) must keep clear.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Which statement is TRUE concerning two sailing vessels approaching each other?
option_a: The vessel making the most speed is the give-way vessel.
option_b: A sailing vessel overtaking another is the give-way vessel.
option_c: A sailing vessel seeing another to leeward on an undetermined tack shall hold her course.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 13 (Overtaking) states that any vessel overtaking another shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken. This applies to all vessels, including sailing vessels, and makes the overtaking vessel the give-way vessel.
