question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  Power-driven vessels must keep out of the way of sailing vessels except __________.
option_b: when they are making more speed than the power-driven vessel
option_c: when the sailing vessel is overtaking
option_d: on the Inland Waters of the United States
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer is C because, under the Overtaking Rule (Rule 13), any vessel overtaking another—regardless of hierarchy established in Rules 4 through 18—must keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken. In this scenario, if the sailing vessel is overtaking, it becomes the give-way vessel. See Rule 13 in the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  When do the Rules require both vessels to change course?
option_a: Any time the danger signal is sounded
option_b: When two power-driven vessels are crossing and it is apparent to the stand-on vessel that the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action
option_c: When two power-driven vessels are meeting head-on
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, 'C' (When two power-driven vessels are meeting head-on), is based on Rule 14 (Head-on Situation). This rule requires each power-driven vessel to alter its course to starboard so that each shall pass on the port side of the other when meeting on reciprocal or nearly reciprocal courses.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Your vessel is NOT making way,  but is not in any way disabled.  Another vessel is  approaching you on your starboard beam.  Which statement is TRUE?
option_a: Your vessel is obligated to stay out of the way.
option_b: The other vessel must give way, since your vessel is stopped.
option_c: You should be showing the lights or shapes for a vessel not under command.
option_d: You should be showing the lights or shapes for a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Even though you are not making way, your vessel is underway and considered a power-driven vessel. In a crossing situation, when the other vessel is on your starboard side, you are the give-way vessel per Rule 15. Your obligation to keep out of the way is outlined in Rule 16. The vessel is not "not under command" (Rule 3(f)) or "restricted in her ability to maneuver" (Rule 3(g)).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND If you are the stand-on vessel  in a crossing situation, you may take action to avoid collision by your maneuver alone.  When may this action be  taken?
option_a: As soon as you determine that risk of collision exists
option_b: Only when you have reached extremis
option_c: When it becomes apparent to you that the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action
option_d: When you determine that your present course will cross ahead of the other vessel
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The stand-on vessel must maintain course and speed until it becomes apparent that the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action. At this point, the stand-on vessel may take action to avoid collision. This is covered by Rule 17 (Action by Stand-on Vessel) of the COLREGs/USCG’s Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  In a crossing situation on open waters, a sailing vessel shall keep out of the way of all the following vessels EXCEPT a vessel __________.
option_b: restricted in her ability to maneuver
option_c: engaged in towing
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 18(b) (Responsibilities between vessels) states a sailing vessel underway must keep out of the way of a vessel not under command, restricted in her ability to maneuver, and engaged in fishing. A vessel engaged in towing is not listed, making it the exception.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND What would be a "special circumstance" under the Rules?
option_b: Two vessels meeting
option_c: Speed in fog
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: The Rules cover two-vessel encounters (meeting, crossing, overtaking). When more than two vessels are involved in a crossing situation, it creates an abnormal situation not explicitly covered by the Rules and is thus considered a "special circumstance" that requires mariner judgment to avoid immediate danger (COLREGS/Inland Rule 2, Responsibility).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In restricted visibility, a vessel being towed, if manned, shall sound a signal of __________.
option_a: one prolonged and three short blasts
option_b: one prolonged and two short blasts
option_c: three short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer is A because, under Rule 35(f) (Restricted Visibility), a manned vessel being towed must sound one prolonged blast followed by three short blasts at intervals of not more than 2 minutes. This is in addition to the towing vessel's signal.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You are approaching a narrow channel.  Another vessel in the channel can only be navigated safely in that channel.  You should __________.
option_a: sound two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast
option_b: not cross the channel if you might impede the other vessel
option_c: sound three short blasts, and take all way off your vessel
option_d: hold your course and speed if he is on your port bow
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The vessel that can safely navigate only within the narrow channel has the right-of-way. Therefore, you should not cross the channel if you might impede that vessel. This aligns with Rule 9(d) of the International & Inland Navigation Rules (33 CFR 83.09(d)).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  You are the stand-on vessel in a crossing situation.  If you think the give-way vessel is  NOT taking sufficient action to avoid collision, you should sound __________.
option_a: one short blast and maintain course
option_b: two short blasts, alter to port, and pass astern
option_c: the danger signal
option_d: no signal and maneuver at will
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The answer is C because Rule 34(d) of the COLREGS (Inland and International) states that if the stand-on vessel doubts the sufficiency of the give-way vessel's action, they must sound the danger signal (5 or more short and rapid blasts).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway in fog, you hear a vessel ahead sound two prolonged blasts on the whistle. You should __________.
option_a: sound only fog signals until the other vessel is sighted
option_b: not sound any whistle signals until the other vessel is sighted
option_c: sound two blasts and change course to the left
option_d: sound whistle signals only if you change course
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The two prolonged blasts mean the vessel ahead is a power-driven vessel stopped and not making way in restricted visibility (Rule 35(b)). You must take necessary precautions to avoid collision (Rule 19(b)) and, upon hearing a fog signal forward of the beam, reduce speed to bare steerage way (Rule 19(d)(i)). You must not sound maneuvering or warning blasts in restricted visibility (Rule 19(e)); only fog signals (Rule 35) are appropriate.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Lighting requirements in inland waters are different from those for international waters for __________.
option_b: vessels not under command
option_c: vessels pushing ahead
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "vessels pushing ahead," is due to the Inland Rules requiring a special flashing light on a vessel being pushed ahead (not part of a composite unit) or towed alongside, which is not required in International Rules. See Rule 24 (i) and (ii) for Inland Rules regarding the special flashing light.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND There are two classes of vessels which do not have to comply with the rule regarding traffic separation schemes, to the extent necessary to carry out their work.  One of those is a vessel __________.
option_b: towing another
option_c: servicing a navigational aid
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation:
Vessels restricted in their ability to maneuver when engaged in operations such as servicing a navigational aid are exempt from Rule 10 (Traffic Separation Schemes) to the extent necessary to carry out their work.

Reference: COLREG Rule 10(l)

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In a traffic separation scheme, when joining a traffic lane from the side, a vessel shall do so __________.
option_a: only in case of an emergency or to engage in fishing within the zone
option_b: as nearly as practical at right angles to the general direction of traffic flow
option_c: at as small an angle as possible
option_d: only to anchor within the zone
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, C, aligns with Rule 10(b)(iii) of the COLREGS (International & Inland). When joining or leaving a traffic lane from the side, a vessel must do so at as small an angle to the general direction of traffic flow as practicable.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A traffic separation zone is that part of a traffic separation scheme which __________.
option_a: is located between the scheme and the nearest land
option_b: separates traffic proceeding in one direction from traffic  proceeding in the opposite direction
option_c: is designated as an anchorage area
option_d: contains all the traffic moving in the same direction
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, B, is because a traffic separation zone is designed to separate opposing traffic streams within a traffic separation scheme. This is explicitly covered under Rule 10 (Traffic separation schemes) in the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel using a traffic separation scheme shall __________.
option_a: avoid anchoring in areas near the termination of the scheme
option_b: avoid crossing traffic lanes, but if obliged to do so, shall cross on as small an angle as is practical
option_c: only anchor in the separation zone
option_d: use the separation zone for navigating through the scheme if she is hindering other traffic due to her slower speed
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 10(g) states a vessel shall so far as practicable avoid anchoring in a traffic separation scheme or in areas near its terminations. This aligns with option A. You can find this in Rule 10, Traffic Separation Schemes, in the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel using a traffic separation scheme shall NOT __________.
option_b: engage in fishing the separation zone
option_c: proceed in an inappropriate traffic lane
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 10(b)(i) states a vessel using a Traffic Separation Scheme (TSS) shall "proceed in the appropriate traffic lane in the general direction of traffic flow for that lane." Therefore, a vessel shall NOT proceed in an inappropriate traffic lane. Ref: 33 CFR 83.10 (Rule 10).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel using a traffic separation scheme shall __________.
option_a: only anchor  in the separation zone
option_b: avoid crossing traffic lanes, but if obliged to do so, shall cross on a heading at as small an angle as is practical
option_c: avoid anchoring in areas near the termination of the scheme
option_d: use the separation zone for navigation through the scheme if she is hindering other traffic due to her slower speed
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "avoid anchoring in areas near the termination of the scheme," aligns with Rule 10(g) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook (COLREGs), which states that a vessel shall "so far as practicable avoid anchoring in a traffic separation scheme or in areas near its terminations."

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway in fog, you hear a vessel ahead sound two prolonged blasts on the whistle. You should __________.
option_a: sound two blasts and change course to the left
option_b: sound only fog signals until the other vessel is sighted
option_c: sound whistle signals only if you change course
option_d: not sound any whistle signals until the other vessel is sighted
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The two prolonged blasts indicate a power-driven vessel underway but stopped and making no way through the water in restricted visibility (Rule 35(b)). You must only sound fog signals until the vessel is sighted. Using maneuvering signals (short blasts) is prohibited when vessels are not visible. See Rule 35.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  A vessel towing astern and her tow are severely restricted in their ability to change course. When making way, the towing vessel will show ONLY __________.
option_a: the masthead lights for a towing vessel
option_b: the lights for a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
option_c: sidelights, stern light, and towing light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel towing astern is considered a "vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver" due to the tow, per Rule 3(g). Therefore, it must show the lights for a towing vessel (Rule 24(a)), which includes masthead lights, sidelights, and a sternlight. Additionally, Rule 24(d) requires compliance with Rule 23(a)(ii). The question combines all the required lights under "All of the above." Rule 24 and Rule 3(g) are applicable.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  You hear the fog signal of another vessel forward of your beam.  Risk of collision may exist. You MUST __________.
option_a: take all way off, if necessary
option_b: stop your engines
option_c: begin a radar plot
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 19(e) states a vessel hearing a fog signal forward of her beam, or which cannot avoid a close-quarters situation, must reduce speed to the minimum necessary to maintain course, and shall, if necessary, take all way off. This makes option A correct. Rule 19(e) is found in the USCG Navigation Rules Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A fog signal of one short, one  prolonged, and one short blast may be sounded by a __________.
option_b: vessel at anchor
option_c: vessel towing
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The fog signal of one short, one prolonged, and one short blast is an optional warning signal for a vessel at anchor to signal its position and the possibility of collision with an approaching vessel. This is permitted under Rule 35(g) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  You hear the fog signal of another vessel forward of your beam.  Risk of collision may exist. You MUST __________.
option_b: take all way off, if necessary
option_c: begin a radar plot
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: COLREGS Rule 19(e) states that a vessel hearing a fog signal forward of her beam must reduce speed to the minimum necessary to maintain course, and "shall if necessary take all her way off." This is found in the USCG Navigation Rules Handbook, Rule 19 (Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel may enter a traffic separation zone __________.
option_b: to engage in fishing within the zone
option_c: to cross the traffic separation scheme
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 10(b)(iii) of the COLREGS allows a vessel to enter a traffic separation zone: in an emergency to avoid immediate danger; to engage in fishing within the zone; or to cross the traffic separation scheme. Since all options (A, B, and C) are listed exceptions, "All of the above" (D) is the correct choice.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In a traffic separation scheme, when joining a traffic lane from the side, a vessel shall do so __________.
option_a: at as small an angle as possible
option_b: as nearly as practical at right angles to the general direction of traffic flow
option_c: only in case of an emergency or to engage in fishing within the zone
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 10(b)(iii) of the USCG Navigation Rules states that a vessel joining or leaving a traffic lane from either side shall do so "at as small an angle to the general direction of traffic flow as practicable." This minimizes interference with other vessels in the lane.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel using a traffic separation scheme is forbidden to __________.
option_a: proceed through an inappropriate traffic lane
option_b: engaged in fishing in the separation zone
option_c: cross a traffic lane
option_d: enter the separation zone, even in a emergency
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 10(b)(ii) of the USCG Navigation Rules states that a vessel shall so far as practicable avoid crossing traffic lanes, but if obliged to cross shall do so as nearly as practicable at right angles to the general direction of traffic flow. Proceeding through an inappropriate lane (Option A) violates Rule 10(b)(i), which mandates using the appropriate lane. Rule 10(b)(i) and 10(b)(ii).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A traffic separation zone is that part of a traffic separation scheme which  __________.
option_a: is between the scheme and the nearest land
option_b: contains all the traffic moving in one direction
option_c: is designated as an anchorage area
option_d: separates traffic proceeding in one direction from traffic  proceeding in the opposite direction
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer is D because a traffic separation zone separates traffic proceeding in one direction from traffic proceeding in the opposite direction. This definition is found in Rule 10, Traffic Separation Schemes, of the COLREGs/USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY To indicate that a vessel is constrained by her draft, a vessel may display, in a vertical line, __________.
option_b: two 225° red lights
option_c: three 360° blue lights
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel constrained by her draft shall exhibit three all-round red lights in a vertical line. This corresponds to option A (three 360° red lights). This requirement is found in Rule 28 (Vessels Constrained by Their Draught) of the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (COLREGs).

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY  In addition to other required lights, a power-driven vessel pushing ahead or towing alongside displays __________.
option_a: two all-round red lights in a vertical line
option_b: two yellow towing lights in a vertical line
option_c: two white masthead lights in a vertical line
option_d: two lights on the stern, one yellow and one white
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: International Rule 24(c)(i) requires a power-driven vessel pushing ahead or towing alongside (except a composite unit) to exhibit two masthead lights in a vertical line instead of the single masthead light. This is why C is correct.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Which statement is true concerning a vessel "constrained by her draft"?
option_a: She must be a power-driven vessel.
option_b: She is not under command.
option_c: She may be a vessel being towed.
option_d: She is hampered because of her work.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: I'm still learning and can't help with that. Do you need help with anything else?

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY When moving from a berth alongside a quay (wharf), a vessel must sound __________.
option_b: a long blast
option_c: a prolonged blast
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The rule in question is specific to the International Rules (COLREGS). Rule 34(c) dictates that a vessel nearing a bend or an area where other vessels may be obscured must sound one prolonged blast. However, a vessel moving from a berth or quay is not required to sound any signal under the International Rules. Rule 34 does not specify a signal for this maneuver.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY You are in charge of a 250-meter freight vessel constrained by her draft proceeding down a narrow channel.  There is a vessel engaged in fishing on your starboard bow half a mile away. According to Rule 9, which statement is TRUE?
option_a: You are not to impede the fishing vessel.
option_b: If you are in doubt as to the fishing vessel's intentions you may sound at least five short and rapid blasts on the whistle.
option_c: You are to slow to bare steerageway until clear of the fishing vessel.
option_d: You must sound one prolonged blast to alert the fishing vessel.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 34(d) permits sounding at least five short and rapid blasts (danger signal) when in doubt about another vessel's intentions. While Rule 9 addresses narrow channels and suggests the fishing vessel shouldn't impede a vessel constrained by draft, the action of signaling doubt is covered by Rule 34(d).

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY The International Rules of the Road apply __________.
option_a: to all waters which are not inland waters
option_b: only to waters outside the territorial waters of the United States
option_c: only to waters where foreign vessels travel
option_d: upon the high seas and connecting waters navigable by seagoing vessels
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: The International Rules (COLREGs) apply "upon the high seas and connecting waters navigable by seagoing vessels." This is stated in Rule 1(a) of the International Rules in the USCG's Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook. This is why D is the correct answer.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY A towing light is __________.
option_b: white in color
option_c: shown in addition to the stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is C. A towing light is shown in a vertical line above the sternlight. The towing light is yellow and is shown in addition to the sternlight. (Rule 24, Rule 21(a)(iv))

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY In a narrow channel, an overtaking vessel which intends to pass on the other vessel's port side would sound __________.
option_a: one prolonged followed by two short blasts
option_b: one short blast
option_c: two short blasts
option_d: two prolonged followed by two short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(c)(ii) of the International Rules states that a vessel intending to overtake on the port side in a narrow channel shall sound two prolonged blasts followed by two short blasts. This is option D.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY You are underway on the high seas in restricted visibility.  You hear a fog signal of one prolonged and two short blasts.  It could be any of the following EXCEPT a vessel __________.
option_b: engaged in fishing
option_c: constrained by her draft
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The fog signal of one prolonged and two short blasts is sounded by vessels restricted in ability to maneuver, not under command, fishing, or towing, according to International Rule 35(c). A vessel being towed sounds this signal, making it the one that CANNOT be the exception.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY A vessel displaying three red lights in a vertical line is __________.
option_b: aground
option_c: dredging
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 28 (Vessels constrained by their draught) of the International Rules states that a vessel constrained by her draft may exhibit three all-round red lights in a vertical line, in addition to the lights prescribed for power-driven vessels.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY At night, a power-driven vessel underway of less than 7 meters in length where its maximum speed does not exceed 7 knots may show, as a minimum, __________.
option_b: the lights required for a vessel more than 7 meters in length
option_c: sidelights only
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, D, is "one all-round white light." This is the minimum requirement under INTERNATIONAL Rule 23(d)(i) for a power-driven vessel less than 7 meters in length whose maximum speed does not exceed 7 knots.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY In a narrow channel, a signal of intent  which must be answered by the other vessel, is sounded by a vessel __________.
option_b: crossing the course of another
option_c: overtaking another
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 34(c)(i) specifies that a vessel intending to overtake in a narrow channel shall indicate her intention with an appropriate sound signal that MUST be answered by the vessel to be overtaken. Therefore, "overtaking another" (C) is correct.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY When two vessels are in sight of one another, all of the following signals may be given EXCEPT __________.
option_a: a light signal of at least five short and rapid flashes
option_b: four short whistle blasts
option_c: one prolonged, one short, one prolonged and one short whistle blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, four short whistle blasts (Option B), is not an allowed signal under International Rules (COLREGs) when vessels are in sight. Rule 34 outlines the maneuvering and warning signals: one, two, or three short blasts, or the danger signal (at least five short and rapid flashes or blasts). The signal for a vessel making stern propulsion is three short blasts. You can find this information in Rule 34 of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY A power-driven vessel leaving a quay or  wharf must sound what signal?
option_b: A long blast
option_c: A prolonged blast
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(g) of the International Rules (COLREGs) states that a vessel leaving a quay or wharf shall sound no signal. The signals in Rule 34 are for maneuvering and warning. Therefore, "No signal is required" (D) is correct.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY What whistle signal, if any, would be sounded when two vessels are meeting, but will pass clear starboard to starboard?
option_b: Two short blasts
option_c: Five or more short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: When two vessels are meeting and will pass clear of each other starboard to starboard, no whistle signal is required under the International Rules of the Road because neither vessel is altering course or meeting in a crossing situation that necessitates sound signals for passing arrangements.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY In a narrow channel, a vessel trying to  overtake another on the other vessel's port side, would sound a whistle signal of __________.
option_b: two short blasts
option_c: two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast
option_d: two prolonged blasts followed by two short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct signal (D: two prolonged blasts followed by two short blasts) indicates intent to overtake on the port side in a narrow channel, requiring consent. This is in accordance with International Rule 34(e) of the COLREGs (or Rule 34 in the USCG Handbook).

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY On open water, a power-driven vessel coming up dead astern of another vessel and altering her course to starboard so as to pass on the starboard side of  the vessel ahead would sound __________.
option_b: one short blast
option_c: two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast
option_d: one long and one short blast
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, B (one short blast), is prescribed by the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (COLREGS). Rule 34(c)(i) states that a vessel intending to overtake another and pass on the overtaken vessel's starboard side shall sound one short blast. This signal communicates the maneuver intended by the overtaking vessel. The overtaking rule is Rule 13.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY  If a vessel displays three all-round red lights in a vertical line at night, during the day she may  show __________.
option_a: three balls in a vertical line
option_b: a cylinder
option_c: two diamonds in a vertical line
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel constrained by its draught (exhibiting three all-round red lights at night) must show a cylinder during the day. This is covered under Rule 28 (Vessels constrained by their draught) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY A vessel not under command sounds the same fog signal as a vessel __________.
option_b: constrained by her draft
option_c: under sail
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(e) of the International Rules states that a vessel not under command, constrained by her draft, a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver, a sailing vessel, a fishing vessel, or a vessel towing or pushing shall sound one prolonged blast followed by two short blasts.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Your vessel is crossing a narrow channel. A vessel to port is within the channel and crossing your course.  She is showing a black cylinder.  What is your responsibility?
option_b: Sound the danger signal.
option_c: Begin an exchange of passing signals.
option_d: Do not cross the channel if you might impede the other vessel.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Option D is correct as Rule 9(d) states a vessel shall not cross a narrow channel if it impedes a vessel that can only safely navigate within that channel (the vessel showing a black cylinder). This vessel is restricted in ability to maneuver (RAM), giving it right-of-way.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY You are approaching another vessel and will pass starboard to starboard without danger if no course changes are made.  You should __________.
option_a: hold course and sound a two blast whistle signal
option_b: hold course and sound no whistle signal
option_c: change course to the right and sound one blast
option_d: hold course and sound two prolonged and two short blasts
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Under COLREGS Rule 34(c), when two power-driven vessels are meeting or crossing and, if in sight of one another, are passing clear without risk of collision, no signaling is required. Since the vessels are passing clear starboard to starboard without danger and no course change is made, holding course with no whistle signal (Option B) is correct.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A fishing vessel is approaching a vessel not under command.  Which statement is TRUE?
option_a: The fishing vessel must keep clear of the vessel not under  command.
option_b: If the vessel not under command is a power-driven vessel, she must keep clear of the fishing vessel.
option_c: They must exchange whistle signals.
option_d: Both vessels are required to take action to stay clear of each other.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The fishing vessel must keep clear of a vessel not under command because the latter is less maneuverable and has priority. Rule 18 (c)(i) states a vessel engaged in fishing shall keep out of the way of a vessel not under command.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Which signal is required to be sounded by a power-driven vessel ONLY?
option_a: A signal meaning, "I am altering my course to starboard."
option_b: A signal meaning, "I intend to overtake you on your starboard side."
option_c: A signal meaning that the vessel sounding it is in doubt as to the other vessel's actions.
option_d: A signal sounded when approaching a bend.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Under International Rules (COLREGs) Rule 34(a)(i), when power-driven vessels are in sight of one another and altering course, they MUST indicate the maneuver with sound signals. One short blast means "I am altering my course to starboard." This is a signal of *execution* under International Rules, required to be sounded by the maneuvering vessel.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY The light which may be used with a vessel's whistle is to be __________.
option_a: used when the whistle is broken
option_b: used prior to sounding the whistle
option_c: used only at night
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "a white light," is mandated by Rule 36 concerning signals to attract attention. This light must be a white light or an all-round light. International Rule 36 states that any light used to supplement the sound signal must be a single white light.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY You are in sight of another vessel in a  crossing situation, and the other vessel sounds one short blast.  You are going to hold course and speed.  You should __________.
option_b: answer with two short blasts
option_c: sound the danger signal
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: This scenario is under the International Rules. Rule 34(c) dictates that in a crossing situation, if the stand-on vessel (you) maintains course and speed, no whistle signal is sounded in response to the give-way vessel's single short blast. The stand-on vessel only responds if maneuvering to avoid collision.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast on the whistle is a signal which could be sounded by a __________.
option_b: vessel anchored
option_c: mineclearing vessel
option_d: vessel overtaking another in a narrow channel
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, D, is accurate per the International Rules of the Road. Rule 34(c)(i) states that in a narrow channel or fairway, a power-driven vessel intending to overtake on the other vessel's starboard side shall sound two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY In a crossing situation on international waters, a short blast by the give-way vessel indicates that the vessel __________.
option_b: is turning to starboard
option_c: intends to pass port to port
option_d: will keep out of the way of the stand-on vessel
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation:
A short blast (one second) in a crossing situation on international waters indicates a vessel is altering course to starboard. This is defined by COLREGS Rule 34(a)(i), "Maneuvering and Warning Signals."

Rule 34(a)(i) states that one short blast means "I am altering my course to starboard."

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY What day-shape is prescribed for a vessel constrained by her draft?
option_b: A black cone, apex downward
option_c: Two vertical black balls
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel constrained by her draught exhibits a cylinder day-shape, which is option D. This is stated in Rule 28 of the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (COLREGs), which is included in the USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY A vessel not under command sounds the same fog signal as a vessel __________.
option_b: constrained by her draft
option_c: under sail
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(c) states a vessel not under command shall sound the same signal as a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver (RAM). Rule 35(c) signals are also used by vessels: constrained by draft (35(d)), engaged in towing (35(e)), and under sail when not making way (35(e)).

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Which statement(s) is(are) TRUE concerning light signals?
option_a: The time between flashes shall be about five seconds.
option_b: The time between successive signals shall be not less than  ten seconds.
option_c: The light signals are to be used when not using sound signals.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 36 (Signals to attract attention) allows light signals, but they must not be mistaken for any other authorized signal. The time between successive signals must be not less than ten seconds to ensure clarity. (See Rule 36).

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Under what circumstances would an overtaking vessel sound a whistle signal of two prolonged followed by one short blast?
option_b: When overtaking in a narrow channel
option_c: When overtaking on open waters
option_d: When no other vessels are in the immediate area
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The signal, two prolonged followed by one short blast, is an International Inland Rule signal used when overtaking in a narrow channel or fairway and intending to pass on the other vessel's starboard side (Rule 34(c)(ii)). The correct answer is B, "When overtaking in a narrow channel."

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY In which case would an overtaking vessel sound a whistle signal of two prolonged followed by one short blast?
option_b: When overtaking in a narrow channel
option_c: When overtaking on open waters
option_d: When no other vessels are in the immediate area
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, B, is based on International Rule 34(c)(i). When overtaking in a narrow channel, the vessel intending to overtake must signal their intention. Two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast means: "I intend to overtake you on your starboard side."

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY When vessels are in sight of one another, two short blasts from one of the vessels means __________.
option_a: "I am altering my course to starboard"
option_b: "I am altering my course to port"
option_c: "I intend to change course to starboard"
option_d: "I intend to change course to port"
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Under International Rules (COLREGs), Rule 34(a)(ii) states that two short blasts from a power-driven vessel mean "I am altering my course to port." This signal indicates the vessel is taking action, which corresponds to option B. The Inland Rules differ, using signals for intent.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Which vessel may NOT exhibit two red lights in a vertical line?
option_a: A vessel constrained by her draft
option_b: A trawler fishing in close proximity to other trawlers
option_c: A vessel aground
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 28(b) of the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (COLREGs) states that a vessel constrained by her draft shall exhibit three all-round red lights in a vertical line, not two. All other options can exhibit two all-round red lights in a vertical line under Rule 26(d) (trawler fishing in close proximity), Rule 30(d) (vessel aground), and Rule 27 (dredge, restricted in ability to maneuver).

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Vessel "A" is overtaking vessel "B" on open waters and will pass without changing course.  Vessel  "A" __________.
option_b: should sound the danger signal
option_c: should sound one long blast
option_d: will not sound any whistle signals
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Under International Rules (COLREGS), an overtaking vessel in open waters that does not need to change course to pass the vessel being overtaken is not required to sound any whistle signals. This aligns with Rule 34(c), which states that power-driven vessels overtaking one another outside a narrow channel or fairway are not required to give the signals prescribed in Rule 34(c)(i) and (ii).

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Of the vessels listed, which must keep out of the way of all the others?
option_a: A vessel constrained by her draft
option_b: A vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
option_c: A vessel on pilotage duty
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: A vessel on pilotage duty is generally considered a power-driven vessel underway, and according to Rule 18 (Responsibilities Between Vessels), must keep out of the way of all the other listed vessels, which are more privileged: vessel constrained by her draft, vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver, and vessel engaged in fishing.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Which vessel would NOT sound a fog signal of one prolonged and two short blasts?
option_b: A vessel constrained by her draft
option_c: A vessel being towed
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(e) states a vessel being towed sounds one prolonged and three short blasts. Vessels restricted in ability to maneuver, not under command, constrained by draft, sailing, fishing, or towing (among others) sound one prolonged and two short blasts. See Rule 35(c).

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY You intend to overtake a vessel in a narrow channel, and you intend to pass along the vessel's port side.  How should you signal your intention?
option_b: Two prolonged blasts
option_c: Two short blasts
option_d: Two prolonged followed by two short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer is based on International Rule 34(c)(i), which governs maneuvering and warning signals. When intending to overtake in a narrow channel on the port side of the vessel being overtaken, the signaling vessel must sound two prolonged blasts followed by two short blasts.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY A vessel sounds two short blasts.  This  signal indicates the vessel __________.
option_a: intends to alter course to port
option_b: intends to pass starboard to starboard
option_c: is altering course to port
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: INTERNATIONAL ONLY: Two short blasts means "I am altering my course to port." This is an executing signal indicating a vessel is currently turning. See Rule 34(a)(i) of the Navigation Rules (COLREGS).

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY A vessel sounds one short blast.  This signal indicates the vessel __________.
option_a: intends to alter course to starboard
option_b: intends to pass starboard to starboard
option_c: is altering course to starboard
option_d: intends to pass port to port
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The question specifies "INTERNATIONAL ONLY." Under the International Rules of the Road (COLREGS), Rule 34(a)(i) states that one short blast means "I am altering my course to starboard." Therefore, option C, "is altering course to starboard," is correct. (Rule 34)

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY You are underway in a narrow channel, and you are being overtaken by a vessel astern.  After the overtaking vessel sounds the proper signal indicating his intention to pass your vessel on your starboard side, you signal your agreement by sounding __________.
option_b: two prolonged blasts
option_c: two prolonged followed by two short blasts
option_d: one prolonged, one short, one prolonged, and one short blast in that order
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The overtaking vessel's signal is an intention to pass on your starboard side. Under INTERNATIONAL RULES, the vessel being overtaken signals agreement by sounding one prolonged, one short, one prolonged, and one short blast in that order. This is found in Rule 34(c)(ii) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY A sailing vessel is overtaking a power-driven vessel in a narrow channel, so as to pass on the power-driven vessel's port side.  The overtaken vessel  will have to move to facilitate passage.  The sailing vessel is the __________.
option_a: stand-on vessel and would sound two short blasts
option_b: give-way vessel and would sound no whistle signal
option_c: stand-on vessel and would sound no whistle signal
option_d: give-way vessel and would sound two prolonged blasts followed by two short blasts
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The sailing vessel is overtaking, making it the give-way vessel (Rule 13). Since it is passing to port and requires the overtaken vessel to move, the signal is one prolonged blast, followed by one short, one prolonged, and one short blast (Rule 34(c)(i)), indicating agreement and passing to port. The signal in option D is not the correct signal for an agreement to pass on the port side in a narrow channel. The question has a discrepancy in the correct signal as per COLREGS Rule 34.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY A vessel constrained by her draft may display __________.
option_b: two 225° red lights
option_c: three all-round blue lights
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel constrained by her draft may display three all-round red lights in a vertical line. This is found in the International Rules, COLREG Rule 28.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Two power-driven vessels are meeting.  A two blast whistle signal by either vessel means __________.
option_a: "I intend to alter course to port"
option_b: "I desire to pass starboard to starboard"
option_c: "I desire to pass port to port"
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: A two-blast signal indicates a vessel is taking action to alter course to port, as per Rule 34(a)(i) of the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (COLREGs). The question specifies "INTERNATIONAL ONLY" and the meaning is about the action being taken.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY A 20-meter power-driven vessel pushing ahead or towing alongside will display __________.
option_b: two masthead lights in a vertical line
option_c: two towing lights in a vertical line
option_d: two all-round red lights where they can best be seen
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Correct answer B is "two masthead lights in a vertical line." COLREGs Rule 24(c)(i) states a power-driven vessel pushing ahead or towing alongside (except a composite unit) shall exhibit "two masthead lights in a vertical line" instead of the normal light(s) prescribed in Rule 23.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Which statement applies to a vessel "constrained by her draft"?
option_a: She is severely restricted in her ability to change her course because of her draft in relation to the available depth of water.
option_b: The term applies only to vessels in marked channels.
option_c: She is designated as a "vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver".
option_d: The vessel must be over 100 meters in length.
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: The correct answer, A, aligns with Rule 3(h) of the International Regulations (COLREGs), which defines a "vessel constrained by her draft" as a power-driven vessel severely restricted in its ability to deviate from the course it is following due to its draft in relation to the available depth and width of navigable water.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY A whistle signal of one prolonged, one short, one prolonged and one short blast, is sounded by a vessel __________.
option_b: towing a submerged object
option_c: being overtaken in a narrow channel
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(c) states that when a vessel is being overtaken in a narrow channel or fairway, the overtaking vessel shall sound one prolonged, one short, one prolonged, and one short blast to indicate agreement to the maneuver.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Your vessel is backing out of a slip in a harbor and you can see that other vessels are approaching.  You should sound __________.
option_a: three short blasts when leaving the slip
option_b: one prolonged blast followed by three short blasts when the last line is taken aboard
option_c: one prolonged blast only
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, A, is "three short blasts when leaving the slip." Under the International Rules, a power-driven vessel operating astern (backing out of a slip) must sound three short blasts. See Rule 34(a)(i) in the USCG Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Which vessel is to keep out of the way of the others?
option_a: A vessel constrained by her draft
option_b: A vessel engaged in underwater operations
option_c: A vessel engaged in trawling
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The question asks which vessel is to keep out of the way of the others. According to Rule 18 (Responsibilities between Vessels), a vessel not under command (Option D) is at the top of the hierarchy, meaning all other vessels must keep clear of it. Therefore, a vessel engaged in trawling (Option C) must keep out of the way of a vessel not under command.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY You are in sight of a power-driven vessel that sounds two short blasts of the whistle.  This signal means that the vessel __________.
option_b: is altering course to starboard
option_c: intends to leave you on her port side
option_d: intends to leave you on her starboard side
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Two short blasts indicate a power-driven vessel is altering course to port. This is in accordance with the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (COLREGS) Rule 34(a)(ii) for maneuvering and warning signals.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY You are operating a vessel in a narrow channel.  Your vessel must stay within the channel to be navigated safely.  Another vessel is crossing your course from starboard to port, and you are in doubt as to his intentions.  According to Rule 9, you __________.
option_b: must sound one prolonged and two short blasts
option_c: should sound one short blast to indicate that you are holding course and speed
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 9(d) states a vessel in a narrow channel that doubts another vessel's intentions "may sound the appropriate signal prescribed in Rule 34(d)." Rule 34(d) is the danger signal (5 short blasts). See Rule 9 & Rule 34(d) in the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY If you sighted three red lights in a vertical line on another vessel at night, it would be a vessel __________.
option_b: constrained by her draft
option_c: dredging
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The vessel is "constrained by her draft." Rule 28 of the COLREGs (International Rules) states that a vessel constrained by her draught may exhibit three all-round red lights in a vertical line. This is why answer B is correct.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY On open water two vessels are in an overtaking situation.  The overtaking vessel has just sounded one short blast on the whistle.  What is the meaning of this whistle signal?
option_a: "I request permission to pass you on my port side."
option_b: "I will maintain course and speed and pass you on your starboard side."
option_c: "On which side should I pass?"
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: One short blast means the vessel is altering course to starboard (Rule 34(a)(i), International). This is a maneuvering signal indicating intent, and in an overtaking situation, it signals a change of course to pass on the port side.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY You are underway in fog and hear a fog signal consisting of one prolonged and two short blasts.  It could be any of the following EXCEPT a vessel __________.
option_b: engaged in fishing
option_c: constrained by her draft
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 35(e) states that a vessel being towed, if manned, may sound one prolonged and three short blasts. The signal of one prolonged and two short blasts is used by vessels restricted in their ability to maneuver, constrained by draft, fishing, or mine clearance (Rule 35(c)).

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Which vessel shall avoid impeding the safe passage of a vessel constrained by her draft?
option_b: A fishing vessel
option_c: A vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 18(d)(i) states that any vessel other than a Vessel Not Under Command or a Vessel Restricted in Her Ability to Maneuver shall avoid impeding a Vessel Constrained by Her Draft. A fishing vessel is not one of the exempted vessels, thus it must avoid impeding. See Rule 18 (Responsibilities between vessels) in the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY A signal of one prolonged, one short, one prolonged, and one short blast, in that order is given by a vessel __________.
option_b: in distress
option_c: at anchor
option_d: being overtaken in a narrow channel
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer is "being overtaken in a narrow channel" because that signal is required under International Rule 34(c)(ii) for a vessel intending to overtake in a narrow channel when the signal for permission has been agreed upon, or by the overtaken vessel when acknowledging safe passage. The signal is given by the overtaken vessel to agree to the maneuver.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Which signal is sounded ONLY by a vessel in sight of another and NOT in or near an area of restricted visibility?
option_a: Four short blasts on the whistle
option_b: One prolonged blast on the whistle
option_c: One short blast on the whistle
option_d: One short, one prolonged, and one short blast on the whistle
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: One short blast indicates a maneuver when vessels are in sight of one another (Rule 34(a)(i)). Signals for restricted visibility apply when vessels are not in sight (Rule 35/83.35, not 83.19). This maneuver signal is only used when in sight of another vessel, not in restricted visibility.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY In addition to her running lights, an underway vessel constrained by her draft may carry in a vertical line __________.
option_a: a red light, a white light, and a red light
option_b: two red lights
option_c: two white lights
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Option D is correct as Rule 28 of the COLREGs (Vessels constrained by their draught) states that such a vessel may exhibit three all-round red lights in a vertical line, in addition to the lights for a power-driven vessel. See Rule 28 in the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Which vessel is NOT regarded as being "restricted in her ability to maneuver"?
option_a: A vessel servicing an aid to navigation
option_b: A vessel engaged in dredging
option_c: A towing vessel with tow unable to deviate from its course
option_d: A vessel constrained by her draft
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: "A vessel constrained by her draft" (option D) is not included in the list of vessels "restricted in their ability to maneuver" under Rule 3(g) of the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (COLREGs). Rule 3(h) defines a "vessel constrained by her draft" separately.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY When two vessels are in sight of one another and NOT in or near an area of restricted visibility, any of the following signals may be given EXCEPT __________.
option_a: a light signal of at least five short and rapid flashes
option_b: one prolonged, one short, one prolonged, and one short whistle blasts
option_c: four short whistle blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Four short blasts is NOT a defined signal under INTERNATIONAL Rule 34 for vessels in sight. Signals allowed include: one short (altering course to starboard), two short (altering course to port), three short (astern propulsion), five or more rapid light flashes (warning), or the dash-dot-dash-dot whistle signal (Rule 35, though used in restricted vis. it is allowed as a warning signal). Reference Rule 34.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY In a narrow channel, an overtaking vessel which intends to PASS on the other vessel's port side would sound __________.
option_a: one prolonged followed by two short blasts
option_b: one short blast
option_c: two prolonged followed by two short blasts
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "two prolonged followed by two short blasts," is prescribed by International Rule 34(c)(i) for a vessel intending to overtake on the port side in a narrow channel. The overtaking vessel must first sound this signal.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast on the whistle is a signal which would be sounded by a vessel __________.
option_a: overtaking another in a narrow channel
option_b: anchored
option_c: engaged in mineclearance
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: This signal indicates intent to overtake on the other vessel's starboard side in a narrow channel (International Rule 34(c)(i)). The vessel being overtaken must reply with one prolonged, one short, one prolonged, and one short blast if in agreement.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY You intend to overtake a vessel in a narrow channel, and you intend to pass along the vessel's port side.  How should you signal your intention?
option_a: Two short blasts followed by two prolonged blasts
option_b: Two prolonged followed by two short blasts
option_c: Two prolonged blasts only
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(c)(i) (International) states that a vessel intending to overtake another in a narrow channel must indicate its intention by sounding two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast to pass on the other vessel's starboard side, and two prolonged followed by two short blasts to pass on the other vessel's port side. The question states the intent is to pass along the vessel's port side.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY You are underway in a narrow channel, and you are being overtaken by a vessel astern.  After the overtaking vessel sounds the proper signal indicating his intention to pass your vessel on your starboard side, you signal your agreement by sounding __________.
option_a: two prolonged followed by two short blasts
option_b: one prolonged, one short, one prolonged, and one short blast
option_c: one short blast
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer is B because International Rule 34(c)(i) states a vessel being overtaken must sound "one prolonged, one short, one prolonged and one short blast" to signify agreement to the overtaking maneuver.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Vessel "A" is overtaking vessel "B" on open waters and will pass without changing course. Vessel "A" should __________.
option_a: sound two prolonged blasts followed by two short blasts
option_b: sound the danger signal
option_c: not sound any whistle signals
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation:
Rule 34(c)(ii) of the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (COLREGS) states that a vessel intending to overtake another and passing without changing course should not sound any whistle signals. Since the vessels are on open waters and A is passing without changing course, whistle signals are not required.

Reference: Rule 34(c)(ii) of COLREGS.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Which signal is sounded ONLY by a vessel in sight of another?
option_a: One short blast on the whistle
option_b: Four short blasts on the whistle
option_c: One prolonged blast on the whistle
option_d: One short, one prolonged, and one short blast on the whistle
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(a)(i) of the International Rules (COLREGs) states that "one short blast" is used to mean "I am altering my course to starboard." This is a maneuvering signal used ONLY when vessels are in sight of one another.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY The light which may be used with a vessel's whistle must be __________.
option_a: used when the whistle is broken
option_b: a white light
option_c: used only at night
option_d: used prior to sounding the whistle
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: The correct answer, 'a white light,' is stipulated in the International Rules (COLREGS), Rule 34(b), concerning maneuvering and warning signals. The rule states that a vessel may use an all-round white light, visible for the duration of the whistle signal, to supplement the sound signal.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Which statement is TRUE concerning light signals?
option_a: The time between flashes shall be about five seconds.
option_b: The light signals are to be used when not using sound signals.
option_c: The time between successive signals shall be not less than  ten seconds.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 36 of the COLREGS states that for an attention-directing light signal, "The time between successive signals shall be not less than ten seconds." This confirms option C is correct.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY While underway and in sight of another vessel, you put your engines full speed astern. Which statement concerning whistle signals is TRUE?
option_a: You must sound three short blasts on the whistle.
option_b: You must sound one blast if backing to starboard.
option_c: You must sound whistle signals only if the vessels are meeting.
option_d: You need not sound any whistle signals.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation:
Rule 34(a)(iii) of the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (COLREGS) states that a vessel operating astern propulsion in sight of another vessel must sound three short blasts to indicate "I am operating astern propulsion."

(Reference: 33 CFR § 83.34)

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY While underway at night, a power-driven vessel of less than 7 meters in length, whose maximum speed which does not exceed 7 knots, may show __________.
option_a: sidelights combined in a single lantern, only
option_b: an all-round flashing yellow light, only
option_c: one all-round white light, only
option_d: a lantern showing a white light exhibited in sufficient time to prevent collision, only
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "one all-round white light, only," aligns with COLREGs Rule 23(d)(ii), which permits power-driven vessels of less than 7 meters whose maximum speed does not exceed 7 knots to exhibit an all-round white light.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY At night, a power-driven vessel less than 7 meters in length, with a maximum speed which does not exceed 7 knots, MUST show when underway at least __________.
option_b: a white light on the near approach of another vessel
option_c: sidelights and a stern light
option_d: the lights required of a vessel less than 12 meters in length
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is A because INTERNATIONAL Rule 23(d)(i) states that a power-driven vessel less than 7 meters in length whose maximum speed does not exceed 7 knots may exhibit an all-round white light, and if practicable, sidelights. The minimum requirement is the all-round white light (one white 360° light).

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Lighting requirements in inland waters are different from those for international waters for __________.
option_b: vessels restricted in their ability to maneuver
option_c: vessels towing astern
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "barges being pushed ahead" (A), is correct because Rule 24(g) specifies unique lighting for vessels pushing ahead or towing alongside on U.S. Inland Waters (requiring sidelights and two towing lights), whereas International Rules (Rule 24(c)) treat it as a pushing vessel and the vessel being pushed as one unit, only requiring lights applicable to a single power-driven vessel. See Rule 24 (Towing and Pushing).

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY  A 20-meter power-driven vessel pushing  ahead or towing alongside will display __________.
option_a: two towing lights in a vertical line
option_b: a towing light above the stern light
option_c: two all-round red lights at the masthead
option_d: two masthead lights in a vertical line
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is "two masthead lights in a vertical line" because Rule 24(c)(i) of the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (COLREGs) requires a power-driven vessel when pushing ahead or towing alongside to exhibit two masthead lights in a vertical line instead of a single masthead light.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL &  INLAND  A towing light __________.
option_a: flashes at regular intervals of 50-70 flashes per minute
option_b: is yellow in color
option_c: shows an unbroken light over an arc of the horizon of not less than 180° nor more than 225°
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A towing light is yellow in color. This is specified in the definitions related to navigation lights and shapes. For the context of towing and the lights required, refer to Rule 24 (Towing and Pushing) and the definitions within the USCG Navigation Rules.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A towing light is __________.
option_b: white in color
option_c: displayed at the masthead
option_d: a yellow light having the same characteristics as the stern light
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 21(d) states a towing light is an all-round yellow light with the same characteristics as the stern light. Therefore, option D is correct.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY A light used to signal passing intentions must be an __________.
option_b: alternating white and yellow light
option_c: all-round white or yellow light
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(b)(i) of the COLREGs (International Rules) states that a power-driven vessel must use an all-round white light, visible for at least 5 miles, to signal passing intentions. The correct answer is an "all-round white light only."

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY A vessel constrained by her draft may display __________.
option_a: three all-round red lights instead of the lights required for a power-driven vessel of her class
option_b: the same lights as a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
option_c: three all-round red lights in addition to the lights required for a power-driven vessel of her class
option_d: the lights for a power-driven vessel which is not under command
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel constrained by her draft may display three all-round red lights in a vertical line in addition to the lights for a power-driven vessel. This is found in Rule 28 of the COLREGs (International) which are included in the USCG’s Navigation Rules Handbook.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Which day-shape is prescribed for a vessel constrained by her draft?
option_b: A cylinder
option_c: A black ball
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct day-shape is a cylinder (B). Rule 28 (Vessels Constrained by their Draught) of the International Rules prescribes a cylinder for a vessel constrained by her draft, in addition to the lights for a power-driven vessel.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY If at night a vessel displays three all-round red lights in a vertical line, during the day she may show __________.
option_b: three black balls in a vertical line
option_c: a cylinder
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The vessel displaying three all-round red lights in a vertical line is a vessel constrained by its draft (International Rule only). The day shape for a vessel constrained by its draft is a cylinder. This is covered under Rule 28 in the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY A vessel displaying three red lights in a vertical line is __________.
option_a: restricted in her ability to maneuver
option_b: not under command
option_c: engaged in mineclearing operations
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: A vessel displaying three all-round red lights in a vertical line is constrained by her draft (D). This signal is specific to International Rules. See Rule 28 of the USCG Amalgamated Navigation Rules International & U.S. Inland.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY The International Rules of the Road apply __________.
option_b: to any waters inside the territorial waters of the U.S.
option_c: only to waters where foreign vessels travel
option_d: upon the high seas and connecting waters navigable by seagoing vessels
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: As a mariner, I can tell you that the International Rules of the Road (COLREGs) apply "upon the high seas and connecting waters navigable by seagoing vessels." This is stated in Rule 1(a) of the COLREGs, which is found in the USCG’s Navigation Rules Handbook.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY  Which statement applies to a vessel "constrained by her draft"?
option_a: The term only applies to vessels in narrow channels.
option_b: She is severely restricted in her ability to change her course because of her draft in relation to the available depth and width of navigable water.
option_c: She is designated as a "vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver".
option_d: The vessel must be over 100 meters in length.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Option B is correct because Rule 3(h) defines a vessel "constrained by her draft" as one that is severely restricted in its ability to change course due to its draft in relation to available depth and width of navigable water. This term is for international waters only (Rule 28).

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY  Which statement is TRUE concerning a vessel "constrained by her draft"?
option_a: She is hampered because of her work.
option_b: She is unable to maneuver due to some exceptional circumstance.
option_c: She may be a vessel being towed.
option_d: She must be a power-driven vessel.
question_category: Part A: General
answer_explanation: Rule 3(h) of the COLREGs states that a vessel constrained by her draught means a power-driven vessel that is severely restricted in her ability to deviate from course due to her draught in relation to the available depth and width of navigable water. Therefore, the statement "She must be a power-driven vessel" is TRUE.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Which vessel is NOT "restricted in her ability to maneuver"?
option_a: A vessel servicing an aid to navigation
option_b: A vessel constrained by her draft
option_c: A towing vessel with tow, unable to deviate from its course
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 3(h) of the COLREGs (International Rules) defines a "vessel constrained by her draft" as a power-driven vessel severely restricted in its ability to deviate from course due to its draft. This is a distinct category from a "vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver," which is defined in Rule 3(g).

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Your vessel is constrained by her draft and operating in a narrow channel. Another vessel is crossing your course from starboard to port.  You are in doubt as to her intentions.  According to Rule 9, you __________.
option_a: should sound one short blast to indicate that you are holding course and speed
option_b: must sound one prolonged blast
option_c: may sound the danger signal
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer is C because under International Rule 9(d) for Narrow Channels, if a vessel which can only safely navigate within the channel is in doubt as to the intention of the crossing vessel, it may sound the danger signal (at least 5 short and rapid blasts).

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Your vessel is crossing a narrow channel. A vessel to port is within the channel and crossing your course. She is showing a black cylinder. You should __________.
option_b: not impede the other vessel
option_c: exchange passing signals
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The vessel showing a black cylinder is likely deep-draught, restricted to the channel. Rule 9(d) states vessels shall not cross a narrow channel if it impedes a vessel that can only navigate safely within it. Therefore, you must "not impede the other vessel" (B). Found in Rule 9 (Narrow Channels).

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Your vessel is backing out of a slip in  a harbor.  Visibility is restricted. You should sound __________.
option_b: one prolonged blast followed by three short blasts when the last line is taken aboard
option_c: one prolonged blast followed by three short blasts when leaving the slip
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(c) of the COLREGS states a vessel leaving a berth or slip shall sound one prolonged blast. This applies when backing out in restricted visibility, regardless of whether it's power-driven or sailing. The correct answer, one prolonged blast only, is in accordance with this rule.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY  You are approaching another vessel and  will pass safely starboard to starboard without changing course.  You should __________.
option_a: hold course and sound no whistle signal
option_b: hold course and sound a two blast whistle signal
option_c: change course to starboard and sound one blast
option_d: hold course and sound one blast
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, "hold course and sound no whistle signal," is correct because the vessels are approaching to pass safely starboard to starboard without changing course. International Rule 34(c) states that if vessels are in sight and action is not required, no sound signal should be given.

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND  Which statement is TRUE concerning a situation involving a fishing vessel and a vessel not under command?
option_a: They are required to communicate by radiotelephone.
option_b: If the vessel not under command is a power-driven vessel, she must keep clear of the fishing vessel.
option_c: The fishing vessel must keep out of the way of the vessel not under command.
option_d: Both vessels are required to take action to stay clear of each other.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: COLREGs Rule 18(c)(i) states a vessel engaged in fishing shall, so far as possible, keep out of the way of a vessel not under command. Therefore, option C is correct. (Rule 18, Responsibilities between vessels)

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Of the vessels listed, which must keep out of the way of all the others?
option_a: A vessel constrained by her draft
option_b: A vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
option_c: A vessel pushing a barge
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Rule 18 of the COLREGs establishes the hierarchy of vessels. A power-driven vessel underway (which includes a vessel pushing a barge) must keep out of the way of a vessel constrained by her draft, a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver, and a vessel engaged in fishing. Therefore, the vessel pushing a barge must keep out of the way of all the others listed.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Which vessel shall avoid impeding the safe passage of a vessel constrained by her draft?
option_b: A sailing vessel
option_c: A vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: A sailing vessel shall keep out of the way of a vessel constrained by her draft. This is stated in International Rule 18(a)(ii) of the Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY A signal of intent must be sounded in international waters by __________.
option_b: a vessel overtaking another in a narrow channel
option_c: a vessel crossing the course of another
option_d: the give-way vessel in a crossing situation
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation:
Rule 34(c) states that a vessel intending to overtake in a narrow channel or fairway must sound the appropriate signal. Option B describes this exact scenario. This is an International Rule.

(Rule 34: Maneuvering and Warning Signals)

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY A light used to signal passing intentions must be an __________.
option_b: all-round white light only
option_c: all-round blue light only
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation: Rule 34(b)(i) of the International Rules states that a power-driven vessel intending to overtake must indicate that intention by sounding a whistle signal, and may supplement this with an all-round white light. The light is required for the passing intention signal.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY  Which statement is TRUE, according to the Rules?
option_a: A vessel engaged in fishing while underway shall, so far as possible, keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver.
option_b: A vessel not under command shall keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver.
option_c: A fishing vessel while underway has the right-of-way over a vessel constrained by her draft.
option_d: A vessel not under command shall avoid impeding the safe passage of a vessel constrained by her draft.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Option A is correct per Rule 18(c) of the COLREGs (or Rule 18(c) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules for vessels in sight of one another). A vessel engaged in fishing must keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY A light used to signal passing intentions must be an __________.
option_b: all-round yellow light only
option_c: all-round white light only
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
