answer_explanation: Rule 34(b) of the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (COLREGs) states that a vessel may indicate passing intentions by flashing five or more short and rapid flashes of the masthead light or all-round white light.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY  Which statement is TRUE, according to the Rules?
option_a: A vessel constrained by her draft shall keep out of the way of a vessel engaged in fishing.
option_b: A vessel engaged in fishing while underway shall, so far as possible, keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver.
option_c: A vessel not under command shall avoid impeding the safe passage of a vessel constrained by her draft.
option_d: A vessel not under command shall keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: The correct answer, B, is true because, according to the International Rules (COLREGs), a vessel restricted in its ability to maneuver has higher precedence than a vessel engaged in fishing. Rule 18(c) states that a vessel engaged in fishing shall keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY Which statement is TRUE, according to the Rules?
option_a: A vessel engaged in fishing while underway shall, so far as possible, keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver.
option_b: A vessel not under command shall keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver.
option_c: A vessel engaged in fishing shall keep out of the way of a sailing vessel.
option_d: A vessel not under command shall keep out of the way of a vessel engaged in fishing.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Option A is correct per Rule 18(c)(ii) (Responsibilities between Vessels). The hierarchy of responsibility dictates that a vessel engaged in fishing must keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY  Which statement is TRUE, according to the Rules?
option_a: A vessel not under command shall keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver.
option_b: A vessel not under command shall avoid impeding the safe passage of a vessel constrained by her draft.
option_c: A vessel constrained by her draft shall keep out of the way of a vessel engaged in fishing.
option_d: A vessel engaged in fishing while underway shall, so far as possible, keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules
answer_explanation: Option D is correct because vessels restricted in their ability to maneuver are generally stand-on vessels to vessels engaged in fishing. A vessel engaged in fishing must keep out of the way of a vessel restricted in her ability to maneuver. See Rule 18 of the International Rules.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY What characteristic must a light have if used to signal passing intentions?
option_a: It must be an all-round white light.
option_b: It must be an alternating blue and white light.
option_c: It must be an all-round white or yellow light.
option_d: It must be an alternating red and yellow light.
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: The correct answer is A because Rule 34(b)(i) of the INTERNATIONAL Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (COLREGs) states that a vessel intending to overtake must indicate this by two prolonged blasts followed by one short blast on the whistle and exhibit an all-round white light.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY What characteristic must a light used to indicate passing intentions have?
option_a: It must be an all-round red light.
option_b: It must be an all-round white light.
option_c: It must be an all-round yellow light.
option_d: It can be either an all-round white or yellow light.
question_category: Part D: Sounds and Light Signals
answer_explanation:
The correct answer, "It must be an all-round white light," is mandated by the International Rules (COLREGS). Rule 34(a)(i) requires a short, single flash of the all-round white light to indicate passing intentions.

Reference: Rule 34(a)(i) of the USCG’s Navigation Rules and Regulations Handbook.

question_text: INTERNATIONAL ONLY A power-driven vessel pushing ahead or towing alongside will show sidelights, a stern light,  and __________.
option_a: an all-round red light where it can best be seen
option_b: two yellow masthead lights in a vertical line
option_c: two masthead lights in a vertical line
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes
answer_explanation: Rule 24(c) of the International Regulations requires a power-driven vessel pushing ahead or towing alongside to exhibit sidelights, a sternlight, and two masthead lights in a vertical line instead of the single masthead light prescribed in Rule 23(a)(i) or (ii).

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel fishing should display which of the day signals shown.
option_b: B
option_c: C
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In the situation illustrated, vessel I is a power-driven vessel. Vessel II is a sailing vessel with the wind dead aft.  Which statement about this situation is correct?
option_a: Vessel I should keep out of the way of Vessel II.
option_b: Vessel II should keep out of the way of Vessel I.
option_c: Vessel II would normally be the stand-on vessel, but should stay out of the way in this particular situation.
option_d: The Rules of Special Circumstances applies, and neither vessel is the stand-on vessel.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Two sailing vessels are approaching each other as shown.  Which statement is correct?
option_a: Vessel "I" should stand on because she has the wind on her  port side.
option_b: Vessel "II" should stand on because she has the wind on her starboard side.
option_c: Neither vessel is the stand-on vessel because they are meeting head-on.
option_d: Vessel "I" should stand on because she is close-hauled.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Vessel "A" is underway and pushing ahead when vessel "B" is sighted off the starboard  bow as shown.  Which statement is TRUE?
option_a: Vessel "A" is the stand-on vessel because it is to the port side of vessel "B".
option_b: Vessel "A" is the stand-on vessel because it is pushing ahead.
option_c: Vessel "B" is the stand-on vessel because it is to starboard of vessel "A".
option_d: Neither vessel is the stand-on vessel.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND As shown, vessel "A", which is pushing ahead, and vessel "B" are crossing.  Which is the stand-on vessel?
option_a: Vessel "A" is the stand-on vessel because she is to port of vessel "B".
option_b: Vessel "A" is the stand-on vessel because she is pushing ahead.
option_c: Vessel "B" is the stand-on vessel because she is to starboard of vessel "A".
option_d: Neither vessel is the stand-on vessel in this situation.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel which displays the day signal shown may be engaged in __________.
option_b: pilotage duty
option_c: fishing
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND You see a vessel displaying the day signal shown.  The vessel may be __________.
option_b: fishing with trawls
option_c: laying cable
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway, you see a vessel displaying the day-shapes shown. Which action  should you take?
option_b: Provide assistance, the other vessel is in distress
option_c: Stay clear, the other vessel is maneuvering with difficulty
option_d: Stop your vessel and sound passing signals
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND While underway you sight a vessel displaying the day-shapes shown.  You should __________.
option_a: contact the vessel on VHF radiotelephone
option_b: provide assistance, the other vessel is in distress
option_c: stay clear, the other vessel cannot get out of the way
option_d: stop your vessel and sound passing signals
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel displaying the day signal shown is __________.
option_b: a dredge underway and dredging
option_c: fishing
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel displaying the day-shapes shown is __________.
option_b: fishing
option_c: a minesweeper
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND In DIAGRAM 8, vessel "A" and vessel "B" (which is pushing ahead) are meeting head-on as shown.  How must the vessels pass?
option_a: Vessel "A" must alter course while vessel "B" continues on  its present course.
option_b: The vessels should determine which will alter course by exchanging whistle signals.
option_c: Both vessels should alter course to port and pass starboard to starboard.
option_d: Both vessels should alter course to starboard and pass port to port.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules

question_text: INLAND ONLY You are on vessel "B" and vessel "A" desires to overtake you on your starboard side as shown.  After the vessels have exchanged one blast signals, you should __________.
option_b: slow your vessel until vessel "A" has passed
option_c: hold course and speed
option_d: alter course to the left or right to give vessel "A" more sea room
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND Vessel "A" is overtaking vessel "B" as shown.  Which vessel is the stand-on vessel?
option_b: Vessel "B"
option_c: Neither vessel
option_d: Both vessels must keep clear of the other.
question_category: Part B: Steering and Sailing Rules

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel displaying the day-shape shown __________.
option_b: is not under command
option_c: has a tow that exceeds 200 meters in length
option_d: has a tow that is carrying dangerous cargo
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel displaying the day shape shown is __________.
option_b: anchored
option_c: towing
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A tugboat displaying the day-shape shown __________.
option_b: is not under command
option_c: has a tow that exceeds 200 meters in length
option_d: has a tow that is carrying dangerous cargo
question_category: Part C: Lights and Shapes

question_text: BOTH INTERNATIONAL & INLAND A vessel displaying the day-shapes shown is __________.
option_b: conducting underwater operations
option_c: drifting
